HEADLINE: The Qaeda Vipers In Europe's Bosom 

BYLINE:  By Jonathan Stevenson; Jonathan Stevenson is senior fellow for counterterrorism at the International Institute for Strategic Studies.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
Make no mistake: the United States is still Al Qaeda's main enemy. But it's become morbidly obvious in the last few months, with terrorist attacks in Indonesia and Kenya, that Al Qaeda has expanded its "fields of jihad." That development should be a particular cause of concern for Europe, where much of the planning of the Sept. 11 attacks was done and where perhaps thousands of Al Qaeda affiliates live. Just this week, the Italian police arrested 28 Pakistanis suspected of links to Al Qaeda. 
 It is no surprise that the 15 million Muslims in the European Union should be ripe for recruitment by Al Qaeda. They live on the margins of European society, socially, economically and politically. More than 100 British Muslims joined the Taliban in Afghanistan to try to repel American and allied forces, and up to 3,000 British Muslims have undergone military training at terrorist camps in Afghanistan since 1996. Radical clerics preach war against the West in Europe's mosques. European citizens like Richard C. Reid of Britain, who just received a life sentence for trying to ignite a bomb in his shoes on a trans-Atlantic flight, and Zacarias Moussaoui of France, described by prosecutors as the would-be 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks, were converts to militant Islam. 
 For the sake of the United States, Europe needs to tackle the root causes that make young Muslims resort to terrorism. But it needs to act to protect itself as well. So far, there have been no Al Qaeda attacks carried out in Europe, but officials say they have thwarted several plots. Over the last six weeks, the police in France, Spain and Britain, as well as Italy, have arrested more than 50 terrorism suspects, some in possession of the deadly poison ricin, disrupting what was apparently a Qaeda network. 
The obvious first steps are tightened border security and a Europe-wide immigration policy that would allow for better monitoring of who is applying for visas where, and expanded intelligence and law-enforcement links. But in the long term they won't be enough. Europe also needs to resolve the economic and political problems that could make Al Qaeda attractive to a young Muslim. The tough question is how to do it.
Aggressive anti-discrimination policies in employment and education may help. The most rigorous fair employment laws in Europe, verging on affirmative action, are in effect in Northern Ireland. Workers there are entitled to damages even if they have been only indirectly and unintentionally discriminated against. Such provisions have probably kept young Catholics from joining the Irish Republican Army. 
More focused government subsidies for Muslim schools that follow a moderate form of Islam would also be salutary. Britain has begun limited subsidies to Muslim schools, but has made no effort to encourage moderate Islam education as opposed to fundamentalism, whose support by wealthy Wahhabi Muslims gives it an advantage. Another possible remedy could be government benefits for businesses operated by Muslims. Such economic and education policies would be conducive to participation in politics, in which Muslims are seriously underrepresented. 
More broadly, European nations like Britain need to end reflexive multiculturalism -- for example, lax language and cultural education requirements for naturalization -- that perversely discourages Muslims from learning the ways of their new countries, thus isolating them from the mainstream and fueling radicalization. Stricter requirements for citizenship may also dissolve racial or religious biases among majority populations. 
In theory, France, which wants its five million Muslims to think of themselves as Frenchmen, provides a good model. It encourages a secular view of French citizenship by promoting a strict separation of church and state. It requires candidates for naturalization to speak serviceable French and know basic French history and culture. Though criticized by some orthodox French Muslims, the new government-endorsed Council for the Muslim Religion should help secure a position for Muslims in the civic mainstream and produce an indigenous, moderate version of Islam. 
Politically, the European Union could soften Muslims' views of the West by moving ahead on Turkey's bid to join the union -- for instance, by setting a definite date for talks on membership. That would send the message that secular Muslim countries are considered partners of Western nations. Further, the union could emphasize the economic links between Europe and the Persian Gulf nations and its financial support for the Palestinian Authority. It should also revitalize the 27-member European-Mediterranean Partnership, which was established in 1995 with high hopes of deepening ties among the countries of the Mediterranean but became enervated because of the second Palestinian intifada and Sept. 11. 
Al Qaeda has proven a resilient, pragmatic and elusive network of networks. It may take a generation to eradicate all its branches. But if the causes of radical Islam are not eradicated also, another network will rise to take Al Qaeda's place. Europe has the ideals, institutions and resources to change the attitudes of its radical Muslim population. What it does could be a model for the rest of the world.

HEADLINE: Japan Posts Gloomy Numbers, And Fears of Recession Return 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
Japan's jobless rate matched a record high in December, one of several indicators that show that the economy stalled in the last quarter of 2002.
 The gloomy figures, which include declines in consumer spending, new-home starts and production, suggest that Japan may be nearing its fourth recession in the last decade. They also come just after the government passed an extra budget worth $25 billion. The package, which includes expanded payments for the newly unemployed, will only offset a more severe slowdown, not bolster the slowing economy, analysts said. 
 Hemmed in by a bulging budget deficit, policy makers are stepping up calls on the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy further. But anything less than a drastic turnaround in current policy will not jump-start growth because of the government's plan to push banks to write off their bad loans, a strategy that will most likely lead to more bankruptcies and unemployment.
Emerging signs of a slowdown in the United States, deepening deflation at home and jitters over the possibility of war in Iraq have helped push the benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index to near two-decade lows. Government bond yields have also fallen to record lows, leading some to speculate a bubble has formed in the credit market.
The government has played down the risks to the economy. Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa said the economy was "not very bad." Yet Mr. Shiokawa, alarmed that the yen's recent strength could sap Japanese exports, warned that his ministry was prepared to buy dollars.
Shipments of automobiles, computer chips and machinery to other parts of Asia and the United States have been one of the few drivers of Japan's $4.4 trillion economy. Growth in exports, however, has moderated in recent months.
The unemployment rate matched a record 5.5 percent in December. Spending by wage earners declined 3.5 percent in December, the third consecutive decline. New-home starts also fell 3.4 percent.
Consumer prices, too, continued their slide. Prices in Tokyo fell 0.4 percent this month, compared with those in the month a year earlier.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Dow Is Up for Day but Is Down for 3rd Consecutive Week

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors took chances on blue-chip stocks yesterday, picking up bargains after the decline of nearly 900 points in the Dow Jones industrial average in the last two weeks. But the buying was not enough to save Wall Street from its third consecutive weekly decline, a slide not seen in nearly four months, or from heavy losses for the month.
 Analysts attributed the day's gains to investors' seeking lower-priced stocks rather than improving sentiment about the market or the economy, especially since the news on both fronts was mixed yesterday. The blue-chip advance came despite investors' continued concerns that a war with Iraq would derail what has already been feeble economic progress. 
 "Is there anything that has significantly changed that justifies or is driving this rally?" said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "And my answer to that question is no."
The Dow closed up 108.68 points, or 1.4 percent, to 8,053.81. For the week, the Dow lost 1 percent.
The broader market was mixed, with technology issues slipping on signs of further weakness in the chip sector. The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.44 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,320.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 11.09 points, or 1.3 percent, to 855.70. For the week, the Nasdaq fell 1.6 percent and the S.& P. lost 0.7 percent.
All three gauges endured declines in 8 of the previous 11 sessions. Over that period, the Dow plummeted 897.49 points. And, despite the surge yesterday, the indexes posted their third consecutive weekly losses; that has not happenedin almost four months, or since the period that ended Oct. 4.
Likewise, it was a bad month for Wall Street. In January, the Dow fell 3.5 percent, the Nasdaq declined 1.1 percent and the S.& P. lost 2.7 percent.
Analysts were dubious that any buying would be long-lasting. Investors have been refusing to commit themselves to stocks before knowing whether there will be war with Iraq.
While the market typically begins to lift after military action is undertaken, and more so if it is successful, analysts warn investors not to count on that happening this time given the already dismal state of earnings and the economy.
"What happens if we go to war, win the war and the market keeps going down?" said Gary Kaltbaum, market technician for Investors' Edge Partners in Orlando, Fla. "I just think valuations are too high and earnings are still pretty bad."
Honeywell rose 94 cents, to $24.44, after meeting fourth-quarter earnings expectations and forecasting 2003 profit in line with expectations.
Disney advanced $1.15, to $17.50, on fiscal first-quarter profits that were 2 cents a share higher than Wall Street's estimate.
But the technology sector was pulled lower by the chip equipment maker Applied Materials, which said first-quarter orders would decline 35 percent, rather than the 20 percent previously projected. Applied Materials fell 98 cents, to $11.97.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners 5 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, where trading was light.
Bond prices mostly rose. The price of a 10-year note increased 1/32, to 100 0/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 3.96 percent from 3.97 percent on Thursday. The two-year note fell slightly, to 99 27/32. Its yield rose to 1.69 percent from 1.68 percent.
The 30-year bond climbed 7/32, to 108 5/32. Its yield dropped to 4.84 percent from 4.86 percent.

HEADLINE: Russia Revokes Licenses for All Importsof Meat and Poultry 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
The Agriculture Ministry revoked all import licenses for meat and poultry today without warning or explanation.
 The decision will effectively halt all shipments of meat and poultry from abroad starting next week, Russian news agencies reported. Importers will have to reapply for the permits, known as veterinary licenses -- a process that could take weeks, given Russia's tangled bureaucracy. 
 While it did not say so today, the government has clearly been moving to protect the domestic meat industry. The agriculture minister, Alexei Gordeyev, said on Wednesday that beginning in May the government would begin imposing quotas on meat imports, resulting in a reduction of about one-third in total imports. The quotas are the first Russia has imposed on foreign meat, an agricultural specialist at a Western embassy in Moscow said today.
As Russian industries mature, they, like those in more developed countries, have begun to demand that their government erect trade barriers to shield them from foreign competition. The government agreed last year to impose high tariffs on used foreign cars, the main rivals of new Russian-made cars.
Russia had been importing about two-fifths of the meat it consumes. In comments today, Mr. Gordeyev said Russia should eventually stop importing meat altogether. "Western companies want to gain ground on the Russian market, and we should take steps to curb these aspirations," he told the Prime-Tass news agency.
But economists said that Russian producers were not likely to make efficient use of the new breathing space granted them by the interruption of imports and the likely rise in prices to follow.
"We consumers will lose more than Russian meat producers will win," said Sergei Guriyev, vice rector of the New Economics School in Moscow. "The national interest is actually in open trade."
The situation today was reminiscent of a trade dispute last year between American poultry producers and the Agriculture Ministry. Citing health concerns, the ministry revoked veterinary certificates for American chicken last year. But the action was seen as retaliation for tariffs the United States had imposed on imported steel from Russia and elsewhere. 
American poultry producers eventually regained access to Russia, their biggest export market, but not without loss.
The meat licenses revoked today are also expected to be regranted eventually. But the use of import quotas and license revocations to shield domestic meat producers is likely to become an issue in Russia's already stalled negotiations to enter the World Trade Organization, Mr. Guriyev said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Mexican Energy Giant Lumbers Into Hazy Future

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
The view from the 44th-floor offices of Raul Munoz Leos is both breathtaking and dismal. All the city lies beneath him, steeped in an ocean of smog.
 It is as good an image as any for the sea of troubles he faced two years ago when he became director of Petroleos Mexicanos, the state-owned energy company. 
 Pemex, as it is known, controls Mexico's production of oil, natural gas and petrochemicals. It employs more than 130,000 people, and ships as much oil to the United States as Saudi Arabia does. Nearly all of its net income goes to the national treasury, financing roughly 40 percent of Mexico's federal budget. 
Mr. Munoz Leos is driving the company to ever greater production of crude oil, and he estimates that output will grow to 4 million barrels a day in 2006 from 3.2 million in 2002. But the long-term outlook for Pemex is as murky as the view from his office window. Independent analysts predict that after 2010, production will level off and then start falling steeply. 
For Pemex is a giant bound and lashed by politics -- including a tradition that prohibits any direct foreign investment in oil or gas that is still in the ground. Those restraints were created and to a great degree are still controlled by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as PRI -- the old guard that ran Mexico continuously from 1929 to 2000.
"You turn the battleship's wheel many times to turn the ship one degree," Mr. Munoz Leos said in an interview. "We are working on a culture change. The focus of our change is to help Pemex be able to compete with the world leaders in the oil business."
Even so, he said, "we have a significant number of rules and regulations from many government agencies that create very heavy bureaucratic problems in almost everything we attempt."
Chief among these is the ban on foreign investment, imposed when the government created Pemex by nationalizing American and British oil interests in 1938.
Mr. Munoz Leos managed to persuade Mexico's Congress to let him have an extra $4 billion this year to invest in expanding production, but no one thinks Mexico can adequately finance its growing energy needs on its own. Today, even though it is sitting on some of the world's major fossil fuel reserves, the country must import one-quarter of its gasoline and one-fifth of its natural gas from the United States because it does not have enough refineries or drilling rigs to meet its own needs.
"It is us, the Mexicans, who have stunted the growth of Mexico's oil industry," Mr. Munoz Leos said this week in a speech to workers and engineers at a Pemex refinery.
Mr. Munoz Leos, 62, came to Pemex after a long tenure as chief executive of DuPont Mexico, and by all accounts his managerial skills are great. Though Pemex still loses at least $1 billion a year to internal corruption, his administration has managed to end the use of Pemex as a piggy bank for politicians. And he has formed a new engineering group inside Pemex, reconstituting expertise that was eliminated a decade ago by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
In an effort to reduce the government's role in the economy as the advent of the North American Free Trade Agreement loomed, Mr. Salinas divided Pemex into four subsidiaries -- refining, exploration and production, natural gas and petrochemicals. The reorganization, seen as a step toward selling one or more of those businesses, instead created "a very significant weakness" in the company, Mr. Munoz Leos said.
Privatization remains the great bugaboo surrounding Pemex. 
Mr. Munoz Leos faces a major challenge in February, when he plans to begin offering a group of contracts, potentially worth billions of dollars, for work that would help Pemex tap natural gas in the giant Burgos basin in northeastern Mexico, near the Texas border. 
He says that by bringing in private capital and technology that Mexico lacks, the contracts, called multiple service contracts, will help Pemex develop the Burgos field and deliver one billion cubic feet of gas a day by 2005. Mexico has 64 trillion cubic feet of proven gas reserves, or about a 50-year supply at present rates of domestic consumption, but it has been able to expand output only slowly, while demand for gas, especially to fire power plants, is growing rapidly.
The PRI, which lost the presidency to Vicente Fox in 2000 but is still the largest party in Congress, is fiercely opposed to granting the contracts, saying they violate the Constitution. 
Mexico opened the storage, distribution and transportation of natural gas to private investment in 1995, and private companies are allowed to export and import natural gas. But the contracts that Mr. Munoz Leos says are crucial to Mexico's future are seen by the PRI as a form of political treason.
Another political battle looms. Mr. Munoz Leos's predecessor, Rogelio Montemayor, and the leader of Pemex's unionized workers, Carlos Romero Deschamps, are both prominent Institutional Revolutionary Party stalwarts, and they are trying to fend off a criminal investigation that cuts to the heart of the history of corruption at Pemex. 
The Fox government has said the two men helped funnel tens of millions of dollars from Pemex into the PRI before the elections in 2000. Mr. Montemayor, a former state governor, left Mexico for the United States, where he is fighting extradition in a Houston courtroom. Mr. Romero Deschamps, who holds a seat in the Senate, is battling attempts in Congress to strip him of the immunity the seat gives him. Unless they win their cases, it seems unlikely that the PRI will lift a finger to help Mr. Munoz Leos overhaul Pemex. 
George Baker, an independent oil analyst in Houston who publishes a newsletter, Mexico Energy Intelligence, compares Mr. Munoz Leos's challenges to the myth of Sisyphus.
"Here's a man who comes in from the private sector, from DuPont, which meets international standards as a business, and he faces political problems that would never apply in a business context," Mr. Baker said. 
"The politics of Pemex go far beyond what should be expected of a manager of a business," he said. "Munoz Leos has had to say, 'Let's work within the realm of the possible.' With the multiple service contracts, he's flying into tremendous opposition to try to find a way to ask a basic question: Does the Mexican state have to be the risk-taker and the financier? Or can private management skills and technology be brought in?
"It's a remarkable accomplishment to even take that position, regardless of how the multiple service contracts come out. The future of Mexico is much easier to understand than the present, and at least Munoz Leos understands the future."

HEADLINE: Ned Stiles, 70, Leader Of Wall St. Law Firm 

 BODY:
Ned Berry Stiles, a former managing partner of the international Wall Street law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, died Wednesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 70 and lived in Greenwich and Quogue, N.Y. 
 He had a brief illness after a stroke, the firm said. 
 Mr. Stiles was its managing partner from 1988 to 2000, when he became of counsel. During his tenure, Cleary, Gottlieb strengthened its presence in Europe and the Far East, adding offices in Frankfurt, Rome and Moscow.
He was chairman of a City Bar Association committee in the late 1990's when it set goals for greater diversity in New York's legal profession. He was active in the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association and the New York City Economic Development Corporation, and had a role in keeping the law firm downtown in enlarged quarters at 1 Liberty Plaza.
Ned Stiles was born in rural Kentucky, graduated in 1953 from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, served as a captain in the Air Force and received his law degree at the University of Cincinnati in 1958. He was a staff lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington before joining Cleary, Gottlieb in 1961.
Mr. Stiles is survived by his wife of 28 years, the former Deborah Fiedler; a daughter, Jessica, of Greenwich; three sons, Michael, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Andrew, of Seattle, and Peter, of Austin, Tex.; and a brother, Andrew, of Louisville, Ky.

HEADLINE: Jonesville Journal; 
Pitching In As Town Hits Hard Times

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: JONESVILLE, Ind., Jan. 30 

 BODY:
This town of 236 souls is stone-broke. Founded about 1865, Jonesville now has $359 in the bank. It owes the trash company $5,966.25.
 So Rick Trimpe, who has spent 21 of his 40 years as a volunteer firefighter -- 12 as chief -- and last year also became president of the Town Council, is adding a new hat to his collection: garbage man. 
 "If you call me," Mr. Trimpe assured angry residents complaining about the town's abrupt cancellation of curbside trash pickup, "I'll come and get it and take it to the Dumpster." 
Jonesville, a four-block stretch off Interstate 65 halfway between Indianapolis and Louisville, Ky., is an extreme example of the struggle facing hundreds of other American cities and towns whose revenues have shrunk in the lingering sluggish economy. 
Nobody seems to have stolen anything here. No catastrophe brought the town to the brink of bankruptcy. Instead, a combination of exuberant spending during the flush years of 2000 and 2001, and a surprise shortfall in tax payments from the state and county last year -- plus plain poor planning -- has landed Jonesville in this deep hole.
Now residents who have known one another all their lives but cannot remember ever voting in a municipal election are left wrestling with what exactly it means to be a town, testing democracy in its raw form.
Melissa Schultheis, the clerk-treasurer -- who, like the three members of the Town Council, gave up her monthly stipend long ago -- has agreed to advance the $194 monthly Dumpster fee from her pocket. Mr. Trimpe, whose day job is in weights and measures in surrounding Bartholomew County, promised to photocopy the town ordinances so everyone could have a copy. 
At an emergency town meeting on Wednesday evening, housewives offered to cook supper or wash cars for fund-raisers. One even suggested raising taxes. Men in overalls with grease on their palms promised to attend future council meetings, if board members promised to listen. 
"Work with us," pleaded Mike Mensendiek, 35, an auctioneer and real estate broker who joined the Town Council last January. "Help us get back on our feet. It's a bad situation, but if we all stick together, we're going to be fine."
Mr. Mensendiek should not count on Joe Sutton, who lives with his wife and four children in the brown trailer adjacent to where the town placed two Dumpsters when it stopped curbside pickup on Jan. 15. Mr. Sutton, who works at a nearby factory, is circulating a petition to disband the town and have it re-annexed by the county, and he is threatening to sue the Council for encroaching on his land.
"They just throw it on top of the Dumpster," he said of the new trash situation. "It ends up on my yard. This is going to draw cockroaches, rats and everything else into my home."
Of the town fathers, he said: "They want to do what they want. They don't want to listen to the people."
From the outside, Jonesville is not much of a town at all. It has two churches, a post office, a mill and a tool and dye shop, where Mr. Mensendiek, the councilman, works. A century-old tavern called The Brick draws people from miles around for its $2.50 burgers (add 25 cents for cheese) and $2 chili or chowder.
There is no town hall; Ms. Schultheis does the books at her dining room table. She does not have a fax machine. Minutes from a century of town meetings, the earliest ones all in German, are locked in an old safe at the firehouse along with electric bonds and the handwritten vote tally from the council elections in 1947.
Yet in a two-year period of seeming surpluses, the town managed to spend $187,035 -- $27,500 on a tornado siren, $41,000 to trim and remove trees, $7,500 to knock down a dead man's house, $24,639 for lawyers' fees, $5,950 for a new police car, $5,500 for a tractor, $1,900 on uniforms for the town marshal and $12,000 for a shed and dog pens, among other items. 
Some of those purchases were apparently approved by previous council members outside of public hearings. Ms. Schultheis said she learned about the patrol car when the dealership called to ask how to fill out the title. And few even remember the hot dog and chips celebration the old board called an appreciation dinner and billed at $2,500.
"They were trying to do everything for the best of the town," Mr. Mensendiek sighed. "They just got ahead of themselves."
Though no more than a handful of residents have turned up for the monthly town meetings in the back of the firehouse in years, the two dozen folding chairs filled early for Wednesday's special session. There was no written agenda, no Pledge of Allegiance or invocation, no microphones. Mr. Trimpe opened the meeting with a simple request: "No yelling and stuff like that," he said. "That goes for the board members, too."
Mr. Mensendiek read through the list of expenditures, to gasps and head-shaking -- $41,000 for trees? Why didn't anyone watch the dwindling resources?
"Really and truly, I make a budget every year," scolded Becky Davis, who has lived here since 1972. "I know what I'm going to get, and I know what I'm going to spend. Maybe I didn't have as much money as you people have, but I know where every penny of it went."
Much of the ire was directed at the former board members, Arnold Madden and Earl Chasteen, who did not show up. In an interview later, Mr. Madden, 48, insisted that "we did nothing, absolutely nothing, wrong." Mr. Chasteen did not return telephone calls.
"I don't know how much we spent," Mr. Madden admitted. "That should be what the treasurer's for, to tell us what we've got."
Matt McLean, who joined the board in April 2001, acknowledged that buying the police car was a mistake, since the county would have donated one. "We screwed that up," he said.
But the Council never anticipated a drop in state revenue from as much as $1,500 a month to less than $800 a month for most of last year, and $693.71 this January. And a change in software used by the county, Ms. Schultheis said, resulted in Jonesville receiving just part of what was due in December, with no clear indication of when the rest will come.
"That's just like the Senate and Congress," said Mrs. Davis's husband, Terrell. "They spend the money and then here comes the new bunch and say they have nothing to do with it."
"My daddy told me a long time ago," he added, "if our foresight was as good as our hindsight, we'd be worth a damn sight."
The 25 residents, more than 10 percent of the whole town, arrived on Wednesday steamed over the abrupt cancellation of curbside pickup, which cost $675 a month.
As long as they were there, residents also complained about stray dogs barking all night, and weeds growing by the railroad tracks, and cars speeding on side streets. They questioned the need for a town marshal when they do not even know his phone number (the position is required by the state) and wondered why public notices are hung in the post office rather than distributed to each of the 76 households (the last such mailing cost $238).
The proposal to un-incorporate was roundly booed. Being part of the county would mean higher water bills, and more red tape, residents said.
Slowly, the talk turned to recovery. Don Smith suggested that each family pitch in $2 so Ms. Schultheis would not have to cover the Dumpster fee herself. Mr. Smith's wife, Dee, volunteered their teenagers as couriers for the garbage of the elderly and disabled. Ron Penroso offered $2,000 for the barely used tractor, and said he would mow the grass by the tracks, too.
Mr. Trimpe said he would notify the post office that its monthly rent on the town-owned land where it parks its trailer, which has been stuck at $10 for a generation, would jump to $100. Ms. Schultheis reminded people that every dog must be registered -- $3 a pop for the town coffers.
"Do we get any actual tags?" came a question from the audience.
Ms. Schultheis looked sheepish, and acknowledged that there were "a whole bunch in a box somewhere" but she had no idea what had happened to them.
"Can we get more?" a woman asked.
"When we get some money," Mr. Trimpe said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The four-block town of Jonesville, Ind., is struggling to make ends meet. Rick Trimpe, below, the Town Council president, volunteered to be the garbage man. Many in town link the financial problems to expenditures like those listed at left. (Photographs by Tom Strattman for The New York Times) Map of Indiana highlighting Jonesville.

HEADLINE: U.S. Incomes And Spending Both Gained In December 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
Americans made and spent more money in December, reports released today showed, helping the economy cling to a fifth consecutive quarter of growth. Midwest manufacturing expanded in January, the latest sign that demand may be picking up.
 The 0.9 percent gain in personal spending in December was the biggest in five months, powered by a surge in auto sales, the Commerce Department said. The 0.4 percent gain in income, to $9.11 trillion, was the best since June. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago's factory index rose to 56, the highest figure since May, from 51.7 in December. Readings higher than 50 indicate expansion at the region's factories. 
 "Most households are maintaining spending, and that is supporting all areas of the economy," said William Sullivan, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "Any revival in manufacturing would be a prelude to more consistent gains in capital spending, and that is the missing ingredient for a more robust recovery."
Consumer confidence dropped to a three-month low in January as Americans grew more pessimistic about the months ahead. The University of Michigan's sentiment index fell to 82.4 from a revised 86.7 in December. The measure reached a nine-year low of 80.6 in October.
"We're seeing worries about the possible impact of a war with Iraq creeping into consumers' psyches," said Stephen Stanley, an economist at RBS Greenwich Capital. "Given that geopolitical worries rather than traditional economic issues may dominate attitude measures over the next few months, it would be wise to take the confidence survey results with a grain of salt and pay attention mainly to the actual spending data."
Spending rose 4.5 percent for all of 2002, matching the increase in 2001. Incomes increased 3 percent last year, the smallest gain since 1954. The figures are reported in current dollars and are not adjusted for inflation.
Disposable income, or money left over after taxes, increased 5.9 percent last year. That compared with 3.8 percent in 2001 and underscored how tax cuts put more money into people's pockets.
Economists had expected personal spending to rise 0.7 percent in December after a previously reported 0.5 percent gain in November. Sales of cars and other durable goods surged last month as no-interest loans lured buyers to dealer lots. December spending was the highest since a 1.1 percent gain in July, suggesting consumer spending strengthened entering the first quarter.

HEADLINE: AK Steel Posts Wider Quarterly Loss; 
<DTL >MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Jan. 31

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
After raising its bid for the bankrupt National Steel Corporation, the AK Steel Corporation reported a wider loss in the fourth quarter today because of pension and retiree benefit losses. 
 AK Steel said that it lost $489.7 million, or $4.54 a share, in the October-December quarter, compared with a loss of $76.4 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. 
 Excluding charges, the company would have earned $600,000, or 1 cent a share. That is 4 cents below expectations of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. 
Sales for the quarter were $1.06 billion, up from $932.7 million a year earlier. 
AK Steel said that it took a charge of $483.8 million after taxes because of losses from the pension and retiree benefit plans, resulting fromincreasing health care costs, lower interest rates and losses in equity markets. AK Steel said that it had expected the expense. 
The company also had an after-tax expense of $6.5 million, or 6 cents a share, for an investment in a taconite iron ore mining and processing plant in Minnesota. AK Steel said the plant had lost big customers including AK Steel, which had decided to buy most of its iron ore from other suppliers. 
AK Steel, which is based in Middletown, has emerged as the lead bidder in a competition with the U.S. Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, to buy National Steel. The case is pending in Bankruptcy Court in Chicago.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
UAL Has Big Quarterly Loss And Ends Year Deep in Red
UAL, parent of United Airlines, reported a much larger fourth-quarter loss that underscored the problems that forced it to seek bankruptcy protection in December.
 The company's fourth-quarter loss was $1.47 billion, nearly five times its loss of $308 million in the fourth quarter of 2001, when the airline was still struggling to recover from the Sept. 11 attacks. For the year, UAL reported a net loss of $3.2 billion, compared with $2.1 billion in 2001. Page C2. 

Russia Revokes Import Licenses
Russia's Agriculture Ministry revoked all import licenses for meat and poultry without a warning or explanation. The decision will effectively halt all shipments of meat and poultry from abroad starting next week. Importers will have to reapply for the permits, a process that could take weeks. C3.

Ryanair to Buy 100 More Aircraft
Ryanair, the discount Irish airline, has committed itself to buying 100 more 737-800 aircraft from Boeing, less than a year after ordering 150 of the planes. The deal coincided with Ryanair's first acquisition, of Buzz, the ailing discount airline, from KLM Royal Dutch Airlines for $25.7 million in cash. C3.

Pact to Open Unlicensed Spectrum
Technology companies and the Pentagon have reached an agreement to unlock a swath of spectrum, the industry's most valuable real estate, for the next generation of wireless devices, officials said. C2.

Reports Point to Economic Growth
Americans made and spent more money in December, reports showed, helping the economy cling to a fifth consecutive quarter of growth. Midwest manufacturing expanded in January, meanwhile, the latest sign that demand may be picking up for companies. C2.

Japan's jobless rate rose to a record, while consumer spending, new-home starts and production declined in December. C3.

Bargain Hunting Lifts Blue Chips
Bargain hunters helped push the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average higher. It closed up 108.68 points, or 1.4 percent, to 8,053.81. For the week, the Dow lost 1 percent. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 1.44 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,320.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 11.09 points, or 1.3 percent, to 855.70. For the week, the Nasdaq fell 1.6 percent and the S.& P. lost 0.7 percent. C4.

Dynegy Restates 4 Years of Results
Dynegy, the energy provider whose trading business drove the company close to bankruptcy, restated four years of earnings and said that it might violate loan agreements. ChevronTexaco, which holds a big stake in Dynegy, reported a fourth-quarter profit of $904 million as energy prices rose. C2.

Pemex Presses to Produce Crude Oil
Raul Munoz Leos is working to overhaul Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, the state-owned energy company that is bound and lashed by politics. Mr. Munoz Leos is driving the company to ever greater production of crude oil, and he estimates that output will grow to 4 million barrels a day in 2006 from 3.2 million in 2002. But its long-term outlook is murky. C3.

Honeywell Posts Loss in Revamping
Honeywell, which is in the process of revamping, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $1.47 billion as it settled asbestos claims. Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $5.86 billion. C2.

Honda Earnings Surge in Quarter
Honda Motor earned 115 billion yen ($958 million) in the October-December period, a 40 percent surge compared to the same period last year, thanks to strong sales in the United States and Europe. C3.

CSX Appoints Snow's Successor
CSX named a long-time executive, Michael J. Ward, as chairman and chief executive, succeeding John W. Snow, who was confirmed as Treasury secretary this week. C4.

HEADLINE: Corporate Turnaround Paved the Way for Profit 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN and JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Only a decade ago, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield would have been an unlikely honey pot for any state government to use to solve a cash crisis.
 Empire's management and board of directors were pilloried in the press and in Congress for running their business into the ground while they were enjoying lavish perquisites, from silver punch bowls to chauffeured limousines and cashmere throws. The company's imperious chief executive, Albert A. Cardone, was ousted in 1993, and the chief financial officer, Jerry Weissman, went to prison for misleading Congress about the company's health. 
 Help arrived in May 1993, when the board brought in Ira Millstein, a corporate management expert, to help lead the reforms. In late 1994, Dr. Michael A. Stocker, a family practitioner who had been at Cigna, signed on as Empire's new chief executive. 
To improve performance, he simplified everywhere he could. He streamlined the number of products Empire sold from dozens to four, so customer representatives could better field calls, and as some customers left, he shrank the work force to 6,000, from 7,500.
He shifted the product mix away from Empire's traditional indemnity products to managed care to keep pace with rivals, and speeded up claims handling so hospitals that filed electronically got their money in 14 days. When bills needed to be contested, Empire adopted a "pay and pursue" policy, meaning it pays now and argues later.
The company's turnaround has been remarkable. Underwriting profits have surged 16 straight quarters, complaints have fallen and the company's Standard & Poor's rating has risen sharply. Even in 2001, the year that the company lost employees and its headquarters in the World Trade Center, it was back processing claims the day the towers collapsed and finished the year with $131 million in overall profits.
In 1996, Empire also took the approach that it "didn't want to be special," as Dr. Stocker put it. So it relinquished its long-held status as New York's insurer of last resort and forfeited the discount it had enjoyed on hospital rates. Today, all managed care providers in New York must extend benefits to individual buyers, come one, come all.
Dr. Stocker has done well personally. Even without access to stock options, he took home $2.1 million in 2001. Two other senior executives each made more than $1 million. "We compensate well," Dr. Stocker said unapologetically.
Nonetheless, he avoids anything resembling the perks that got earlier management in trouble. There is the occasional car service and a mini-bar stocked with Diet Cokes. But he paid for the paintings in his office and his computer at home, according to a company spokeswoman. He also has no gripes about having to wait a year from the offering date before insiders qualify for stock options.
Empire has done even better in his care. Standard & Poor's has nudged the company's financial strength rating up seven notches from the B-plus it had in 1997 to the current A-minus.
"They have done an excellent job turning the company around," said Philip Tsang, the analyst who follows the company at Standard & Poor's. "We were quite impressed, when two days after the loss of the World Trade Center, I got onto their Web site, and they were back in business."
Dr. Stocker has also been the driving force behind the decision to join the for-profit ranks. Companies like Aetna and Cigna that have access to the capital markets, he argued, can more easily invest in their businesses and achieve economies of scale through mergers. "Scale is really important in this business," Dr. Stocker said.
Empire's crowning moment came in November, when the company traded in its nonprofit status for a new identity as a publicly traded company called WellChoice. Despite the weak market for initial public offerings, Empire was valued at $2 billion, twice the net worth on its books.
The company's unexpected value has turned out to be a boon for state lawmakers seeking to close a giant budget gap. But whether the public lost something in the conversion remains to be seen. Some health care executives, like Howard J. Berman, the president of Excellus Inc., a large nonprofit insurer in upstate New York, make the case that the market's few remaining nonprofit insurers should be preserved.
"Who's worrying about the community? I'm sitting here and saying my priority is my community," he said. "I'm validated by how I serve this market," he added, "not by how I serve the capital markets or a group of absentee stockholders."

HEADLINE: Pentagon and Companies In Agreement on Spectrum 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
Technology companies and the Pentagon have reached an agreement to unlock a swath of spectrum for the next generation of wireless devices, officials said today.
 The companies said this would lift the popularity of high-speed wireless Internet service, a bright spot in an otherwise moribund industry. 
 For the military, the agreement wards off an emerging threat to their radar systems by setting detailed technical mechanisms to deal with interference. 
"The Pentagon was very concerned that wireless devices were popping up in what has historically been a radar band," said Steven Price, deputy assistant secretary of defense for spectrum and command, control and communications policy.
Spectrum has become a battleground the last few years among the competing interests of consumers, the technology industry, the military and other government agencies.
Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has advocated change, citing the need to open more unlicensed spectrum.
Spectrum is the technology industry's most valuable -- though invisible -- real estate. It is measured by its frequency, usually in units of kilohertz, megahertz or gigahertz. The most desirable property is below 3 gigahertz because that is a range where portable devices can generally emit and receive signals economically. As technology advances, however, consumer devices can take advantage of higher frequencies.
The new agreement will give technology companies access to 255 megahertz of unlicensed spectrum around the 5-gigahertz band, a large amount of band close to premium spectrum that can be described as "a block or two off the beach."
There is currently about 200 megahertz of spectrum for outdoor use under the 3-gigahertz range, but it is cluttered with items like garage door openers, baby monitors and cordless phones.
The 5-gigahertz range opens a new arena for the industry's next generation of wireless technology, including 802.11a, one of the so-called Wi-Fi standards that is many times faster than the popular 802.11b used in coffee shops, offices and parks across the country for Internet connections.
"This is undeveloped property," said Scott Blake Harris, a lawyer who represented large technology concerns in the negotiations. "The 5-gigahertz band is so much less developed, so much cleaner."
While this agreement represents a policy position, it is completely balanced on technological compromise. Military and industry engineers worked around the clock for the last several weeks to determine specifications that could both adequately protect the military's radar without being overly sensitive. Under the agreement, the wireless devices and radar will share the spectrum but the devices will be designed to jump to another frequency when they sense radar operating in their range.
The time pressure was exerted by an approaching World Radio Conference, a biennial meeting under the aegis of the United Nations at which international spectrum allocations are ironed out. 
While the conference does not take place until June, the United States needs several months to lobby other nations to share its position. Despite the worldwide influence of both the United States military and technology companies, each nation has a single vote at the conference.
"It would have been a much more difficult scenario for the U.S. position without a unified delegation," Mr. Price said.

HEADLINE: Meat Safety at Risk 

 BODY:
A court ruling last week in Nebraska has dealt a devastating blow to the nation's program for policing meat safety. It calls into question the government's authority to shut down meat plants for repeatedly violating sanitary standards designed to combat bacterial contamination and outbreaks of food-borne illness.
 Judge Joseph Bataillon of the Federal District Court rebuffed an Agriculture Department effort to shut down the operations of Nebraska Beef, an Omaha slaughterhouse with numerous citations for violating standard sanitary operating procedures. The plant was chosen for special scrutiny after the discovery last year of deadly E. coli bacteria in ground beef produced by a Nebraska Beef customer. In granting a temporary restraining ordering blocking the closure, the judge elevated the economic interests of a local employer over public health while questioning the government's power to act under current law. 
 All this has a familiar ring. Just two years ago, in a different case, a federal appeals court in New Orleans declared that the Agriculture Department lacked the power to close a Dallas beef processing plant that had failed three rounds of tests for Salmonella contamination in a year. Unfortunately, Congress and the Bush administration failed to heed the message of that misguided decision by passing a law that reaffirms the government's authority to enforce health standards.
Reacting to the new ruling, the Agriculture Department has decided to reach a settlement with the meat packer that allows the plant to continue to operate. It is hard to fault the department's lawyers for wanting to avoid a drawn-out court fight likely to result in an adverse final decision by the judge. But even now, Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman refuses to acknowledge the grievous damage inflicted on her department's food safety efforts by the courts' suggestion that the government has no authority to close a plant based on public health considerations. She still hesitates to get behind legislation sponsored by Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Richard Durbin of Illinois, Representative Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut and others that would close this and other gaping holes in the nation's food safety system. That is inexcusable.
To her credit, Ms. Veneman has said she will seek $42 million more in funding next year for increased microbial testing of meat and poultry and other needed food safety initiatives. But more money and good intentions are no substitute for strong legislative action clarifying the government's power to enforce stringent safety standards.

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
'Pacem in Terris,' and debate on it, echo anew.

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
The 40th anniversary of Pope John XXIII's encyclical "Pacem in Terris" ("Peace on Earth") is not until April, but the commemoration has already begun -- understandably enough.
 Pope John Paul II made it the subject of his World Day of Peace Message on Jan. 1 and of a message to journalists on Jan. 24. 
 "Pacem in Terris" reflected another moment of great international tension. John XXIII conceived of writing it in October 1962 -- in the midst of the Cuban missile crisis -- during the late-night hours when he passed back and forth from his writing desk to his private chapel, composing a message sent to Kennedy and Khrushchev in hopes of bringing them into agreement and preventing a war that might incinerate millions in its opening salvos. 
When the encyclical emerged just before Easter in 1963, it was addressed not only to the Catholic bishops, clergy and faithful, as was customary, but also "to all men of good will." And "Pacem in Terris" was embraced by non-Catholic readers like no previous encyclical.
One reason was its refusal to be constricted by the stalemate of superpowers and the balance of nuclear terror that then defined peace. Pope John XXIII, in a phrase not then current, was thinking "outside the box."
His thinking focused on two topics. One was a lengthy catalog of human rights, including economic rights, that he said all people and nations had a duty to respect. The other was a call for some new kind of world authority adequately empowered to address what he called the "universal common good."
In the view of John Paul II, the encyclical grasped the nascent human rights movements' "singular power to change history," a power ultimately triumphant in Central and Eastern Europe. "The road to peace," as the present pope summarizes the encyclical's teaching, "lay in the defense and promotion of basic human rights." 
But are there not "situations in which nothing short of war can defend or establish" such rights? That was one objection raised in 1965 by the theologian Paul Tillich at a major conference where a score of world leaders addressed the themes of "Pacem in Terris."
A refugee from Nazism, Tillich welcomed the encyclical but countered its optimism with a more tragic perspective. Other theologians, like Reinhold Niebuhr and even John Courtney Murray, a Catholic, also questioned the pope's optimism. Couldn't the ingredients in his recipe for peace -- human rights, disarmament, equal respect for all nations, economic development, the peaceful resolution of differences by dialogue and negotiation -- come into conflict with one another? Wouldn't hard choices be unavoidable?
The drama now being played out on the world stage necessarily draws attention to John XXIII's plea for the evolution of a universal public authority commensurate to the problem of menacing armaments and the promotion of that "universal common good."
His brief, abstract argument for such an authority was made tangible in the hope he placed in the United Nations and its Universal Declaration of Human Rights as first steps in that evolution.
Clearly the United Nations' capacity -- actual and potential -- to serve as that public authority is one of the things at the center of the Iraq drama. Yet when one reads John XXIII's description of that "public authority, having worldwide power and endowed with the proper means for the efficacious pursuit of its objective," one recognizes that today there is another claimant to the role: the United States.
This claim may be unacknowledged. It emerges less from words than from the logic of the war on terror and the promulgation of military doctrines many see as little short of global police powers. But the half-explicit, half-implicit claim of the United States to global authority has also been at the center of the recent drama. What has galvanized opinion in other parts of the world, however painful or unfair it may seem to Americans, is not just the potential threat of Iraq but also the potential threat of the United States.
John XXIII saw such a problem 40 years ago when he warned that the world authority he envisaged "must be set up by common accord, and not imposed by force" or assumed on the basis of military or economic superiority. Effective global power had to be exercised with "sincere and real impartiality" rather than as "an instrument of one-sided interests." Indeed, even if a supranational authority did act impartially, it would still, he wrote, have "to avoid all suspicion of partiality."
Underlying "Pacem in Terris" was another conviction pertinent to the current drama: Peacemaking was a gestalt -- a total configuration of endeavors that encompassed disarmament, human rights, economic development, sensitivity to the dignity of weaker nations and, John XXIII would doubtless add today, environmental protection and the campaigns against terrorism and weapons of mass destruction. 
It may have been a weakness that the pope did not rank in importance these multiple aspects of peacemaking, or address the problem of resolving conflicts among them. But in insisting that they all went together, he was presaging much of the current conflict.
Religious leaders, no less than political ones, have raised this or that objection to a war in Iraq. But in both cases, as well as in the opposition revealed in public opinion polls around the world, what seems to be driving the resistance is a gestalt much like the one "Pacem in Terris" emphasized 40 years ago: in this instance, the total pattern of American policy.

HEADLINE: Accounts Chock-Full, Or a Plan Half Empty? 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
The White House's proposal to simplify and expand tax-preferred savings accounts has just one problem: it may not increase saving.
 Instead, economists say, its main impact may be to tilt the tax system away from its current bias in favor of immediate consumption. At the same time, if it becomes law, it is expected to shift some tax revenue from the distant future to the present. 
 Since Congress approved the first I.R.A.'s in 1974, economists have tried to measure whether people use such programs to save more or just transfer money from existing saving accounts that lack a tax advantage. The evidence has been mixed. Yet skepticism over the administration's latest proposal was widespread, even uniting academics who have long disagreed about the effects of tax-preferred plans on household saving. 
"When one thinks, 'Are we going to get a lot more saving out of this?' I just don't know," said David A. Wise, a professor at Harvard whose research indicates that I.R.A.'s and 401(k)s promote extra saving.
His sometime rival, John Karl Scholz, a professor of economics at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, was even more dismissive. "My best guess is that this would reduce private saving in aggregate," Professor Scholz said, "rather than increase private saving." 
Despite their differences, both economists agree that few people are constrained by current limits on contributions to I.R.A.'s and 401(k) plans. So the higher limits in the administration's proposal might not have much effect on saving.
The new program would allow individuals to put away up to $15,000 of their after-tax income each year into two separate accounts, with no taxes on any earnings from their saving. Each year, the maximum contribution would rise with inflation. All the money in the new accounts, known as Lifetime Savings Accounts, could be taken out at any time tax free, while the money set aside in the expanded Retirement Savings Accounts would remain saved until age 58, except in cases of death or disability.
"That's going to take care of almost everybody's saving," said Gary V. Engelhardt, an associate professor of economics at Syracuse University. Except for the wealthiest families, the $30,000 that a married couple could put aside every year would be more than enough to cover what they can afford to save. "Effectively all your saving is going to be sheltered," Professor Engelhardt said.
Even with higherlimits on tax-preferred saving, the government might have a hard time encouraging more people to begin putting money aside. "You're not going to get the participation rates you do in employer-based plans," said William G. Gale, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, a liberal policy group.
Professor Wise agreed. For most people, he said, "this is small potatoes relative to 401(k) plans." Replacing saving plans aimed at medical care and higher education with one lifetime account, Mr. Engelhardt warned, could also curb savers' enthusiasm.
Nevertheless, Mr. Gale noted, economists have little data to use in forecasting the behavior of high-income people, who are currently barred from contributing to Roth I.R.A.'s, which work in the same way as the new accounts.
Contributions to traditional I.R.A.'s, which offer an upfront tax deduction in exchange for being taxed at ordinary income rates when money is withdrawn, would stop under the White House's plan. Their replacement could even lead to lower saving rates, Professor Wise said.
"The upfront deduction is the thing that gets people's attention," he argued. "I would question whether you might not have a decline in contributions."
He predicted that some middle-income people who contribute to traditional I.R.A.'s would not switch to the new accounts, because they would no longer receive the immediate tax break.
"It's clear that it is going to be skewed toward upper-income individuals," Mr. Engelhardt said.
Indeed, that is almost unavoidable. Most proposals to increase saving inherently favor the well-to-do because they are the only ones who can afford to set aside income beyond their immediate needs. "They do proportionally more saving than lower-income individuals," Mr. Engelhardt said. Moreover, the wealthy have a greater incentive to avoid taxation. "They face higher marginal tax rates," he said, "and have bigger tax benefits from these types of vehicles."
Combined with President Bush's plan to protect dividend income from personal taxes, this latest proposal also moves toward a goal long favored by a number of economists, including R. Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers: the transformation of the income tax into a tax on consumption.
With a pure consumption tax, there is no disadvantage to spending money in the future instead of the present; the tax -- effectively paid at the time of a purchase -- is always the same. In a sense, eliminating taxes on saving achieves the same goal, even with an income tax in place. That transformation would be on the horizon if the new saving rules became law. "I can't imagine that there's ever going to be a taxable dividend or capital gain or anything else if we do this and the president's other proposal," Mr. Gale said.
Aside from its effects on the character of the tax system and income inequality, making the entire savings of almost all Americans eligible for a tax shelter could also put a dent in the government's annual revenue.
"Clearly the government's going to forgo a lot of tax revenue," Professor Scholz said. "Households with two incomes -- like me and my lawyer wife -- we'll be real capable of taking full advantage of these things."
After 20 years, an individual who saved at the program's maximum levels could have $300,000 in principal yielding tax-free income. But while the government would be giving up a big revenue stream in the future, the new accounts are likely to generate extra taxes in the near term to the extent people with traditional I.R.A.'s take up the Treasury's offer to convert them.
"If they get people to convert existing funds, and pay a tax on the conversion, they'll show a big gain in revenue in the short term, and a big loss in the long term," Mr. Gale said. "It's a gimmick, in that it's shifting revenue from the future to now."

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Approves Biotechnology Drug for Psoriasis 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
The Food and Drug Administration has approved Amevive, the first drug from the biotechnology industry to treat psoriasis, opening what doctors say will be a new era in treating the disease, a sometimes debilitating skin ailment.
 The approval of the drug, announced yesterday by its manufacturer, Biogen, could also fuel a new growth spurt for the 25-year-old company. Sales of its only product until now, the multiple sclerosis treatment Avonex, have been flattening, and it faces new competition. 
 Doctors said Amevive, as well as several other biotechnology drugs that are expected to be approved in the next two years, could help patients with severe psoriasis without the side effects of existing drugs, which can cause liver or kidney damage. 
"There's hope for safe and effective long-term control of this disease," said Dr. Alice Gottlieb, a professor at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Jersey, who has been active in testing Amevive and other psoriasis drugs. Gail M. Zimmerman, president of the National Psoriasis Foundation, a patient advocacy group that receives donations from Biogen and other companies, called the new drugs "the most significant advance in psoriasis care in 20 years." 
Psoriasis is characterized by reddened skin covered by a silvery scale. About 1.5 million American adults have moderate to severe psoriasis. Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it expected to sell at least $85 million worth of Amevive this year and $500 million in 2005. 
Amevive, known generically as alefacept, is given as an injection in a doctor's office once a week for 12 weeks. Biogen will sell the drug to wholesalers for about $7,000 to $10,000 for the 12-week course. Patients and insurers are likely to pay about $8,400 to $11,900, said Ronald Renaud, an analyst at Bear, Stearns. 
The price, plus the fact that Amevive is injected, could discourage some patients from switching from methotrexate, an existing drug that costs only $1,000 to $2,000 a year and can be taken orally, though it can cause liver damage.
"We are really going to face a hard question on the economic side," said Dr. Steve Feldman, professor of dermatology at Wake Forest University School of Medicine. 
Psoriasis is an autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's defense system against microbial invaders mistakenly attacks the skin. Amevive is a genetically engineered protein that blocks certain immune system cells, known as T cells. But because lower T-cell levels can leave people prone to infection, Amevive users will have to have their blood T-cell counts checked weekly and will have to wait at least 12 weeks after finishing one course of treatment before starting another. 
In clinical trials, Amevive produced a 75 percent improvement in psoriasis in 15 percent to 40 percent of patients, depending on how it was administered and for how long. 
Some analysts think Biogen will not achieve its sales goals because Amevive will lose out to other drugs, particularly Enbrel from Amgen. That drug is already approved for rheumatoid arthritis and for psoriatic arthritis, a joint condition, and is now in late-stage trials for psoriasis. Enbrel seems to work in a higher percentage of patients than Amevive, though it can be misleading to compare results from different trials. Also, since Enbrel has been used for five years for arthritis, doctors might be more comfortable with its safety. 
"I think down the road Enbrel ends up becoming the incumbent psoriasis therapy and everything else is second to that," said Mr. Renaud of Bear, Stearns, who once worked for Amgen. He said Biogen should have priced Amevive lower to compete better with Enbrel, which costs about $12,000 to $15,000 a year.
Genentech and Xoma applied to the F.D.A. in December for approval of their psoriasis drug, Raptiva, which could be the next one to reach the market after Amevive. Remicade from Johnson & Johnson, already approved for rheumatoid arthritis, has also shown effectiveness against psoriasis in clinical trials. 
But Biogen, being first to market, has the chance to establish itself. Amevive's big selling point is that when it does work, patients' skin can remain clear for months. "Duration has always been the hallmark of our discussions" with doctors, said Doug Abel, vice president in charge of Biogen's dermatology business.
Shares of Biogen rose 26 cents yesterday, to $38.25.
While psoriasis is sometimes viewed as merely a cosmetic disease, it can be painful and severely disrupt lives. "Your whole body is on fire," said Diane Lewis, a 34-year-old artist in San Francisco. "You wake up bloody and stuck to bedsheets." 
Ms. Lewis received Amevive along with ultraviolet light, another treatment, in a clinical trial. Three months after the treatment ended, her skin is still clear and she finds it almost unnerving that the disease no longer controls her life. 
"I can dress however I want," she said. "I was able to book a trip to Europe without any thought" of skin condition.

HEADLINE: Details Given On New Plans To Aid Saving 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
The Bush administration today unveiled its plan to create two new types of savings accounts that would allow a couple to save as much as $30,000 a year in funds that could be withdrawn, with any investment gains, free of taxes.
 Everyone would be able to contribute to the plans, with no limitations based on age or income. 
 For people with plenty of money, the accounts would offer powerful new ways to build wealth. A person could contribute up to $7,500 a year to a Lifetime Savings Account, which would generate investment income tax free, then use the money for any purpose, not just buying a home or paying for education. Withdrawals could be made at any age and would also be tax free. 
That same person could also contribute up to $7,500 a year to a Retirement Savings Account, which would replace today's individual retirement accounts and Roth accounts, among others. After the saver reached age 58, withdrawals would be free from taxes and penalties. The saver's spouse could set aside those amounts each year, a total of $15,000, in such accounts.
The accounts "make saving simple for everyone and for every purpose," stated Pamela F. Olson, the assistant Treasury secretary for tax policy, in a department statement. "No longer will individuals have to worry about the confusing alphabet soup of six different savings accounts."
Though the proposals are described as simplifying the mix of saving plans, choosing the best way to harness the new plans would still be a complicated matter. .
"This is not going to be simplified, believe me," said Steven G. Lockwood, president of Lockwood Pension Services and the author of "Individual Retirement Account Answer Book."
"But it's all good news," he said. "People will walk away from this with more money." 
Some of the complexity would arise as savers make decisions about how to invest their money in the new accounts -- decisions with new twists if the administration's plan to make dividends tax exempt goes forward.
In addition, people would have to compare the merits of saving through one of the new individual accounts with those of any retirement account they are offered at work. The Bush administration is also proposing to reshape work-based retirement plans like the 401(k) account, calling the successor plans Employer Retirement Savings Accounts. The advantages and disadvantages would vary depending on each person's age, goals, tax bracket and other factors. 
Like many other financial analysts, Mr. Lockwood noted that the benefits of the new accounts would flow only to those who have money to save. The accounts would have little effect on people who live from paycheck to paycheck.
Indeed, some benefits consultants warned that the new accounts and proposed rule changes on accounts sponsored by employers could combine to eliminate the incentives for some companies to offer retirement savings plans to their workers.
"If you're a small-business employee, what this could potentially mean is your employer will no longer offer a program for you," said Brian H. Graff, executive director of the American Society of Pension Actuaries. 
The new accounts also appear to threaten certain existing financial services, because they would damp public enthusiasm for some investment instruments, like annuities and education savings accounts.
The proposals could provide a one-time increase in federal tax revenues. The new plans have incentives to encourage savers to withdraw money from their old individual savings accounts, pay the applicable taxes and put the funds into the new accounts. People who convert from I.R.A.'s in the first year, for example, will be allowed to stretch the tax payments over four years.
When those people retire, though, they will be able to receive income free from taxes, meaning less federal revenue in later years.
For employers, the Bush administration said it hoped to eliminate many of the rules now imposed on the structure of retirement accounts. The Treasury said it also wanted to reduce the number of work-based plans, consolidating such vehicles as the 401(k) plan, the Simple 401(k) plan, and the governmental 457 plan into a single format, the Employer Retirement Savings Account.
Employees eligible for the Employer Retirement Savings Account at work could contribute the amounts that they may now put into their 401(k) plans: $12,000 a year if they are younger than 50, and $14,000 a year if they are 50 or older. These maximum amounts would increase in the coming years, just as they do on 401(k) amounts.
The new consolidated account would be similar to the 401(k) account in many other ways. Companies would deduct workers' contributions from their paychecks before taxes, employers could offer to match worker contributions, and savers would pay taxes on money they withdrew after retirement.
Administration officials said that they believed that the variety of work-based accounts confuses employees, and the rules discourage companies from offering such plans.
"This is especially true of small employers who together employ 4 out of every 10 American workers," Ms. Olson said. "It's one important reason why only 50 percent of working Americans have any pension plan at all."
She said she believed that once the rules were stripped away, more companies would offer retirement savings programs to their workers, ultimately improving the financial well-being of elderly Americans. 
Employee-benefits specialists said, however, that they feared that the administration's package might have the opposite effect.
This is because some rules are intended to ensure that senior officials of companies -- particularly small companies -- do not set up retirement plans for their workers and direct most of the benefits to themselves, creating abusive tax shelters.
One such provision is the "top heavy" rule. It requires that when a small company creates a retirement plan that grants most of its benefits to top officials, the plan must also guarantee that the lowest-paid workers get contributions of at least 3 percent of their pay.
Another provision requires that companies that set up Simple 401(k) plans for their workers must offer to match 3 percent or more of employee contributions.
These rules have been criticized by companies because they make small businesses do considerable paperwork relative to the size of the benefits they bestow on low-income workers. Those workers might prefer cash to the small retirement benefit they receive, in any case.
The administration is proposing to repeal both rules, along with similar regulations that are meant to distribute the benefits of retirement plans more equally among workers and managers.
Mr. Graff said he was not convinced that large numbers of employers would set up Employer Retirement Savings Accounts for their companies if they no longer had to adhere to complex rules. He said that since small-business owners and their spouses would be able to put away $30,000 each year in the other new tax-advantaged accounts, they would have little need to create tax-advantaged savings plans at work.
"It's the rank and file who are going to lose out of the opportunity to get a matching contribution," he said, adding that millions of employees now participate in the Simple plans, which would be eliminated. Studies show that low-wage workers are unlikely to save anything at all for their retirement unless an employer deducts the money from their paychecks.
For savers whose employers now offer 401(k) accounts with matching money, Mr. Lockwood said the best strategy would be, first of all, to keep paying into the same accounts if the proposals are enacted. These accounts would automatically become Employer Retirement Savings Accounts, and while the new individual accounts would offer attractive features, he said, even they do not measure up to the value of matching payments from an employer. 
"It's Pension 101," he said. "You never turn your back on a match."
After that, any savers with still more money to set aside could turn to the individual accounts. Financial planners said that converting money from the older savings accounts to the new ones would probably pay off, even though it would mean paying taxes in the process. 
"That would be an individual decision depending on your age, how soon you want access to the money, what you want to invest in, your future tax bracket," Mr. Lockwood said. "You'd have to look at a lot of different factors."
Not least of which is how confident each saver is that the rules will not change again before he or she is ready to withdraw the money or retire.

HEADLINE: Indian Leader Cites Poverty and Pleads for Aid 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
The president of the National Congress of American Indians, which represents more than 250 tribes, called on Congress and President Bush today to "make good on its word" to provide financial aid for education, housing and health care while respecting the tribes' right to self-governance.
 The president of the group, Tex G. Hall, traveled here from his ranch in North Dakota to deliver what he called the first State of the Indian Nations address in the 60 years of the group. Rather than the customary dark suit worn by lawmakers and other power, Mr. Hall wore an open-collar shirt, jeans and a cowboy hat. 
 "Seven generations ago, the United States was engaged in forced removal of tribes to the lands west of the Mississippi," Mr. Hall said. "Today we carry the wounds of that legacy. But we are alive and well and strong." 
Mr. Hall covered many issues in his 60-minute speech, including the need to improve schools, roads, telephones, cable television and high-speed data lines on reservations. He also spoke of the need to improve efficiency in dealing with the government, of the urgent desire for development and the double-edged effects of gambling on reservations.
Casinos at some reservations have provided jobs and economic activity where few other options were available, Mr. Hall said. But of the more than 560 federally recognized tribes, slightly more than 200 have gambling, and fewer than 20 have generated the wealth that can transform a tribe's economy. He asked Washington to help create 100,000 jobs for Indians by 2010.
Mr. Hall focused on the survival of self-governing tribes, Indians' ability to leave poverty and unemployment and the well being and general quality of Indian life.
"One of the most important things to understand about American Indian tribes," he said, "is the simple fact that tribes are governments. Not nonprofit organizations, not interest groups, not an ethnic minority."
Mr. Hall urged lawmakers to address the "jurisdictional confusion" and said, "We need Congress to help clarify the authority of tribes to set and enforce laws on the lands they govern."
For generations, Indians have contended that Washington has lost or stolen millions of dollars earned on tribal lands. For years, the government has ignored or disputed the contentions without accounting for the money from oil, mineral, timber and grazing leases, whose proceeds go to a trust fund for the Indians. The conflict, which dates from 1887, entered a new stage in 1996, when the Indians sued the Interior Department, a case that has not been resolved.
Mr. Hall proposed a two-day meeting in the summer between tribal leaders and the administration and Congress to revise the trust fund accounts.
"Fixing this system will not be easy," he said, "and it will, unfortunately, be expensive. But it simply must be done." 
Indians are the fastest-growing segment of the population by percentage, Mr. Hall said, but they are haunted by troubling statistics. They have a life expectancy significantly shorter than other groups. More than one-fourth live in poverty, and unemployment on reservations averages nearly 14 percent, more than double the national rate.
The domestic violence rate is more than twice the national rate, with 75 percent of the incidents involving non-Indian offenders.
