HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
'Don't Call Us' Is Becoming the Headhunters' Mantra

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
ABOUT two years ago, when he was an associate at a big public relations firm in Manhattan, Timothy Seitz said that he got two or three calls a week from executive recruiters trying to woo him away. Nowadays, he says, most of those same recruiters won't even return his calls.
 "Unless you're at the top of your field, headhunters want nothing to do with you," said Mr. Seitz, 32, of Brooklyn, who had been looking for a position for more than a year. 
 With fewer spots to fill in a tight job market, recruiters across nearly all industries, even growth markets like pharmaceuticals and health care, report that they are sharply narrowing their candidate pools. 
In the late 1990's, when the economy was stronger, recruiters "couldn't find people for jobs fast enough," said Arnold Huberman, president of Arnold Huberman Associates, a recruiting firm based in New York that specializes in the public relations field. "Now it appears that almost nobody is good enough for our clients."
Mr. Huberman says he is often only able to place candidates with impeccable credentials. Job seekers who have been laid off, or have worked at a dot-com "have black marks on their foreheads and are virtually ignored by recruiters right now," he said.
The same holds true in the legal profession, where the more lucrative jobs in many big cities are typically filled by recruiters. Dominic Morandi, a recruiter with Schneider Legal Search in Manhattan, said his firm had sharply narrowed its cold-calling lists to include only those lawyers who work at the city's top firms.
A few years ago, when there was a seemingly endless stream of corporate work for lawyers because of a high level of merger activity, Mr. Morandi said, some clients were "willing to drop their standards" by considering, for example, lawyers who went to law schools not in the Ivy League. Today, he said, candidates who did not graduate from top schools in the top 10 percent of their classes are going to have a harder time attracting recruiters' attention.
Another legal recruiter based in San Francisco, who insisted that he not be identified, agreed. "Three years ago, we had an A list, a B list and a C list" of potential candidates, he said. "We called everybody on all of those lists. Now, if you're not on the A list, we can't waste our time with you."
So who's on the A list? "If you were summa cum laude at Harvard Law and work for a top firm, you'll probably make the cut," he said.
What then can a job seeker without such credentials do? There are ways to gain a recruiter's attention even in a tight market. The trick, many of them say, is to be persistent, to try to stand out and to remain flexible. (If all else fails, you may have to do it yourself, they acknowledge.)
Gary Miller, president of the Oak Brook, Ill., branch of Management Recruiters International, which places candidates in the consumer goods and health care fields, among other industries, recommends taking a personalized approach. He suggests approaching three or four recruiting firms that specialize in the field you work in. "It's better to try to get a few recruiters to know you well than solicit yourself to dozens," said Mr. Miller, who says he receives hundreds of computer-generated resumes and cover letters each week.
Candidates should also treat an interview with a recruiter with as much importance as a real job interview, right down to their dress and the questions they ask, said Audrey Smith, a senior vice president at Development Dimensions International in Bridgeville, Pa., which helps Fortune 500 companies develop criteria for executives. 
"You've got to show the recruiter that you're serious about a position, and not just going on a fishing expedition," she said. 
Mr. Miller of Management Recruiters International says candidates should not be rigid in their salary requirements. "I'm more interested in candidates who are less worried about compensation and more interested in a great opportunity," he said.
And while credentials often carry the day in the legal field, Mr. Morandi of Schneider Legal Search suggests that job seekers can attract a recruiter's attention if they have established themselves as an expert in their field. "There are people who slip in the door because their skills are known," he said. "Maybe they're well known as regular speakers in continuing-education courses, or they've worked on a high-profile bankruptcy deal." 
Other experts recommend that job seekers try to leave a memorable impression. When Deborah Brown-Volkman, 37, was looking for a marketing position in the last economic downturn in the early 1990's, she said she sentseveral recruiters a copy of her resume, along with a red pen and a return envelope, asking them to critique it. Ms. Brown-Volkman, now a career coach in Long Beach, N.Y., said she received dozens of replies, and ultimately a new position.
She now counsels job seekers to send portfolios to recruiters highlighting the work they have done. She also recommends that they do not spend much time on headhunters who do not return their phone calls. "The truth is that recruiters won't call you back unless they have a job for you," she said. "You can't take it personally -- you've just got to move on." 
Mr. Seitz, the public relations executive, did just that, only without the help of a recruiter. In early January, he saw a help-wanted ad for a senior account executive position at a boutique public relations firm with an office in Manhattan. He decided to send its hiring manager a news release highlighting his achievements, including a description of how he had created an internal course for employees at his previous firm on how to build better media lists. He also included testimonials from past clients. 
Within a few days, Mr. Seitz said, he received a call from the company's president applauding his creativity. He started his job on Jan. 22.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Online Calculator Computes Incentives; 
Figuring Rents For Downtown

 BODY:
Companies trying to decide whether to remain in or relocate to lower Manhattan have two new online tools -- a space finder and a calculator that computes the savings from the government incentives they would receive to move or stay downtown. 
 "We're hoping the tools will increase the number of companies leasing space downtown," said Shirley Jaffe, vice president of economic development at the Downtown Alliance, which created the incentive calculator and space finder. They are available on the alliance's Web site, www.DowntownNY.com. 
 The calculator allows firms to list such things as the number of workers, the desired rent range and their corporate tax rate. They must specify if on 9/11 they were in or out of the zone designated for certain types of grant eligibility, bounded by Chambers and Rector Streets, Broadway and the Hudson River. 
Ms. Jaffe gave as an example a 50-employee company seeking 12,500 square feet for five years at an annual rent of $27 a square foot. If that company moved from outside to inside the downtown restricted area it would get government incentives totaling $579,451 over the term of the lease, an annual savings of $11.11 a square foot. If it is already inside the restricted area and remains, the incentive totals $645,418, or $12.31 a square foot.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Tax Rules On the Sale Of a Home

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
LATE last year, the Internal Revenue Service issued regulations aimed at clarifying a 1997 law that allows taxpayers to exclude up to $500,000 in gain from the sale of a principal residence.
 One set of regulations, made final on Dec. 24, 2002, addresses a number of issues that were somewhat unclear in the original law. Among these topics are how to determine if a home is a principal residence; when and how to allocate the gain between residential and business use of the property; how to apply the exclusion to joint owners who are not married; and how to fulfill the requirement that the owner use the home as a principal residence for two of the five years before the sale. 
 Another set of regulations, published on Dec. 24 but designated as temporary, identifies when a home that has been used as a principal residence for less than two years may qualify for a reduced exclusion of gain.
"People sometimes need help reading and applying a statute," said Joel E. Miller, a Queens tax lawyer. "And these regulations serve that purpose." 
Mr. Miller said that while neither set of regulations substantively changes the original 1997 law, they do reflect an I.R.S. interpretation of that law that seems favorable to taxpayers.
Gary H. Schatsky, a Manhattan lawyer and financial consultant, said that before 1997, homeowners could defer paying tax on the gain resulting from the sale of their principal residence if, within two years of the sale, they purchased a new home for an equal or greater amount than the sale price of the old one. In addition, Mr. Schatsky said, the tax laws at the time allowed a once-in-a-lifetime exclusion of up to $125,000 in gains for homeowners who were 55 and older when they sold their home.
The 1997 law was more generous to homeowners. It allows an individual taxpayer who owns and lives in a home for two out of the last five years to completely avoid paying taxes on up to $250,000 in gains and, in fact, to repeat the process every two years. Married taxpayers filing jointly, Mr. Schatsky said, can exclude up to $500,000 in gain.
"It was an extraordinary boon for people who have enjoyed significant increases in their property values," he said. "But the law left some questions unanswered."
For example, the 1997 law provided that a homeowner who did not meet the two-year requirement might be eligible for a partial exclusion if the homeowner had to sell the house because of health reasons, a change in the place of employment or, to the extent provided by I.R.S. regulations, "unforeseen circumstances." In other words, he said, the law left it up to the I.R.S to determine what would be considered an unforeseen circumstance.
Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y., said that with the temporary regulations, the I.R.S. had identified various "safe harbors" that will automatically qualify a sale for a reduced exclusion.
For example, he said, taxpayers who sell their homes because their place of work has changed will automatically qualify for a reduced exclusion if a "qualified person's" new place of work is at least 50 miles farther from the old home than the old workplace was. A qualified person, Mr. Block said, includes the taxpayer, the taxpayer's spouse, a co-owner of the home or a member of the taxpayer's household. 
The reduced exclusion, he said, is based upon the length of time the taxpayer owned and lived in the home before selling it. For example, a taxpayer who would be entitled to a $250,000 tax exclusion if he sold the home after two years will be entitled to a $125,000 exclusion if he sells it after one year and meets the requirements for the reduced exclusion.
In addition, Mr. Block said, the I.R.S. has said that a sale made for health reasons is eligible for a reduced exclusion if a qualified person -- which includes close relatives -- has a disease, illness or injury. "If a physician recommends the change in residence, that will be enough to satisfy the I.R.S.," he said.
Finally, Mr. Block said, the I.R.S. has articulated what it considers to be "unforeseen circumstances" for purposes of qualifying for the partial exclusion. Such events include death, divorce or legal separation; becoming eligible for unemployment compensation; a change in employment that leaves the taxpayer unable to pay the mortgage or reasonable basic living expenses; and multiple births resulting from the same pregnancy. Such events, he said, must involve the taxpayer, a spouse, a co-owner or a member of the taxpayer's household. 
Other unforeseen circumstances include damage to the residence resulting from a disaster caused either by nature or by humans, an act of war or terrorism or the condemnation, seizure or other involuntary loss of the property.
"And the regulations also give the director of the I.R.S. the discretion to identify other circumstances as unforeseen," Mr. Block said.
Mr. Miller, the Queens tax lawyer, said a taxpayer who has already filed a return reporting a gain from the sale of a principal residence but now realizes he or she qualifies for an exclusion can obtain the benefits of the exclusion by filing an amended return. In most cases, he said, returns can be amended for up to three years after the original due date. 
In the recently published final regulations, Mr. Miller added, the I.R.S. addressed several issues that needed clarification.
For example, he said, for taxpayers with more than one home, relevant factors for determining which is the principal residence include the amount of time a home is used; the taxpayer's place of employment; the residence of other family members; the address used for tax returns, driver's license, car registration, voter registration and bills and correspondence; and the location of the taxpayer's banks, religious organizations and recreational clubs.
The final regulations also allow the home sale exclusion when the gain includes the sale of vacant land that has been used as part of the residence (provided the land sale occurs within two years of the sale of the residence) and indicate that a co-owner who files an individual return is entitled to an exclusion of up to $250,000, provided the other requirements of the law are met.
The regulations also explain how the two-year personal use and ownership time periods are calculated. For example, Mr. Miller said, the two-year ownership and use periods need not be concurrent. That means that someone who lives in a home for two years before buying it and who then moves out of the home after buying it but does not sell for it another two years will have met the requirements of the law.
And the two-year period itself, he said, can consist of 24 consecutive months, 730 individual days or any other variation equaling two years, provided that the two years of residence occurs within the five years before the sale. Short absences like vacations, he said, would count as periods of use while longer absences -- such as a one-year sabbatical -- would not.
Finally, Mr. Miller said, the I.R.S. has relaxed the rules on business use of the home. He explained that whenever a taxpayer uses a portion of a home exclusively for business purposes and takes a tax deduction for that use, the cost basis of that portion of the house is reduced by the amount of the depreciation deduction allowed or allowable.
Under the former rules for excluding gain on the sale of a house, whenever a home office was involved, the taxpayer would basically report two separate sales: one for the residential portion of the house and the other for the business portion. And while the gain on the residential portion might qualify for the exclusion, the gain on the business portion would not.
Under the final regulations, however, if the business use of the home occurred within the same dwelling unit as the residential use, the taxpayer does not need to allocate the gain between the business and residential use. 
And while in most cases a taxpayer who realizes a gain will be subject to tax on any depreciation deductions taken on the business portion of the home after May 6, 1997, he or she will be entitled to exclude any amount above that up to the maximum allowable exclusion.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Upscale Rentals to Open in Downtrodden Camden

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
FOUR years of planning and effort are coming together now in Camden, the state's poorest city, where work is under way on the historic RCA Victor building to transform it into 341 upscale loft apartments.
 The wind whipping off the Delaware River, where the huge brick structure occupies a square block at Market and Delaware Streets, may seem icy enough to freeze motion. Yet throughout the dead of winter, work has proceeded at "120 miles an hour," said the project's developer, Carl Dranoff. 
 Financing through Fleet Bank fell into place last October, and Dranoff Properties took title to the property and immediately began "coring" the building -- removing concrete and steel at the center of the structure to create a 60-by-300-foot space for an atrium courtyard. Right now, 1,100 windows on the exterior and courtyard walls of the building -- some 14 feet tall, some wood and some steel -- are being removed and replaced with historically correct new ones, Mr. Dranoff said. 
The building, vacant for 11 years, was put on the National Register of Historic Places last summer, he said, and must be restored accordingly. It is six stories tall, with a tower rising four more stories.
A grand opening of the refurbished building and model apartments is planned for Memorial Day. Also on display that day will be other new construction in Camden's waterfront area, including research-and-development buildings being built for Drexel and Rutgers University researchers, which will feature space for start-up "incubator" businesses. Another building nearing completion will house L-3 Communications, a manufacturer of military and commercial communications equipment. 
Mr. Dranoff said he expected the transformed Camden waterfront to come off as an "overnight sensation." He added, "Of course, that's supreme irony, given all that has gone into the revival of Camden."
Mr. Dranoff's company, Dranoff Properties, is based just across the Delaware, in Philadelphia -- where he renovated a hulking old industrial building into upscale apartments five years ago, using many of the techniques now being employed at the Victor, as the building has been renamed.
But Mr. Dranoff said he had never participated in anything comparable to the far-reaching, concerted effort to revive the crumbled city of Camden.
Members of the South Jersey delegation to the State Legislature developed the idea over the last five years of making Camden a real "university city." Rutgers has both a university campus and a law school near the central business district. There are also two teaching hospitals in Camden: Cooper and Our Lady of Lourdes.
Last summer, Gov. James E. McGreevey announced the state would invest $175 million over the next three years to demolish abandoned houses, rehabilitate deteriorated housing, build business space, improve public safety and resurrect the economy in Camden. The state also took over administration of city government, which has been chronically problem-ridden, with three mayors indicted in the last 10 years.
The state financing is being drawn from an array of state agencies, including the Casino Reinvestment Authority, Community Affairs Department, Environmental Protection Department, Transit Authority, Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency and the State Police.
The funding for the Victor is also a patchwork, with New Jersey's largest bank, Fleet, having structured the overall financing for the $58 million project. 
Philip G. Grossman, a senior vice president with Fleet, which has more than 500 branches in the state, said. "We are providing $30 million in partnership with two smaller banks, Wilmington Trust Company and United Bank of Philadelphia," he said, "and Fleet is administering nearly $9 million from the Casino Redevelopment Authority."
Creda, as it is known, reinvests money that the state takes in from casino taxes to further projects deemed to be "smart growth" efforts. About $5 million from Creda was used for environmental cleanup at the building, which was polluted by chemicals used in manufacturing cabinetry for Victrolas, and later radios and televisions.
In addition, Fleet assembled $11 million in equity financing from Related Capital of New York and Dranoff. Another $8 million in cut-rate financing came from the Delaware River Port Authority, Mr. Grossman added.
Fleet is committed to supporting low- and moderate-income housing, he said, and "Camden needed concentrated effort in order to bring people over from Philadelphia, for jobs and affordable housing."
The Victor will be the first housing ever on the waterfront, and it will be the costliest in Camden, but still a bargain for Philadephians, Mr. Grossman said. Mr. Dranoff said apartment rents would be $775 to $1,050 for studios, $975 to $1,400 for one-bedroom units, $1,650 to $2,100 for two bedrooms, $2,500 to $2,550 for three bedrooms and $2,550 to $2,650 for penthouses and duplexes.
The building will be replete with amenities: a lobby finished in slate, marble and rich woods that opens to the atrium courtyard; a 24-hour uniformed concierge; three conference rooms and a theater for use by residents; and a fitness center, installed on three levels of the building's landmark "Nipper" tower, with 360 degree views. The square tower is so named because of four stained-glass windows near the top, depicting the dog on the RCA logo, Nipper, listening to a Victrola -- an image created by the English painter Francis Barraud.
The entrance to the Victor apartments will be on Market Street next to the tower, at the same entry point used by RCA employees for more than 80 years.
Residents of the Victor will only have to walk across Delaware Street to hop onto an aerial tram to Philadelphia. The tram, financed with $8 million in federal transportation money, is scheduled to be built over the next two years and to begin service by the spring of 2005. A light rail system providing a direct connection to Trenton and quick access to New York City, with a station next to The Victor, is set to open this spring. There is also ferry service to Philadelphia.
The New Jersey State Aquarium, the South Jersey Performing Arts Center, the battleship New Jersey and its new museum, and Campbell's Field where the Riversharks baseball team plays, are all within three blocks of the Victor.
"We did the market analysis of this area, and this project," Mr. Grossman noted, "and we are underwriting it based on a superb plan for a historic building that will provide very high-quality housing units."
Because the building is receiving federal tax credits related to its historic status,rules require that it remain rental units for five years. After that, both Mr. Dranoff and Mr. Grossman said, it is likely to become a candidate for conversion to condominiums.
"We are putting in all the amenities you could ever want in a condo," Mr. Dranoff said, "and we expect the building to be supersuccessful as rentals or condos."
He went on: "I'm telling you, Camden is happening. It's not going to be the poorest city 10 years from now. Our property, which was once the symbol of blight, will be the symbol of a remarkable revival. How could it fail, with all the energy and creativity -- and cash -- flowing into it?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: The RCA Victor building, as of last September. Rents at the Victor are to range from $775 to $2,650 a month. (Carl Dranoff) Map of New Jersey highlighting The Victor in Camden.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
< HDL>Openings For Growth In European Equities

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
ONE of these years, investing in Europe is going to pay off.
 For most people, it certainly didn't last year. Only a handful of mutual funds that invest in European stocks posted positive returns. Over the last three years, the average European equity fund has fallen by just over 16 percent, according to Lipper. 
 Jason T. Holzer, senior portfolio manager of the $375 million AIM European growth fund, talked last week about Europe's prospects. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Why invest in European stocks?

A. Europe is selling at about a 35 percent discount on price to cash earnings relative to the Standard & Poor's 500 index. That is close to a 25-year low. Europe's price to book value is at about 1.6 times, which is close to a 10-year low. And the dividend yield is 3.6 percent.

Q. Aren't European economies weak?

A. People continuously bring up the same negatives about Europe -- the European central bank is less proactive, labor is inflexible in terms of its mobility and Germany is very much sputtering. But, in fact, Europe has some key structural advantages relative to the United States. First, Europe doesn't have a current account deficit, as the United States does. The U.S. deficit requires foreign investment. To this point, foreign investors have been happy to do that.
Second, Europe doesn't have the same level of overcapacity as the U.S. Savings rates are higher, and consumer debt levels are lower. In Europe, consumer debt is 46 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 82 percent in the United States.
Finally, in Europe there is generally a lower level of equity ownership.

Q. Why haven't more Europeans bought stocks?

A. With the bursting of the technology and equity bubble more generally, a lot of first-time investors that came in have pulled out. That has kind of retarded the development of the equity culture.

Q. Why were the markets down in January?

A. A lot of the softness since the start of the year has to do with general uncertainty about economic prospects, the situation in Iraq and forced selling of stock by insurance companies. In the United Kingdom some insurance companies have been selling stock in order to avoid insolvency problems. One of the problems Europe had in the 1990's was that strong returns on equities disguised the fact that insurance companies were not making money underwriting policies.
But the flip side of the weakness is opportunity, and we are finding a tremendous number of reasonably priced growth stocks in a wide range of countries.

Q. Which markets do you like, and why?

A. Peripheral markets like Ireland and Spain are among our larger weights in Europe. The economies in both countries are growing at close to 3 percent. And our biggest weight is in the United Kingdom, which last year had decent economic growth of more than 2 percent. We are underweight in France, as well as Holland and Switzerland.

Q. Which stocks in these markets are you particularly excited about?

A. The largest holding in our European fund is Anglo Irish Bank, an Irish-based company. This is a stock with a $2 billion market cap that has been the fastest-growing bank in Europe over the last five years, with a compound growth rate of more than 30 percent. It focuses on lending to small and medium-size businesses. And they have successfully exported their model from Ireland to Britain. This is a bank that has over 30 percent return on equity yet sells at barely over 10 times 2003 earnings.
We like a number of companies in Spain, including Mapfre, an insurance company with leading positions in life and nonlife insurance. Inditex, a world-class retailer whose best known format is Zara, is another Spanish company we like. It is probably the fastest growing large retailer in the world. They have a few stores in Canada, the United States, Britain and throughout Europe.
One company we like in Britain is Imperial Tobacco. It sells at about 10 times earnings with a dividend yield of more than 4 percent. It has no U.S. exposure, and thus has no litigation risk. It is a very solidly run company that is extracting a lot of cost savings from an acquisition they made in Germany. The company has an A.D.R. that trades in this country.

Q. Do any sectors look attractive?

A. We have increased our exposure in telecom. It is more attractive to us because companies have hunkered down and are focusing on cash flow and reducing capital expenditures. And the pharmaceutical area looks pretty interesting.
One smaller drug company we like is Stada, a German generic drug company. It should be a great beneficiary of a the nascent but much less developed generic drug market in Europe than we see in the States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jason T. Holzer

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Honda Accord; 
Further Dividends From Honda's Midsize Investments

BYLINE:  By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: OJAI, Calif. 

 BODY:
IN the 1980's, before Americans discovered the joys of commuting in vehicles designed for safaris, the family sedan was king of the road. Chevy and Ford vied with pretenders from Japan. Near the end of each model year, automakers mounted last-ditch efforts to win the crown that went to the nation's best-selling car.
 Detroit no longer has its heart, or its wallet, in this race: its automaking profits come mostly from trucks and truck-based S.U.V.'s. But the Japanese (as well as the Germans and Koreans) still invest heavily in midsize, midprice cars, and the market is crowded with classy models at fair prices. The latest, and one of the greatest, is the seventh-generation Honda Accord. 
 The Accord has always been near the top of the pack, offering comfort, polish and reliability on a par with the market-defining Toyota Camry, while generally beating the Camry in power and handling. The competition has become a lot tougher in the last year or two, with the arrival of a handsome, sporty Nissan Altima; better-built midsize sedans from Hyundai and Kia; and, most recently, a new Mazda, the 6, to replace the aging 626. Is Honda up to the challenge?
Better you should ask whether Placido Domingo can carry a tune.
The 2003 Accord comes as four-door sedan or two-door coupe, with four- or six-cylinder aluminum engines and five-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The coupe is also sold with a six-speed manual borrowed from the Acura 3.2CL Type-S.
Both new Accords look more aggressive than previous models, with broad haunches and a sharply sloping hood, along with head-turning headlight treatments. My guess is that this hint of Dr. Jekyll in a car that has defined buttoned-down civility will irritate as many potential buyers as it charms. But on every other score, there's no denying that the 2003 model is a big step up.
The smaller of the two engines, a 2.4-liter in-line four, generates 160 horsepower -- a notable 10 more than the last-generation engine. The 3-liter V-6 pumps out a remarkable 240 horses, up 20 percent. Yet with the extra gear in the automatic transmissions, both engines get better mileage than their predecessors. Indeed, the four-cylinder with an automatic, which will almost certainly be the best-selling combination, is rated at 24 m.p.g. in town and 33 on the highway. Thanks in large part to its fancy electronics, this engine also meets California's super-ultra-low emissions standard, called Sulev.
To complement the new muscle, Honda modified the suspension and steering to accommodate more aggressive driving. The tires are bigger and designed for more demanding use. Models that came with 14- and 15-inch wheels have been bumped up to 15 and 16 inches, and the V-6 with the six-speed gearbox flaunts 17-inch wheels with 215/50R17 low-profile tires. Antilock brakes are standard -- at last! -- on every version.
All the Accords that have four-wheel disc brakes -- that is, all the six-cylinder models, plus the fancy EX four-cylinder -- also come with electronic brake distribution. This technology increases braking efficiency by adjusting the braking force between front and rear according to the distribution of passengers and cargo.
Inside, the new Accord is Honda-practical with touches of eye candy.
The driver's seat is more supportive -- indeed, according to my aching back, it is about as good as car seating gets. The steering wheel now telescopes as well as tilts -- very handy and somewhat unusual in an era of cost-cutting designs. Side air bags are available on all models, and the high-end V-6 has side-curtain bags for head protection.
While the outside dimensions are virtually unchanged, the interior has been reworked to provide more storage for maps, CD's and Twinkies, as well as marginally more passenger room. The bigger change is psychological: the cabin seems more airy, and the materials never feel flimsy or cheap. Aside from the first-class front seats, the rear can handle three adults in economy-class comfort.
As one expects from Honda, the controls earn high marks for aesthetics and ease of use. The buttons are generally large and well placed. Visibility, front and rear, is excellent.
What may not be expected is the bit of flash. The instrument panel, with its L.E.D. meters and backlit "floating" needles, reminded me of a Lexus. The keyless locking system, standard on all but the basic DX model, can be used to open and close all four windows.
Those springing for the EX V-6, starting around $26,000, get frills that push the car into luxury territory: heated leather seats with power controls for both driver and passenger, two-zone climate controls; and a monster stereo with six-disk changer. A DVD-based navigation system with voice recognition (adapted from I.B.M.'s ViaVoice software) is an option on the EX.
I spent a day sampling the whole Accord line on mountain roads above Malibu, and later used a four-cylinder EX automatic to commute and run errands for a week. The V-6 with manual transmission is loads of fun -- a true driver's car. But the real bargain is the combination of four-cylinder engine and five-speed manual gearbox; with optional air-conditioning, that car is around $17,000. The engine is rated at just 160 horsepower, but it felt like more. The Honda stick shift is about as quick and precise as they come, and the steering has just enough road feel.
The four-cylinder automatic that I took home provided a less rousing experience. While creamy-smooth, the transmission bleeds off a bit of power and takes the edge off the sense of control imparted by the stick shift. Moreover, the sheer understated competence of the car can make getting from here to there a forgettableexperience. By every objective standard, however, this is a very satisfying people mover.
It corners very well -- far better than the previous Accord -- with minimal body roll on hard turns. And like all well-designed front-drive cars, the Accord gives ample warning before it reaches the limits of traction. The suspension is unflappable on rough pavement, giving the Accord the feel of a bigger car. Interior noise is exceptionally low for a midprice sedan. The quiet -- along with the great front seats -- probably explains why hours on the freeway generated almost no fatigue.
No car, it is safe to say, is going to dominate a market segment this competitive. I am smitten by the style of the Nissan Altima, and undoubtedly vast numbers of drivers will remain loyal to the Camry, with its great reliability and high resale value. By the same token, the Volkswagen Passat and the new Mazda6 are winners with drivers who put a premium on handling.
In short, the only reason not to buy a new Accord is the proliferation of worthy competition. This is a remarkable moment to be shopping for a midsize sedan. Too bad so many Americans insist on driving vehicles that are more at home fording the headwaters of the Zambesi than changing lanes on Interstate 5.

INSIDE TRACK: A wealth of practical riches.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The 2003 Accord coupe, above, and sedan do not look much alike, and indeed they share few visible exterior pieces. In both versions, the controls and instruments show Honda's attention to detail.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Betting on the Gulf War? Try Securities in Israel

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
AMERICANS have had to factor terrorism and the prospect of war into their investment decisions for more than a year, but Israelis have been doing it for decades. Being near a center of continual conflict has taught them to shrug off events that would alarm investors anywhere else.
 Still, the prospect of another Persian Gulf war, and months of suicide bombings, are among the reasons Israeli stocks have fallen about 25 percent in the last year. 
 "Political events in Israel are so much the norm that the market has learned not to react to them," said Jonathan Half, an analyst for UBS Warburg in Tel Aviv. "But major political events, where there is a change in direction in the geopolitical situation, will have an impact." 
Until the standoff in the gulf is settled, UBS prefers to limit its exposure to Israeli stocks, which fell 0.4 percent last week, after the election that kept Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his Likud Party in power. "The market in Israel will react positively to a short, limited war and a solution to the problem," Mr. Half said.
Americans wishing to take advantage of any recovery in Israeli stocks have ample means to do so. The closed-end First Israel fund and five Israeli companies trade on the New York Stock Exchange. More than 70 Israeli companies trade on Nasdaq. A mutual fund called the Blue and White fund is raising money from investors and is expected to begin operations shortly. It aims to put 75 percent of its portfolio into Israeli stocks that are listed in America.
Beyond the immediate trouble involving Iraq, the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians has produced a chronic drag on the economy, with no end in sight. 
Stanley Nabi, managing director for value investments at Credit Suisse Asset Management, the company that runs the First Israel fund, said that an end to the Iraq crisis may provide only fleeting relief to Israel. The stock market "will go up temporarily," he predicted, "but any resolution with Iraq is not going to resolve the Palestinian conflict."
Israeli stocks have also been hurt by the global slowdown in technology spending. "Israel is a country that relies on exporting technology, and that has weakened considerably," Mr. Nabi said. 
On the other hand, Shlomo Eplboim, the chairman of Eplboim, Poutre & Company, an investment management firm in Los Angeles that is a founder of the Blue and White fund, said that Israeli exporters benefit from the persistent decline in the value of the country's currency, the shekel, which makes their products cheaper for foreign buyers. 
One company with a large following abroad is Check Point Software Technologies, which provides Internet security. Mr. Eplboim likes Check Point but said he would wait until the stock falls to $10 before buying; it closed on Friday at $14.33. Check Point has a lot of cash on its balance sheet and ought to benefit from "a huge catch-up in upgrades of security software" when technology spending revives, he said.
Mr. Half said that Warburg was "not that positive on technology." Nevertheless, Israel has many "higher-quality, profitable companies in the sector," including Check Point, he said, which is "considered almost the primary supplier of firewalls used by corporates to secure their networks."
Other Israeli stocks recommended by Warburg include Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, one of the world's largest makers of generic drugs, and the DSP Group, "a world leader in developing and selling semiconductors used in cordless phones," Mr. Half said.
Mr. Eplboim also said that he likes Teva but recommended buying it on a dip below $30. He said he would buy Taro Pharmaceutical Industries, a producer of dermatology medications , at the same price. It closed on Friday at $35.15.
Other stocks he would consider buying include Elron Electronic Industries, a holding company for technology businesses, and two banks, Bank Leumi and Bank Hapoalim.
All of the stocks mentioned trade on Nasdaq, except the two banks, which trade on the over-the-counter market for smaller or less active stocks.
The country's strength in technology reflects its security needs, as well as a highly educated work force that is continuously replenished by the immigration of scientists, engineers and other skilled workers, including many from the former Soviet states. Israel also devotes considerable resources to education and provides hefty tax breaks for corporate research.
Mr. Eplboim explained that inventors who develop products for the military are typically permitted to profit from civilian applications. The government's attitude, he said, is that "because they are spending so much on the military, they might as well make it into a business."

HEADLINE: Suing the 9/11 Fund 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "7 Families Sue Administrator of 9/11 Fund" (news article, Jan. 27):
 My father (lost on 9/11) would be mortified to know that people are taking Kenneth R. Feinberg to court. 
 Using the federal fund intended to compensate relatives of victims is optional. You can go with it or sue the airlines. The Cantor Fitzgerald suit is a purely opportunistic action, and it's embarrassing to those of us who are glad for an alternative (albeit imperfect) to a suit. 
Yes, the loss of a wage earner will require people to give up things in their lives as a result of the financial change. It happens to families every day. I am concerned to hear that "the families" are demanding one thing and the next; I can imagine what our neighbors -- so generous with their donations after the attack, and many hit hard by this ailing economy -- are thinking.
Of course no one wants to be heard criticizing the 9/11 families, and I think that's what Cantor's attorneys are betting on.

TINA CHRISTMAN
Astoria, Queens, Jan. 27, 2003

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Theodore T. Southworth; 
Northern Income Equity Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THESE have been trying times for buyers of convertible securities, says Theodore T. Southworth, who runs the $204 million Northern Income Equity fund.
 Ideally, convertibles -- bonds or preferred shares that can be converted to common shares at a predetermined exchange rate -- will account for all of the fund's holdings, he said. But he has reduced that proportion to only 76 percent because few convertibles have been issued recently and there are fewer good buys available, he said. At the moment, stocks account for 10 percent of the fund's holdings, and cash represents 14 percent. 
 He said that he believed that the supply of convertibles would remain tight because financial markets are still unsettled. "Companies haven't yet reached the point where they're looking for money for general corporate purposes," he said.
The fund lost 0.5 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with a 5.2 percent loss for all convertible bond funds, according to Morningstar. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell at an annual rate of 13.5 percent in that period.
The fund declined 3.3 percent in the 12 months through Thursday, compared with losses of 6.5 percent for its group and 22.9 percent for the S.& P. 500, Morningstar said.
Mr. Southworth, 54, is a senior vice president of Northern Trust, which owns Northern Trust Investments, the fund's adviser. 
Generally, he said, convertible securities, which pay interest, give investors exposure to stock market profits but with less risk. His goal is to identify convertible issues with high potential for gains.
He picks the fund's 80 or so convertibles mostly from among about 600 domestic convertibles whose underlying common stock has good earnings growth potential and sells for reasonable valuations. 
While he reviews a company's fundamentals, including cash flow and earnings growth rate, he also pays attention to technical analysis -- the study of a stock's price movements -- over the last year or two.
When the price charts deviate from analysts' expectations, he said that he puts his faith in the charts, which reflect the actual behavior of the great majority of investors. 
In April, Mr. Southworth bought a convertible preferred security due in May 2005 issued by Alltel, a regional phone company based in Little Rock, Ark. He paid $49.81 for the issue, which yielded 7.75 percent; it closed on Friday at $47.90. Because the issue is a "mandatory convertible," which must convert to common shares on a specific date, regardless of its stock price at the time, its price fluctuates more like a high-yielding equity than a bond, Mr. Southworth said. It is unrated by Standard & Poor's but rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service, a midlevel investment grade rating. He expects annual earnings growth of 8 percent in the next three years.
He bought a 5.75 percent senior convertible note due in April 2007 and issued by Airborne Inc., in Seattle. He paid $94.34 for the note in October, 2002; it closed on Friday at $107.25. The issue is rated BBB- by Standard & Poor's, its lowest investment-grade rating. "The stock was bumping along at $10 because the market seemed to make the judgment that the economy would never recover," Mr. Southworth said. "We thought that we'd avoid a double-dip recession, and if the economy grows the transportation sector will have to participate."
He also owns a BB- rated subordinated convertible note due June 2006 issued by the Interpublic Group of Companies, the New York-based holding group of advertising agencies. Last summer, "Interpublic's stock price got clobbered when its earnings didn't meet expectations, and everyone worried about whether they can believe anything that management told us." he said. He bought the issue before the Securities and Exchange Commission notified Interpublic in January that it was upgrading an informal inquiry into the company's accounting practices to a formal investigation. "I don't know, whether the investigation will amount to anything," he said, "but I'm still reasonably happy with the purchase."
He paid $65.50. On Friday, the convertible note closed at $77.

HEADLINE: The World; 
To China, North Korea Looks Radioactive

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI 

 BODY:
IT did not seem impossible, just a few weeks ago, that China and the United States would work hand in hand to end the North Korean standoff. 
 Bush administration officials urged China to use its economic and diplomatic leverage to halt North Korea's nuclear ambitions. Some even wondered if China might emulate Germany in 1989, opening its borders to refugees and forcing North Korea to abandon totalitarianism or collapse. 
 It did not seem impossible in Washington, anyway. China, however, has shown few signs of dealing decisively with a crisis on its own doorstep. Instead, to an extent that has worried even some of China's own foreign policy experts, Beijing has been largely paralyzed by of one of the most challenging international problems it has faced since the Vietnam War. 
China has declined Washington's overtures to lead negotiations with its former ally across the Yalu River. It has also continued to summarily repatriate refugees from North Korea and deny them access to the United Nations, appearing to violate its obligations under a 1951 treaty.
China has the largest standing army in the world and spends more on its military than any country except the United States. It is also Asia's rising political and economic heavyweight. Yet the strongest statement the Chinese have mustered in the Korean crisis is an admonition to "both sides" -- meaning the United States and North Korea -- "not to take measures that will complicate matters." China's hesitancy may have surprised those in Washington who saw North Korea as China's client state. China, after all, did lose more than a million men battling American troops to a standstill in the Korean War. 
But Beijing began losing influence with the North Koreans in the 1980's under Deng Xiaoping, when it opened its economy and abandoned Communist-style planning. Things got worse in 1992, when China established an embassy in Seoul without insisting that the United States recognize North Korea first. In 1995, after Beijing reduced subsidized grain exports, North Korea had to swallow its pride and appeal to the United Nations for emergency food aid. 
Even in the area where China has the most to offer North Korea -- reforming its ruined command economy -- the two nations are barely on speaking terms. Last fall, China arrested Yang Bin, a Chinese tycoon whom Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, had selected to head a new economic development zone. Mr. Yang was charged with economic crimes in China. Mr. Kim, by most accounts piqued at Chinese interference, has yet to find someone else to head his planned capitalist enclave.
But China is not without leverage. Two-way trade between the nations is $740 million, about a quarter of North Korea's total trade, and Beijing still provides vital aid. But it has avoided taking a strong stand, at least in part because North Korea threatens to upset the carefully scripted plans of China's inward-focused leadership. 
Both Jiang Zemin, China's president, and his successor as Communist Party chief, Hu Jintao, care primarily about two things: economic growth and Taiwan. The rest of the world can worry about global terrorism, weapons of mass destruction, religious tensions, poverty and the increasing assertiveness of the United States. China just wants to get rich and reconstitute its territorial integrity.
Even on the always-sensitive topic of Taiwan, Chinese leaders have turned "extremely moderate," in the words of one senior official, because they are confident that economic ties will ultimately give them more leverage than test-firing missiles, as they did in the mid-1990's.
The soft approach has generally improved relations with the United States. China did not object to the occupation of Afghanistan, which put American troops on its western border. It does not like the Bush administration's aggressive Iraq policy any more than France does, but it does much less than France to challenge American leadership on the issue.
But Chinese timidity on North Korea may have made a bad situation worse. Some Chinese foreign policy experts are worried that the United States cannot solve the problem alone, hinting that China needs to do more, if only to protect its own interests.
Shi Yinhong, an international relations expert at People's University, argued in an essay published last week that China must reassess its strategic priorities. The problem, he said, is that even if the Americans negotiate in earnest, North Korea may have no incentive to abandon its development of nuclear weapons. It could develop an arsenal of warheads, possibly forcing Japan and South Korea to go nuclear, too. That would upend the strategic balance in Asia, which currently favors China.
"I'm fearful that when North Korea masters the rules of this game, it will have ample time to truly develop its own nuclear weapons," Mr. Shi wrote. "When that happens, it will really be the start of regional tensions."
Can the United States single-handedly bring an end to North Korea's nuclear ambitions? "This is highly doubtful," Mr. Shi wrote.
As a high-level American commission noted in a report last year, the long-term question about China is whether it becomes "a responsible world power or an aggressive, wealthy dictatorship." The short-term question, however, is when it will emerge from its foreign-policy cocoon.

HEADLINE: What's Behind The Retail Slump? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "A Sinking Feeling at the Register" (Jan. 19): It's primarily the retailer that is driving deflation. 
The United States has had too many stores for more than a decade. The buoyant economy of the 1990's, however, masked the problems of some retailers and encouraged others to continue adding stores. When the economy softened in 2000-01, retail overcapacity became a concern. 
 In the current environment, retailers can increase market share only at the expense of their competitors by becoming increasingly promotional. To cope with such price discounting, they're simultaneously reducing expenses and inventories. These savings are being used, in turn, to lower prices to the consumer to gain market share. And so the cycle will continue until the weak retailers fall by the wayside. 
American consumers are simply taking advantage of, and even demanding, lower prices. Consumer demand, in fact, is much stronger than most analysts believe; it has just been muted by the aggressive pricing strategies of retailers.

JAY McINTOSH
New York, Jan. 19

The writer is the Americas director for retail and consumer products at Ernst & Young.

The Seniority column, written by Fred Brock, which usually appears the first Sunday of each month, will now appear on the second Sunday.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Fewer People Choosing Lasers Over Lenses

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
About 162 million people in the United States need some form of eyeglasses or contact lenses. So far, only about 3 million have tried to put away their glasses forever and undergo corrective laser surgery. 
 Prices have dropped for the most common form of laser surgery, called Lasik, to an average of around $1,600 for each eye, but 21 percent fewer people had laser correction in the first nine months of last year compared with the same period in 2001. David R. Harmon, president of Marketscope, an opthamology research firm, blames the weak economy for the falloff. The surgery is not covered by most insurance policies. 
Many people are satisfied with the surgery, but risks include impaired vision, according to the Food and Drug Administration. Details can be found at its Web site, www.fda.gov/cdrh/lasik.
 KATHLEEN O'BRIEN

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
For a Third Week, the 3 Major Indexes Fall

BYLINE:  By JEFF SOMMER 

 BODY:
All three major stock market indexes fell for the third consecutive week as the prospect of a possible war with Iraq weighed on investors.
 A rally on Friday could not counter two weeks of deep losses. 
For January as a whole, the Dow fell 3.5 percent, the Nasdaq declined 1.1 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.7 percent. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 77.2 points, or 0.9 percent, closing at 8,053.81. The S.& P. 500 lost 5.7 points, declining by 0.7 percent, to close at 855.70. The Nasdaq composite index, fell 21.23 points, or 1.6 percent, closing at 1,320.91.
 Economic news was mixed. On Friday, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago reported that manufacturing in the Midwest was expanding, while the University of Michigan said that consumer confidence sputtered in January.
 Hewlett-Packard declined more than 7 percent for the week on signs of weakness in demand for computers. AOL Time Warner, which announced the biggest yearly loss in American history, fell more than 17 percent.
 The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 3.96 percent from 3.93 percent the previous week. 
 JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: Ah, Those Principled Europeans 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS 

 BODY:
Last week I went to lunch at the Hotel Schweizerhof in Davos, Switzerland, and discovered why America and Europe are at odds. At the bottom of the lunch menu was a list of the countries that the lamb, beef and chicken came from. But next to the meat imported from the U.S. was a tiny asterisk, which warned that it might contain genetically modified organisms -- G.M.O.'s.
 My initial patriotic instinct was to order the U.S. beef and ask for it "tartare," just for spite. But then I and my lunch guest just looked at each other and had a good laugh. How quaint! we said. Europeans, out of some romantic rebellion against America and high technology, were shunning U.S.-grown food containing G.M.O.'s -- even though there is no scientific evidence that these are harmful. But practically everywhere we went in Davos, Europeans were smoking cigarettes -- with their meals, coffee or conversation -- even though there is indisputable scientific evidence that smoking can kill you. In fact, I got enough secondhand smoke just dining in Europe last week to make me want to have a chest X-ray. 
 So pardon me if I don't take seriously all the Euro-whining about the Bush policies toward Iraq -- for one very simple reason: It strikes me as deeply unserious. It's not that there are no serious arguments to be made against war in Iraq. There are plenty. It's just that so much of what one hears coming from German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and French President Jacques Chirac are not serious arguments. They are station identification.
They are not the arguments of people who have really gotten beyond the distorted Arab press and tapped into what young Arabs are saying about their aspirations for democracy and how much they blame Saddam Hussein and his ilk for the poor state of their region. Rather, they are the diplomatic equivalent of smoking cancerous cigarettes while rejecting harmless G.M.O.'s -- an assertion of identity by trying to be whatever the Americans are not, regardless of the real interests or stakes.
And where this comes from, alas, is weakness. Being weak after being powerful is a terrible thing. It can make you stupid. It can make you reject U.S. policies simply to differentiate yourself from the world's only superpower. Or, in the case of Mr. Chirac, it can even prompt you to invite Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe -- a terrible tyrant -- to visit Paris just to spite Tony Blair. Ah, those principled French.
"Power corrupts, but so does weakness," said Josef Joffe, editor of Germany's Die Zeit newspaper. "And absolute weakness corrupts absolutely. We are now living through the most critical watershed of the postwar period, with enormous moral and strategic issues at stake, and the only answer many Europeans offer is to constrain and contain American power. So by default they end up on the side of Saddam, in an intellectually corrupt position."
The more one sees of this, the more one is convinced that the historian Robert Kagan, in his very smart new book "Of Paradise and Power," is right: "Americans are from Mars and Europeans are from Venus." There is now a structural gap between America and Europe, which derives from the yawning power gap, and this produces all sorts of resentments, insecurities and diverging attitudes as to what constitutes the legitimate exercise of force.
I can live with this difference. But Europe's cynicism and insecurity, masquerading as moral superiority, is insufferable. Each year at the Davos economic forum protesters are allowed to march through the north end of town, where last year they broke shop windows. So this year, on demonstration day, all the shopkeepers on that end of town closed. But when I walked by their shops in the morning, I noticed that three of them had put up signs in their windows that said, "U.S.A. No War in Iraq."
I wondered to myself: Why did the shopkeepers at the lingerie store suddenly decide to express their antiwar sentiments? Well, the demonstrators came and left without getting near these shops. And guess what? As soon as they were gone, the antiwar signs disappeared. They had been put up simply as window insurance -- to placate the demonstrators so they wouldn't throw stones at them.
As I said, there are serious arguments against the war in Iraq, but they have weight only if they are made out of conviction, not out of expedience or petulance -- and if they are made by people with real beliefs, not identity crises.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The New Calculus Of Diversity on Campus

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
AT public universities in California and Texas, the end of affirmative action in admissions has benefited one minority: Asian-Americans.
 And if the Supreme Court decides later this year to limit or eliminate race-conscious admissions at the University of Michigan, Asian-Americans stand to gain far more than any other group, at least in proportion to their numbers in the general population. 
 Their experience in the admissions process provides yet another prism through which to view the affirmative action debate. As things stand now, a relatively low percentage of Asian-American students are admitted to many top private and public institutions, nearly all of which practice affirmative action, compared with the high numbers of the arguably qualified among them. 
But if the Supreme Court phases out race-conscious admissions, the number of Asian-American students can be expected to soar, at the expense of other groups, even whites.
The statistics in California and Texas give ammunition to critics of affirmative action who say that some applicants, primarily white or Asian-American, are being rejected in favor of blacks and Hispanics who may not be as accomplished, at least as measured by standardized-test scores and grade-point averages.
But the same statistics also provide ammunition to those who support race-conscious admissions and who argue that unless colleges give special attention to black and Hispanic applicants, whites and Asians could lay claim to all but a handful of the spots on some campuses. 
To gain a sense of how the composition of a student body can shift, consider the University of Texas at Austin. 
After a federal court in 1996 barred the University of Texas from practicing affirmative action, the state began offering admission to all high school students ranked in the top 10 percent of their classes. Given the racial and economic segregation in the state's high schools, the assumption was that blacks and Hispanics would be given a fairer chance to enroll, without having to compete directly with whites who lived in richer districts.
But as it turned out, the main beneficiaries were Asian-Americans. The percentage of freshmen entering the Austin campus who were Asian-American rose to 18 percent last fall, compared with 14 percent in the fall of 1995. Thus, almost one in five freshmen at the university's flagship school is Asian, in a state where only about three of 100 residents are. 
As the admission rate of Asian students rose, to 71 percent from 68 percent over that period, the admission rate of whites fell, by one percentage point to 66 percent. So did that of blacks, to 43 percent from 59 percent.
Hispanics were admitted at a rate of 56 percent in 2002, down from 72 percent in 1995. They make up about a third of the state population but less than a fifth of the freshman class at Austin.
Asked to explain the dynamic, Bruce Walker, the director of admissions at Austin, said, "Obviously they are the top students in their schools."
"Any state that goes to a percent plan and has a significant number of Asians will discover that Asians will be the ones who will benefit most," he added.
In California, where Asians make up 11 percent of the general population, the gains were also striking after the state ended traditional affirmative action in the late 1990's and adopted a system similar to that of Texas. 
At Berkeley, the percentage of the freshman class that was Asian-American rose 6 percentage points, to 45 percent, in 2001. Over the same period, the percentage of the class that was black fell by three percentage points, to 4 percent; the percentage that was white dropped by one percentage point, to 29 percent; and the percentage that was Hispanic fell by six percentage points, to 11 percent.
Contrast that with the experience of the University of Michigan Law School, which practices race-conscious admissions in a typical way, with admissions officers considering applicants' test scores and grades, as well as their backgrounds. Along with the undergraduate program, which uses a more formulaic approach that awards extra points to a black or Hispanic applicant, the law school is a defendant in the lawsuits being heard by the Supreme Court.
When, for example, it assembled its class for the fall of 1999, the law school accepted only one of the 61 Asian-Americans, or 2 percent, who were ranked in the middle range of the applicant pool, as defined by their grades and test scores, according to court filings. The admission rate for whites with similar grades and scores was 3 percent. 
But among black applicants with similar transcripts, 22 out of 27, or 81 percent, were offered admission. 
Michigan, like other selective colleges, defends the lift given to black applicants, as well as to Hispanics, for two main reasons: to level the playing field for what it calls underrepresented minorities, who might not have the educational advantages of many whites and Asians, and to enhance the educational experience of all students by immersing them in a diverse environment.
Though supportive of affirmative action for black and Hispanic applicants in particular, Evelyn Hu-DeHart, a professor of history and ethnic studies at Brown, said she took offense at the perception that there might be a threshold for how many Asians on a campus was too many.
"I'll tell you what is discriminatory in the case of Texas," said Ms. Hu-DeHart, who emigrated from China in the 1960's. "They don't say whites are overrepresented. They're pitting Asian-Americans against blacks and Latinos by saying Asian-Americans are taking your place."
She added: "Let Asians compete freely with white students."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Berkeley, the freshman class was almost half Asian-American in 2001. HEADLINE: California Looks to Casinos for Revenue 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER and CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Trying to close a $34 billion budget deficit, Gov. Gray Davis has cast a covetous eye on a gushing revenue stream just beyond his reach: the billions pouring into California's Indian reservations, where slot machines and blackjack have made casino gambling the fastest-growing industry in the state.
 States cannot tax sovereign Indian tribes. But they can strike deals. California reached one four years ago when it legalized Indian casinos. The economy was booming then, and state officials now admit that in negotiating the agreement, known as a compact, they bargained badly. While California's 50 Indian casinos took in an estimated $5 billion in profits last year, only a sliver of those riches went to the state. 
 Now Mr. Davis, hoping to exploit dissension among the tribes and the desire among some to expand their gambling business, wants to reopen the 20-year compact and negotiate a fat share of casino revenue, as states like Connecticut and New York have done. He projects that this could add $1.5 billion a year to state coffers, compared with less than $100 million estimated for the current fiscal year under the existing compact.
But in return, he may have to accept a stunning expansion of gambling in California.
In bargaining with the Indians, the state's only leverage is its ability to grant licenses for additional slot machines and other gambling devices. Gambling experts say that to get the $1.5 billion Mr. Davis seeks, the state would have to allow tribal gambling to at least double.
The most profitable big tribes are asking for an unlimited number of slot machines, currently capped at a total of 61,000 statewide. Some tribes are also pushing to get into sports betting and Internet wagering.
What happens in California, where Indian casinos produce about a third of the nation's $15 billion in tribal gambling revenue, will resonate across the country. Nevada is watching with particular wariness because the huge expansion being sought by the tribes here could starve Nevada's casinos of billions.
Opponents say there are already too many casinos in California, producing local environmental and traffic nightmares as well as thousands of new gambling addicts a year.
Many say that expanding gambling enough to produce the revenue California officials seek would amount to doubling down on an already bad bet.
"You're talking about expanding an industry that has a significant social effect on the public without any regulation or oversight," said Cheryl Schmit, co-director of Stand Up for California, an antigambling group. "That $1.5 billion figure is scary to me because it means a huge expansion. We are a scandal waiting to happen."
The smaller among California's 125 federally recognized tribes are unhappy too. In exchange for supporting the statewide compact in 1999, they were promised a piece of the action. Each of the 75 tribes that either run small operations or own no casinos at all was supposed to get more than $1 million a year under the Revenue Sharing Trust Fund, which the casino-owning tribes finance. But despite as much as $5 billion in casino profits last year alone, the smalltribes have received less than half the promised amount.
Casino gambling "was supposed to lift everybody's boat," said Anna Kimber, a lawyer who represents a consortium of smaller tribes. "To date that has not happened, and many people in Indian country are skeptical that it will happen under any new agreement."
The gambling operations provide plenty of cash for lobbying and political contributions, however. The tribes have spent more than $100 million since 1998 to win legalized gambling and to keep politicians in Sacramento friendly.
Mr. Davis's budget proposal for the coming fiscal year assumes $1.5 billion in fees from Indian gambling, one of several sources of new revenue, including an increase in the sales tax and higher income taxes on the wealthy. The figure was apparently arrived at by looking at the deals other states have cut with tribes. New York and Connecticut, for example, reap from 18 to 25 percent of the profit from slot machines and casino card games.
But California officials involved in overseeing gambling say they have little confidence that Mr. Davis and the Legislature will do a better job of bargaining than they did four years ago. They would not say so for attribution, voicing fear for their jobs.
One senior state regulator said the governor's $1.5 billion revenue estimate was "totally unrealistic." He added that New York and Connecticut had modeled their compacts on California's -- by doing everything differently from it. New York expects to reap as much as $400 million a year from its recent casino deal with the Seneca tribe alone.
California officials acknowledge that the 60-page compact Governor Davis and his aides hurriedly produced in 1999 was deeply flawed.
"When we entered the compacts in 1999, we were entering a brave new world, something that had never before been done here," said David Rosenberg, the governor's point man on Indian gambling issues. "We envisioned we would learn things."
Now the only way the state will get an additional penny from the tribes is by by allowing more gambling devices, including slots, video poker machines and even electronic roulette tables. It is impossible to know how many machines the traffic will bear, but the coming negotiations will provide a test of the tension between commercial hunger for profits and government hunger for revenue. "This will be a very interesting social study going forward," said Richard E. DeCuir, acting executive director of the California Gambling Control Commission.
Mr. Davis has appointed a three-member team to negotiate with the tribes. "My goal," he said, "is this: to ensure that all gaming tribes fulfill their obligations, obey the law and pay their fair share, both to the state and to nongaming tribes."
California tribes have varying interests in the bargaining. Some want to get into the business, some want to expand, and others are happy to keep things the way they are. Conflicts over land and Indian identity are also driving the tribes apart. Mr. Davis hopes the internal conflicts will work to the state's benefit by preventing the tribes from forming a common negotiating position.
The bottom line for most casino-owning tribes is threefold, tribal leaders and lawyers say. They want a ceiling on the fees they will pay to the state, they want to keep the exclusive right to run casinos in California (thus freezing out racetrack owners and others who want to operate slot machines), and they want an unlimited number of machines.
"As long as people want to buy what we have to sell," said Anthony Pico, chairman of the Viejas band,which runs one of the state's most profitable gambling operations, "then we should be able to move forward and sell it."

HEADLINE: Iran's Revolutionary Fervor Is Now All but Spent 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Twenty-four years ago today, a 78-year-old ayatollah with fierce eyes named Ruhollah Khomeini landed in an Air France plane to make a revolution.
 As it has done every year since then, the Islamic Republic that was created in his name is celebrating the 10 days between his arrival and the surrender of the shah's army. 
 Big colored lights were strung on the city squares and public buildings. Iranian flags hung from lampposts. An honor guard on horseback waved bright red banners. Parachutists jumped from helicopters on huge rainbow-hued kites. Paintings and billboards were hung throughout the capital with sayings like, "The revolution was victorious only because of the sacrifices of our martyrs." 
But the revolutionary fervor that moved a nation to sacrifice for so long evaporated long ago. Ayatollah Khomeini promised a heaven on earth in which the poor and the oppressed masses would rule and be free. Instead, the country is plagued by political paralysis, corruption, unemployment, social restrictions and uneven and unnerving repression. A fierce guerrilla battle wages between those claiming to speak in the name of Islamic purity and those who call themselves democrats.
Iranians love to rhyme, and street vendors and taxi drivers have taken to calling the 10 days of "fajr," meaning dawn, the 10 days of "zajr" -- torture. There is so little zeal left that even the apparatus of the Islamic Republic, with its revolutionary foundations, the police and the Armed Forces, made almost no effort to mobilize the masses today. 
Nowhere was that more evident than at Behesht-e Zahra cemetery. That was Ayatollah Khomeini's immediate destination 24 years ago, where he honored those who lost their lives under the regime of the fallen shah and vowed to topple the monarchy forever. He was so badly jostled by the wave of people trying to touch him that his turban fell off.
Today, despite an official call to pray and remember, only about 300 men and a few dozen women came. Many of the folding chairs brought in for the occasion were empty. Schoolgirls in pale blue head coverings and royal blue coats came on a field trip not to honor Ayatollah Khomeini but to visit the tomb of a rival ayatollah who was silenced after he objected to the intrusion of religion into politics.
A soldier on guard duty cried out -- about fatigue. "My legs are breaking," he shouted to a colleague.
The anniversary of the coming of the ayatollah has set off the memories and recalled the dashed dreams of revolutionaries like Mohsen Sazgara, a leading reformist writer. A college student in the United States when Ayatollah Khomeini set himself up in exile in Paris in 1978, Mr. Sazgara quit school and borrowed $200 to join him there. He was one of the 190 aides and journalists on the historic plane trip.
"I remember the night before we were going to leave on that plane that Imam Khomeini called us together and said: 'This journey may have some dangers. Everyone who wants to stay behind, please stay.' But everyone said, 'We want to be with you.' We were ready to be martyred."
In the early part of the revolution, Mr. Sazgara worked to shape the official radio and the Revolutionary Guards. Then he fell from grace.
"Gradually they considered me part of the opposition," he said. "I write books and they don't allow them to be published. I started a newspaper and they shut it down. I was teaching history at a university and they stopped me.
"Let me confess something to you. My son just graduated from university this semester. Once he asked me, 'O.K., father, is it good that you were in the United States and gave up your studies and went to Paris and came to Iran to make this government?' I said: 'You're right. We made a mistake.' "
That sense of defeat is felt even in clerical circles in Qum, the country's training ground for clerics.
For Mohammad Ali Ayazi, a mid-ranking cleric who is in the vanguard of the clerical movement to reform the Islamic Republic, Feb. 11, 1979, the day when the shah's army surrendered, was "the happiest day" of his life. On that day, the revolution triumphed, and Mr. Ayazi's first child, Yasser, was born.
But Yasser Ayazi, a physics major in Qum, will not celebrate the anniversary. "People are not too happy these days," he said. "People need a democratic Islamic republic and justice, but I see a lot of problems still untouched, unsolved. So I am not feeling particularly warmly toward this celebration."
Ayatollah Khomeini died in 1989. But even at the shrine where he and his son Ahmed are buried, there was little Islamic fervor today.
None of the country's major political figures came to speak, and it was left to Hassan Khomeini, the ayatollah's grandson, to address the crowd. As he has done in past years, he praised his grandfather as "a selfless hero" who sacrifice all for the revolution.
"We should value the achievements of the revolution," he said. "This is a country that elects its own president, its own Parliament, its own leadership." By contrast, he said, George W. Bush was elected president "fraudulently with the power of the judiciary behind him."
