PERSON: Evelyn Trout 

HEADLINE: Evelyn Trout, Record-Setting Flier, Dies at 97 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Evelyn Trout, a pioneering aviator who flew in the first Powder Puff Derby and held many records, including becoming the first woman to fly all night, died on Jan. 24 in San Diego. She was 97.
 Known as Bobbi for her bob hairstyle, she had an international pilot's license signed by Orville Wright in 1929 that was carried into space in 1995 by Eileen Collins, the first woman to be the pilot of an American spacecraft. 
 Miss Trout set many records for endurance and altitude; became the fifth woman to earn a transport license, allowing her to fly for hire; and was one of the first women to be a pilot for the Los Angeles Police Department. 
In 1929, she was one of 19 participants in the first National Women's Air Derby, a California-to-Ohio race that Will Rogers famously called the "first Powder Puff Derby." 
She had two hard landings on the trip. After the second, 70 miles short of Cleveland, she did her own repairs, using "old tin and baling wire," according to a 1999 interview with The Los Angeles Times. When she reach Cleveland, officials scolded her for taking such a risk.
"I told them, 'It got me here, didn't it?' " she said. She was the last survivor of the famous race.
Her fame, like that of other early daredevils, was such that Walt Disney hired her in 1928 to publicize Mickey Mouse, not yet a famous character, by taking aloft a planeful of Mickey Mouse dolls.
Remembering the glories of her youth in an interview with The Los Angeles Daily News in 1999, Miss Trout said, "People thought we were nuts."
Miss Trout was born in Greenup, Ill., on Jan. 7, 1906, and spent much of her childhood moving with her family around the country, staying with relatives. Her early ambitions were to be a cowgirl or a motorcycle racer, but when she was 16, she had her first plane ride in a Curtiss Jenny and was captivated.
She was adept at mechanics, but administrators at her Los Angeles high school made her take home economics, which she told The Los Angeles Times was a "sissy course." While still in high school, she persuaded her parents to buy a service station for her to run. Soon the station was so successful that her father quit his job with the phone company to help her run the business.
She said in an interview with The San Diego Union-Tribune that after high school she weighed the options of studying architecture in college or learning to fly. She decided to use her earnings from the service station for flying lessons.
The federal government gave her license number 2,613, meaning that just 2,612 pilots had been licensed before her. On Jan. 1, 1929, she received her international pilot's license, signed by Orville Wright, then chairman of the International Aeronautic Federation. 
Miss Trout had a $35-a-week job demonstrating a new monoplane called the Golden Eagle, and she set her first record on Jan. 2, 1929, when she stayed aloft for 12 hours and 11 minutes to beat Viola Gentry's women's endurance record of eight hours. The New York Times reported that she carried concentrated food and a bottle of hot chocolate.
On Jan. 31, 1929, Elinor Smith beat Miss Trout's time by an hour. The battle was on. On Feb. 13, Miss Trout stayed up for 17 hours, 5 minutes to regain the record and become the first woman to fly all night. Miss Trout said in an interview with The New York Times that she had only lent the record to Miss Smith for a couple of weeks.
On June 16, 1929, Miss Trout climbed to 15,200 feet in a new 90-horsepower Golden Eagle Chief. This set an altitude record in light aircraft for women.
In November 1929, Miss Trout and Miss Smith joined forces to set an endurance record. They hoped to stay up for a month by refueling from a gas hose lowered by a refueling plane. They lasted 42 hours, 3 1/2 minutes, but that was a record.
On Jan. 1, 1931, Miss Trout and Edna May, another pilot, set another record by flying for more than 122 hours.
In the 1930's, Miss Trout was a flying instructor and commercial photographer. In World War II, she invented a machine to sort unused rivets that were being scrapped by aircraft companies and developed a device for smoothing the edges of machined metal. Also in the war, the Los Angeles Police Department hired her and four other women to do aerial surveillance.
Miss Trout was single, and no immediate family members survive. In her later years, she sold real estate and insurance and participated in events honoring the pioneers of aviation. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 6, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Sunday with an obituary of the pioneer aviator Evelyn Trout misidentified the plane shown with her. It was a Curtiss Pusher, not a Curtiss Robin.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
Talking the Talk Of Collusion Redux

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
George Steinbrenner has experienced no more frustrating moment in his 30-year baseball life than that moment on the afternoon of Dec. 18, 1986. He let Jack Morris walk out of the Bay Harbor Inn, Steinbrenner's hotel, in Tampa, Fla., without an agreement to pitch for the Yankees.
 Morris had won 21 games for the Detroit Tigers the previous season, making him a 20-game winner for the second time in four seasons. (He missed a third by one victory.) The Mets had won the World Series less than two months earlier. 
 The Yankees had finished in second place behind Boston, but Dennis Rasmussen, with 18 victories, was their only pitcher with double-digit victories. Morris, a 31-year-old free agent, was exactly what the baseball doctor ordered. This is what free agency was all about. 
Yet Morris walked out of Room 600 of the Bay Harbor Inn without a Yankee deal. He was a victim of the second year of the owners' conspiracy against free agents. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, was not a victim, but he surely was an unwilling participant, given his penchant for lavishing free agents with money.
The owners' collusive activity of the 80's serves as a backdrop for current events in baseball because the clubs have once again raised suspicion with some of their activities involving free agents. 
In 1985 and '86 teams did not try to sign free agents as long as their former teams wanted to retain them. In 1987, clubs made offers to free agents, but the offers were remarkably similar, courtesy of a secret information bank the clubs' labor unit maintained.
Scrutinizing the results of this winter's signing activity, union officials are not attributing the less lucrative contracts or the number of unsigned players to collusion. But agents have reported an unusual sameness or similarity in offers to some of their clients, and they have picked up hints that clubs are sharing information.
If the union, after an exhaustive investigation, determines grounds for a grievance, they will ask the arbitrator to decide if the clubs have violated the provision in the labor agreement that states, "Players shall not act in concert with other Players and Clubs shall not act in concert with other Clubs."
That provision exists because the clubs wanted it. When free agency came into existence in 1976, the clubs wanted to guard against the type of strategy that Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale had used in their contract negotiations with the Los Angeles Dodgers a decade earlier.
And then the owners ignored their own concerns and used the strategy themselves in 1985. Richard Moss, a player agent a decade after he argued the arbitration case that won free agency for the players, demonstrated clairvoyance when he made an observation less than two weeks into the free-agent signing season.
"Obviously, they have an understanding among each other that they're not going to go after free agents as long as the former club is involved," he said.
Just as management officials have denied collusive activity this off-season, they denied it then, too. Barry Rona was the owners' chief labor lawyer in those years, and when the word collusion was uttered, he would scoff and sneer.
"The clubs, in effect, are saying, 'I won't go after your players and you don't go after mine,' " he said that first winter, offering his explanation of events. "There's nothing wrong with that. They didn't sit down and agree to that. They're just doing it."
Union officials were not the only ones who were skeptical of that explanation. "Obviously, they didn't all wake up one day with the same thought," one manager said.
That winter Rona said, "To the best of my knowledge and information, there is no conspiracy, there are no rules, there are no bulletins, there are no regulations that exist that control the behavior of the clubs."
A year later, in January 1987, when Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said he would testify at the grievance hearing, Rona said, "I'm pleased the commissioner will be a witness and look forward to his testimony, which I am totally confident will finally put aside the union's allegations of conspiracy."
But their own constituents undermined the stonewalling stance of Ueberroth and Rona. Notes of owners meetings kept by Bill Giles and Dave Montgomery of the Philadelphia Phillies became critical evidence in support of the union's case. 
And from within the owners' ranks, too, came this telltale report. According to a person present at a meeting of Baltimore officials in September 1986, Edward Bennett Williams, the Orioles' owner, said, "Do you think the commissioner would let us sign Lance Parrish?"
In September 1987, Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, found the owners guilty of violating the concerted action provision. Noting that after the 1985 season no clubs pursued free agents unless their 1985 clubs relinquished interest in them, he concluded that that "in itself, constitutes a strong indication of concerted action."
The right of the clubs to pursue free agents, he added, "no longer remained an individual matter to be determined solely for the benefit of each club."
"The contemplated benefit of a common goal was substituted," Roberts said.
In 2000, in a ruling in a case stemming from collusion, Judge Stephen Reinhardt of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, referred to the "owners' deceit and fabrication" and their effort "to cheat their employees out of their rightful wages" and wrote, "The owners' mendacity in their 1980's collusive efforts to depress the ballplayers' income was in many ways as damaging to baseball as the Black Sox scandal of 1919."
The clubs would be convicted twice more of collusion. They would settle all three cases for $280 million. The payout to the affected free agents was left to the union, which is still dealing with the case.
Responding to the new suggestions of collusion, Rob Manfred, the clubs' chief labor executive, noted last week that when the clubs had just negotiated a labor agreement "that clearly moves the economics in your direction, why would you collude that year?"
He added, "It makes no sense."
The owners initiated Collusion I two months after negotiating a new agreement in which they gained a major concession from the players that raised eligibility for salary arbitration from two years to three.

The Windup, the . . .
Sandy Alderson, for one, was not surprised that the games in last October's World Series were like the Energizer bunny: they kept going and going and going.
"We had three of the four slowest starting pitchers in that Series," said the man in charge of baseball operations in the commissioner's office. 
And how did Alderson determine who the slowest pitchers were in the major leagues last season? Basically the formula is time of game minus time between innings and for pitching changes divided by total number of pitches. The result is adjusted seconds a pitch.
One problem with the result is it does not cover only the time the starting pitcher is in the game. His time a pitch includes the time and pitches for all of the others who pitch in a game for his team. 
But Alderson and his crew want to identify only the pitchers they think work too slowly. Based on the formula, Livan Hernandez of San Francisco was the slowest-working pitcher in the majors last season, averaging one pitch every 30.7 seconds. He pitched in the World Series as did No. 3, his teammate Russ Ortiz (30.1), and Kevin Appier of Anaheim (30.0), who tied for fourth with Andy Pettitte of the Yankees.
The Atlanta Braves have acquired not only Ortiz, but also No. 2 on the slow monitor, Mike Hampton (30.4).
The fastest pitchers last season were Mark Buehrle (25.6) and Dan Wright (25.8) of the Chicago White Sox, Glendon Rusch of Milwaukee (25.9), Wade Miller of Houston (26.3) and Paul Wilson (26.3), then of Tampa Bay, now of Cincinnati.
The average adjusted seconds a pitch in the majors was 27.9.

Home Field, Home Phone
Before Fenway Park, before Yankee Stadium, before Wrigley Field there was Comiskey Park. But no longer. The second incarnation of Comiskey will give way to a new name. U.S. Cellular Field will take its place alongside all of those other new-name parks that give fans no idea of who plays in them.
The Chicago White Sox played in the first Comiskey from 1910 through 1990 and have played in the second since 1991. Now the second will take on a new name, but it will not mask the mistake the White Sox made in having it built as the first but the worst of the new-era parks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jack Morris was one free agent George Steinbrenner let get away. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Therapeutic Treatments For Title IX

BYLINE:  By SELENA ROBERTS 

 BODY:
MAYBE it wasn't the salt exfoliation treatments the fellas looked forward to, but on the night before every home football game last season, the Colorado Buffaloes left dorm life for a luxury retreat.
 About 15 miles from the campus in Boulder, Colo., at the foot of mountains that press like cleats against the sky, the Buffaloes settled into the high thread-count digs of the nearby Omni Resort. 
 Its Mobil four-star rating isn't for the plush towels alone, but for the soothing spa, the 27-hole golf course and aromatherapy massages. Who wouldn't focus better with eucalyptus burning? So, the team with a 100-man roster hunkered down at the Omni to prepare its game face (facial, not included). 
And imagine, college wrestling coaches have blamed Title IX for the elimination of their sports.
Perhaps Dennis Franchione's pledge of loyalty to Bama came with fingers crossed, because when the folks at Texas A&M offered him enough money, his Sweet Home Alabama went up for sale.
One of nearly 20 Division I-A football coaches to cash in after the $1 million barrier was broken a decade ago, Franchione signed a deal that will put him near $2 million a year -- another benefactor of the Bob Stoops Syndrome. Three years ago, Stoops became hotter than a corporate turnaround artist when he delivered Oklahoma's football program from evil during a run to the national title. Fearing Stoops would flee, the Sooners secured him with a $2 million salary. 
And imagine, parents blame Title IX when college administrators take away the men's swim team in an attempt to abide by proportionality guidelines.
"Go point by point and compare football to the cost of the teams that are getting eliminated," said Andrew Zimbalist, professor of economics at Smith College and author of "Unpaid Professionals: Commercialism and Conflict in Big-time College Sports." "You can see there is more than enough money out there for everyone if they would just get rid of the waste."
The cost difference between a 117-player roster versus a 90-man roster is about $800,000, Zimbalist said, who added that an average wrestling team costs $330,000. Put money and proportion to good use, and you save a wrestling program.
It's not Title IX that threatens men's sports, but the entitlement of football programs. It's not manufactured women's teams, but mythical revenues from football. It's not excess of women's uniforms, but the $250,000 Oregon spent on a 34th Street billboard in Manhattan for a Heisman Trophy candidate.
Yet, out of the jumble of fix-it strategies for Title IX -- many emerging from the subjective minds of a Bush administration commission this past week -- there was no insistence on football reform. In the end, the group actually gave a tacit green light for more inflatable football rosters by providing Education Secretary Rod Paige with the leeway to play with the numbers regarding walk-ons and nonscholarship athletes.
Instead of a male-female ratio that is proportionate to enrollment under current Title IX interpretation, if applied, the new system would count the number of roster spots, not the number of participants, toward compliance. Potentially, this could give universities the freedom to deflate numbers of male athletes and pump up those for women.
It would be nice if athletic departments could be trusted to do the right thing -- understanding how Title IX in its current form has been the source of an athletic boom for women -- but football is too seductive to allow room for faith.
As the legend goes, football programs rake in millions, allowing athletic departments to indulge. "We've gone to a hotel because our players are spread out all over campus," said Jon Burianek, Colorado's senior associate athletic director for business. "Some live in dorms where, on a Friday night, it's not a conducive atmosphere."
Beer bong or playbook, it's an easy choice at the Omni. Star treatment is a good recruiting tool. While Burianek said Colorado is treading water in meeting its budget, he sees the hotel as a necessary perk.
"You have to be careful," Burianek said. "You don't want to kill the golden goose." Is it fool's gold, though? As money comes and goes at equal speeds, administrators can easily play puppeteer with the numbers.
"You can have a $100 million stadium that is being funded off a state bond," Zimbalist said. "The cost of servicing the bond could be $10 million a year, but that's not charged to the athletic department."
A marching band could be on an athletic department's budget or charged to the music department. The shuffling can go on and on, Zimbalist said. 
If money isn't the only object, what is? Brand identity. Most often, football is where the prestige is, where trustee pride grows. Other sports are just filler in between the big game on campus.
The obsession is worrisome. Officials fret over football expenditures, but there is no help for the compulsive shopper when winning is a job requirement. The cycle isn't hopeless, though. There is a way to balance Title IX compliance against football's image benefits: put a cap on rah-rah-based spending.
"What the N.C.A.A. ought to do is go to Congress and lobby for an antitrust exemption," Zimbalist said. "I'm sure they would get it."
It's a radical approach, but if implemented, there could be salary ceilings, roster structure and limits on luxuries. Imagine, money for all, sports for each gender and no one to blame.

HEADLINE: To All the Nuclear Fears Swirling Around Indian Point Plant, Add Fear Itself 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
As the government reassesses emergency preparedness at the Indian Point nuclear power plant, it faces a conundrum: the more often that opponents of the plant say the emergency plans will not work, the more likely they are to be right.
 That conclusion was outlined in a recent report by James Lee Witt, former director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which is reviewing disaster plans at Indian Point. 
 Beneath the basic conclusion of Mr. Witt, now a consultant to New York State, that the plan is inadequate, is a second problem: the current debate over Indian Point is having the perverse effect of making emergency action, if necessary, harder, and people who dislike the plant are making things worse. 
"Advocacy groups use language whose emotional content can increase unnecessary evacuation, and thus can have adverse consequences for public health in the event of a release," the report said. 
Unnecessary evacuation, experts say, would clog the roads with people who could safely stay put, a phenomenon argued over since 1979, when emergency planning for nuclear plants began, called "shadow evacuation."
How much would occur is a matter of speculation, but Mr. Witt said some parties were encouraging it. "In pursuit of their agenda to close Indian Point, some have misused" data from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, he said, "presumably to frighten and alarm the public. Misuse of information can lead to behavior that may endanger public health and safety."
FEMA is supposed to sort this out sometime in February, when it will produce a new report on preparedness for the reactors, in Buchanan, N.Y. The report will consist of its evaluation of the September 2002 emergency exercise at Indian Point and an evaluation of Mr. Witt's work. Current officials of the agency said they would not talk about the Witt report until their review was done.
But Mike Beeman, a spokesman for FEMA, listed exactly the same concern as Mr. Witt: "It will work if people understand what they should do if there were an event that occurred at the plant, and understood that they should listen to people providing the directions to them." Otherwise, he said, the potential for paralysis on the roads would increase.
Why, then, is the public becoming more concerned without becoming more educated? Because, according to the Witt report, some people want it that way, to close the plant.
"Their persistent misuse of scientific data contributes to public misinformation," his report complained. "Ending those parts of their effort that can with fairness be termed demagoguery would serve the public better, and make more effective the participation of advocacy groups in the regionwide planning process."
Mr. Witt did not further define which advocacy groups he was talking about, and a spokeswoman for his consulting firm said he would not comment further until the report was complete. It is currently in a "public comment" period that resembles those that accompany the official reports of the government agency he used to head.
And no one was willing to own up to deliberately misrepresenting information to scare the public. 
"There is nothing that we've said publicly that is inaccurate or misleading," said Kym Spell, a spokeswoman for Riverkeeper, the nonprofit organization that is one of the most prominent opponents of the nuclear plant. "I can't speak for James Lee Witt; I don't know who he's referring to," she said. Riverkeeper's position is that emergency plans will never be good enough.
Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, another prominent opponent, said that opposition to Indian Point was now a "great social movement" and that like all such movements, it was diverse and might, in fact, include people who said things that were not true. Mr. Brodsky said he had not concluded that adequate emergency plans were impossible, but that there were plenty of other reasons to close the plant, many of them economic.
Mr. Witt himself, although he found numerous deficiencies, stopped well short of saying the plans could not be made workable, and also said that there was more to coping with an emergency than planning. "Organizations and people have the ability to adapt during a response, so actions can vary emergency to emergency," his report said. "Many preparedness shortfalls can be addressed in a response using emergency processes or adaptation, whereas systemic issues can be much more problematic. We have focused on the systemic, while acknowledging that many things can be 'handled' if an emergency were actually to occur."
How FEMA will read that balance is not clear; Mr. Beeman said it had a clear scope of what it would look at. (Not on the list, he said, was whether opponents were misusing data to scare the public.) But the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which is likely to have the final say, has a different outlook, according to one of its members, Edward McGaffigan.
"We have to have 'reasonable assurance of adequate protection of the public health and safety,' " he said in a telephone interview. "It doesn't say absolute assurance or perfect protection of public health and safety."
"A lot of this emergency planning stuff may well come down to a vision that these plans have to be perfect," he said.

HEADLINE: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE REACTION; 
Sorrow, Memories of Challenger and a Will to Move Ahead

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
"Don't cry, Mom, but they are gone," the voice from London said when Beverly Poon, a municipal bus driver in San Francisco, picked up the telephone this morning.
 The caller was Ms. Poon's daughter, Beverly Alcorn, an emergency room nurse in the Air Force posted to England. She was watching images on television of the space shuttle Columbia as it broke into pieces in the skies over Texas. 
 Ms. Poon did cry. And so did her daughter. Though they did not know anyone on the spacecraft, they felt an intense connection to the disaster. It was in 1986, when the space shuttle Challenger exploded, killing the schoolteacher Christa McAuliffe and six other astronauts, that Ms. Alcorn vowed to enlist in the military, Ms. Poon said. Her daughter was 15 at the time. 
"Seeing what happened to Christa McAuliffe made her want to be the best of the best," said Ms. Poon, 53, tears welling in her eyes as she shared her sorrow with several other drivers at the downtown bus terminal here. "That is how I always explained terrible things to my children. Yes, it is a heart breaker, but look what went before that. These people lived their dream."
The sadness was everywhere today. Sadness for the families of the dead astronauts. Sadness for a country still feeling the hurt of Sept. 11, and apprehensive about a possible war with Iraq. Sadness for a space program that is a source of great national pride. And sadness for the distant countrymen of Col. Ilan Ramon, a former Israeli combat pilot and the first Israeli to travel in space.
"This kind of thing just brings everybody down," said Mike Kelly, an engineer from Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., who was running errands when his wife called to tell him of the disaster. "And what the country needs now is some positive news."
In Washington, at the National Air and Space Museum, more than 100 people crowded beneath a mock-up of the Hubble telescope, their eyes fixed on a 50-inch screen broadcasting a news conference from NASA. Next to the television, a small sign served as a painful reminder of the screen's intended purpose: "Transmissions from Shuttle Orbiter Columbia, Landing, Feb 1, 9:16 a.m."
Ziv Neeman, an Israeli physician who works at the National Institutes of Health, went to the museum with his family after hearing about the explosion. It was the only place that it made sense to go to, he said.
"It was supposed to be a great day for Israelis," Dr. Neeman said. "With all the horrible things going on, this was supposed to be a light."
At William Horlick High School in Racine, Wis., where one of the astronauts, Laurel Salton Clark, had graduated, displays of her accomplishments were suddenly transformed into memorials. Flowers piled up at the school's entrance and moments of silence were observed during an afternoon wrestling match. Attendance was higher than usual, as people congregated at the school to talk about what had happened.
"It's kind of like having a huge hole taken out of your stomach," said William Freyer, a social studies teacher, who had taught Ms. Clark.
For many people, the news about Columbia came in anxious telephone calls from friends and relatives. Others learned of the disaster on the radio. Still others, like Robert Aubey, caught the first shocking images of the splintering spacecraft when television news broke into the morning's cartoon shows.
For Mr. Aubey, of Madison, Wis., it was one of those awful moments for a parent, much like Sept. 11 had been. He was watching "Dora, the Explorer" with his son, Connor, who is 4, when a bulletin about Columbia flashed across the screen. After realizing the gravity of what had happened, he switched to the Cartoon Network. He then slipped out of the room to follow the news reports on another television.
"I didn't know how to explain what had happened," said Mr. Aubey, who later took his two sons and wife shopping to get away from the television coverage. "We don't necessarily want to talk about it with the children."
In Grosse Pointe Park, it had been a good week for Mr. Kelly, whose wife, Beth, gave birth to their first child on Thursday. But her telephone call this morning about the disaster sent him reeling. A self-described "science buff," Mr. Kelly said he feared for the future of the space program and worried about the repercussions for a wobbly economy.
Mostly, though, he mourned the loss of life. Like Ms. Poon, the bus driver, Mr. Kelly's thoughts drifted to 1986, when he had watched the Challenger explosion on television while holed up sick in a hotel room. 
"I remember this hollow feeling," Mr. Kelly said.
Heather Natsch, 26, a graduate student in San Francisco, said the disaster also reminded her of the Challenger. She was in elementary school then. Things seemed simpler 17 years ago, she said, and the country quickly rallied. Her teachers brought the children together to watch coverage on television and to talk about the process of mourning.
This time, Ms. Natsch said, there seemed to be so many other issues and distractions. She wondered how Americans would respond.
"We've got our resources spread so thin," she said. "There are so many things going on in so many places. I'm concerned this accident won't get the same attention as the Challenger."
Though the Bush administration said there was no evidence that the disaster today was related to terrorism, some people said it would be difficult to separate the tragedy from the tense state of world affairs.
Gracie Farkas, 48, of South Bend, Ind., had watched a shuttle launch at Cape Canaveral, Fla., about five years ago. She still remembers vividly how the spacecraft caused a tremendous shaking of the ground. Today, she said, terrorism was the first thing that came to mind.
"Isn't it an eerie coincidence that this would happen when there is a crisis in the Middle East?" Ms. Farkas said. "I just find it ironic given the crisis of the world right now."
In Grosse Pointe, Mich., Dr. Bonnie Stanton, a pediatrician, said she hoped the loss of the Columbia would somehow cool the fiery oratory toward Iraq and slow the march toward war.
"I just wish people would stop and think," said Dr. Stanton, who opposes a military conflict with Iraq. "It's so easy to be cavalier until something like this wakes us up and reminds us what every death is like."
Charles B. Hendrix of Florence, Ala., feared that the disaster would prove a distraction at a time when the nation cannot afford one.
"It's a shame that something like this has to happen just as we are about to go into battle," Mr. Hendrix said
Ms. Poon, the bus driver in San Francisco, said she served in the Army during Vietnam and the Persian Gulf war. She was not fearful of a military conflict with Iraq. She also did not read hidden meanings into the Columbia disaster. But she shared the view that the calamity over the skies of Texas carried significance far beyond the event itself.
"What will not break us, makes us stronger," Ms. Poon said. "I believe in this country. I believe in the innate ability of Americans to survive. We will survive this one too."
Dr. Neeman, the Israeli physician, also saw hope in the darkness. This morning, his four-year-old son, Omer, threw a coin into a fountain and wished to become an astronaut. "There will be more Israeli astronauts," Dr. Neeman said.
He also suggested that there was solace in such a distant death in the sky.
"It is a wonderful place to die," he said. "It is the closest you can get to heaven." 
But for Cynthia Strachan, a store manager in Buchanan, Mich., yet another fiery end to a space mission made it difficult to look toward the sky with optimism. She watched the television in tears as President Bush addressed the nation.
"It's just horrific," Ms. Strachan said. "Everyone used to look up at the stars and used to be so idealistic."

HEADLINE: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE PAST; 
Space Program's Cycles of Triumph and Tragedy

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
America's 44-year adventure into space has been a chronicle of triumph and tragedy, of early manned flights that circled the earth and landed on the moon, of explosions that killed astronauts, of cost overruns and corruption, and of robot satellites that explored the Solar System and sent home amazing pictures and data from other worlds.
 The chapters have been called Mercury, Gemini, Pioneer, Mariner, Apollo and the less glamorous space shuttle, and the issues have been complex, combining national aspirations, cold-war politics, the endless human quest for scientific knowledge and the hard practical questions of cost and feasibility. 
 After the Soviet Union leaped first into space with the orbiting of Sputnik I in 1957, American fears of losing the space race led to the creation of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 1958. Through the 1960's, it focused on putting Americans on the moon, although it also launched weather and communication satellites andachieved many other goals. 
The $25 billion space shuttle was envisioned in the 1970's as the successor to the successful moon-landing program. Less expensive and ambitious than a manned mission to Mars, the reusable shuttle was to revolutionize exotic space flight by turning it into an inexpensive, once-a-week event, paying its own way by deploying and repairing satellites and selling other space services.
But almost from the start, the shuttle was plagued by design failures, cost overruns, delays, fraud and mismanagement within NASA and its contractors. Many problems were hidden until the 1986 explosion of the Challenger, which killed seven astronauts. More recently, an aging work force and management shortcomings have continued at NASA, experts say, and these and other problems are expected to be explored in the inquiries into yesterday's Columbia tragedy.
In the early years, NASA exploits, including Alan B. Shepard Jr.'s suborbital spaceflight in 1961 and John Glenn's three-orbit flight in 1962 -- seemed to be the stuff of science fiction, with splashdowns broadcast to millions on television and heroes stepping from capsules.
Begun in 1958 and completed in 1963, the Mercury program was the nation's first man-in-space project, although its six flights accomplished much more, sending up the first weather and communications satellites, devising ways to launch and recover spacecraft and investigating human ability to work in space.
From 1964 to 1966, Gemini put astronauts into orbit for up to two weeks, with some of them stepping outside their capsules for spacewalks. A Ranger 7 rocket sent back close-up images of the moon before crashing on the lunar surface in 1964. A year later Mariner 4 flew within 6,118 miles of Mars, providing the first close-up images, and in 1966 Surveyor 1 made America's first soft landing on the moon and transmitted 10,000 photos of the lunar surface.
There were setbacks, even tragedies, as NASA worked under pressure of tight budgets and technical difficulties to carry out President John F. Kennedy's 1961 call for the nation to put a man on the moon before the end of the decade.
On Jan. 27, 1967, the astronauts Virgil I. Grissom, Edward H. White II and Roger B. Chaffee were killed on the launchpad at the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral when a flash fire engulfed their capsule during a simulation aboard an Apollo-Saturn rocket. They were the first deaths directly attributable to the space program.
But the 1960's were its glory years. In December 1968, Apollo 8, with the astronauts Frank Borman, James A. Lovell Jr. and William A. Anders on board, circled the moon and, focusing a television camera on earth, sent to worldwide television audiences the first view of the "blue marble."
The halcyon period reached a climax in 1969 with the Apollo 11 moon landing. On July 20 Neil A. Armstrong and Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. touched down in a lander while Michael Collins orbited in a command module. Setting foot on the surface, Armstrong told millions of viewers it was "one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind."
Before returning to earth, the astronauts spent 21 hours on the moon, taking rocks and soil, setting up experiments and planting an American flag. 
The Apollo 13 mission, in 1970, was a near disaster. An oxygen tank ruptured as the craft neared the moon, damaging power, electrical and life-support systems. The lunar landing was scrapped. After circling the moon, the astronauts used the lunar landing module as a lifeboat to return to earth. With limited air and water, they endured an ordeal but landed safely.
There were other moon landings, including Apollo 15 in 1971, the first of three longer, expedition-style missions using a lunar rover. In 1972, Apollo 17 was the last of six moon missions; the astronauts spent 22 hours in moon walks and camped out for three days. In all, 12 men walked on the moon before the Apollo program ended. 
Meanwhile other projects went ahead. In 1971, Mariner 9 became the first Mars orbiter, and over the next two years Pioneer 11 went to Jupiter and sent back dramatic cloud-top and polar pictures. Viking 1 landed on Mars in 1976 and transmitted data for six years.
By the early 1970's, however, the nation's space program was entering a new and more troubled phase. While a manned mission to Mars was a possibility, it it was seen by political leaders and the public as far too expensive, at least for the forseeable future. The development of a reuseable space shuttle emerged as an economical and practical interim step.
The Nixon administration embraced it initially to promote scientific and military goals and to help shore up the ailing aerospace industry. It was sold to Congress on the assumption that it would pay for itself through business it would generate: shuttling up to deploy and repair many private commercial satellites, and other tasks.
From the start, however, the program set unrealistic goals, as many as 60 flights a year, and was plagued with cost overruns, delays and other problems. By 1981, when Columbia became the first shuttle, each launch was costing $250 million, 16 times the original estimates. But many of the worst problems were hidden until the shuttle Challenger exploded on Jan. 28, 1986.
Investigations later showed that faulty welds in a booster rocket -- faults that had been concealed through falsified X-rays by a subcontractor to avoid the cost of repairs -- had gone undetected and uncorrected until NASA auditors were tipped off by former employees of the subcontractor.
Investigators also learned that NASA had drastically cut spending on safety testing, design and development, even skipping thermal and vibration tests on the shuttle and its engines. Instead of testing component parts, contractors only tested assembled systems, investigators said. And they said NASA had misled Congress on costs and schedules, withheld documents, violated federal codes and squandered billions.
After the Challenger disaster, the shuttle was grounded until 1988. Since then, NASA has sought to make safety paramount, but critics have said this has fostered a conservatism that has led to further delays and cost overruns.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Apollo 1 astronauts Virgil I. Grissom, left, Edward H. White II, center, and Roger B. Chaffee, in front of their rocket at Cape Canaveral on Jan. 17, 1967. Ten days later they were killed in a fire on the craft. (Associated Press); Worshipers prayed at a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York for the crew of Apollo 13 in 1970. HEADLINE: Sheff Is Just the First Step 

BYLINE:  By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
NO sooner had Benjamin Otto of Glastonbury been accepted to the Greater Hartford Academy of the Arts, a magnet school, than his parents heard there might not be enough money in the town's budget to send him. So last spring, Benjamin, then 13, stood before the somber faces of his local board of education and asked for the $3,500 to send him to the school.
 "I told them how it's kind of like a family there, that it's just really fun," said Benjamin, who also urged the board to pay for the two dozen or so Glastonbury students accepted to the school. "All the kids there are nice, every single one. These are kids from other suburbs, kids from pretty much all over the state. It's a very evenly mixed school." 
 His parents figured the session would take half an hour, but they sat for three hours, as school administrators puzzled over how they would come up with the cash. The compromise: his parents would pay half. Administrators throughout the Greater Hartford area are even more puzzled now that Hartford's long-running desegregation case, Sheff vs. O'Neill, has been settled. The particulars of the settlement, announced late last month, are wending their way to suburban school districts, including the news that eight new magnet schools are to open in the Hartford area in the next four years in a move to attract more suburban children to city schools.But even before the particulars are digested, it is clear that the agreement hinges on two things: The willingness of suburban parents to send their children to school in a city with a dismal education history and, like all things, money, which Gov. John Rowland has made all too clear is in short supply. State officials said the cost of the new magnet schools would be paid in full by the state and Hartford, , but suburban officials questioned their ability to do so over the long run. "The state has consistently shown a pattern of coming up with new initiatives, particularly when it comes to schools, then not funding them," said Mary Tomolonius, Canton's first selectwoman. "Equalized cost-sharing was supposed to help towns pay for education. That has been cut. The school-construction grant program, now they are monkeying with those figures, and they are considering delaying payments to school construction projects. I have general concerns that when the state says it is going to pay for something, is it really going to pay? I have great trepidation when they say it's not going to cost the towns anything."
Sheff vs. O'Neill, filed in 1989, claimed that segregation in Hartford schools deprived students of the education guaranteed them under the state constitution. Numbers have changed little in Hartford since the suit was filed; about 90 percent of Hartford schoolchildren are minorities. The case dragged through the courts, until in 1996 the State Supreme Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs. But it left the practical application of a solution to the groups involved. The state instituted numerous programs to promote integration, yet the numbers in Hartford wouldn't budge. Today, only 10 percent of Hartford's school children are involved in the magnet schools. The settlement demands a 30 percent involvement over four years. It also doubles the Open Choice program, which sends Hartford students to suburban schools. 
The state is indeed saying the new magnet schools will cost the towns nothing. The schools will be called "host magnets," meaning they will be run by the city of Hartford. The existing host magnets, unlike the magnets run by the Capitol Region Education Council, do not charge tuition and neither will the new ones. The state insisted it would stay that way."The bottom line is that in the past five years, in good budgets and in bad, we always have funded the magnet schools," said Marc S. Ryan, the state's budget director. "But that doesn't mean this is going to be easy."
The host magnets are in comparison to the four inter-district magnet schools in Hartford, including the arts academy that Benjamin Otto is attending, run by the Capitol Region Education Council. They do charge towns for each of their children attending the schools. Many town education officials said they are already having trouble affording the fees and fear that similar fees will eventually be charged at the new schools.
One thing that makes the towns nervous is that the state's four-year contribution to the Sheff agreement is predicated on the belief that the economy will improve by next year. This year the state will spend $4.5 million under the agreement. That will build to a $45 million total at the end of four years. 
School districts are not so sure about the economy and are looking to cut where they can and conserve elsewhere. Simsbury has 40 students attending magnet schools. Schools Superintendent Joseph Townsley expected the tuition to the capitol region-run magnet schools to increase this year."I was concerned about the state keeping its fiscal commitment to the magnet, which they weren't able to do last year," he said. "That's still a concern, and the state has a significant debt that we need to address."
Local boards of educations also face difficult decisions at a time when the state is decreasing the amount of money towns get. Local taxpayers also may not support a budget where money could go out of town to the Hartford-area magnets rather than paying to hire another teacher to reduce crowding in the local schools. As the choices increase and the money tightens, "the problem will become more shaky," said Robert Villanova, the school superintendent of Farmington. "Even if this wasn't a tight budget year, we'd be struggling with those issues. This will be a test, in part because we have more students going than in the past and less money this year." 
Simsbury's Mr. Townsley took an informal survey of several suburban schools and found that school budgets had increased between 9 and 10 percent. Towns can draw in some revenue under the Open Choice program, in which students from Hartford attend school in the suburbs. But suburban school superintendents said they come up short in that exchange. In Simsbury, 69 students travel to the town from Hartford in the Open Choice program. The state pays Simsbury $2,000 for each of those students. The town then pays anywhere between $2,000 and $3,500 per Simsbury student to attend the magnets in Hartford. 
"It's clear to everyone the math does not work," he said. "An incoming student with $2,000, coming into a district whose per-pupil cost may range from $8,000 to $9,500, does not support a revenue flow. We're paying to educate those children from Hartford. The formula has to be changed. They should have more money follow the child."
The monetary difficulties overshadow the enthusiasm many suburban parents feel for the magnet school programs. Some of the schools have a waiting list and the hope among education officials is that the new magnets become just as popular. A few days after the Sheff settlement had been announced, three parents who were waiting in an orthodontist's office in Rocky Hill for their children to have their braces adjusted offered different reactions to the settlement.One parent sends her children to Catholic school in Middletown. She said she would not consider the magnet schools in Hartford. "Why change?" said the woman, who would not give her name. Another had never heard of the magnet schools, or Sheff vs. O'Neill. The third already sends his son to the Hartford arts academy."The schools in Rocky Hill are really good, but he wanted to try something different," said Don Hutchinson of his son, Sean, a freshman. "He loves it. But with the state cutting money to towns, and more call among the students to attend these schools, even with all the new options, fewer kids may be able to go."
The most popular magnet schools in Hartford are run by the Capitol Region Education Council, which has been running in the red for years. Every child costs about $9,500 to educate in council-run schools. The state budget pays $5,300 per suburban child, and the suburbs pay about $2,000 for full-time programs. That equals $7,300, about $2,200 short of the actual education cost. The shortfall has been picked up by the State Department of Education, about $4 million last year and projected at $6 million this year.
"Because the new magnet schools will be host magnets, we're not going to perpetuate that funding formula, but we have to solve the problem that is there," said Bruce Douglas, executive director of the Capitol Region Education Council and a former school superintendent in Suffield. "Suburban school districts can't afford to pay any more tuition, and yet these districts are trying to be socially conscious." 
The Hartford-host magnet schools formula is a bit more complicated. Hartford public schools use their budget to educate their own students in the magnets, plus receiving a subsidy from the state of about $1,700 per Hartford student. Add to that the $5,300 the schools get from the state for each suburban student. Because of all that money, Hartford does not have to charge suburban towns tuition."Of course, if every student is going to get a laptop and a trombone, that might require some type of tuition," said Tom Murphy, spokesman for the Department of Education. The bigger question may be whether the Hartford system can replicate what the council has done with the magnet schools. . The recent successes of both Anthony Amato, former Hartford schools superintendent, and his successor, Robert Henry, to increase test scores and attendance are helping to buttress those hopes. For parents throughout the Greater Hartford region, the possibilities are enticing."Who knows what they're going to come up with?" said David Colleary of West Hartford, whose daughter attends Kingswood-Oxford, a private school in town, and whose son, a fifth-grader, attends local schools. "We're pretty excited about it. I think it's a win-win for everybody involved, and we will certainly investigate all opportunities. The more the merrier."

HEADLINE: Two Cities Beton Power 

BYLINE:  By MARK PETERS 

 BODY:
THE fact that two new power plants should produce enough electricity to light a million homes means little in Milford and Meriden, the communities where they are being built. Instead, what matters is the promise of newly paved streets, additional teachers and lower property taxes that the plants represent.
 The question is when -- or whether -- that promise will be fulfilled. Construction on both plants has stalled and neither has announced a date for the start of operations. 
 Considerable money is at stake. Even before selling a single watt of electricity, each plant has become the largest taxpayer in its community. This year, the plant in Milford , which has a population of 52,000 residents, is expected to pay $5.3 million in property taxes. The Meriden plant will pay $2.9 million under a long-term tax agreement with the city of of 58,200 people.
Both plants would take advantage of state legislation passed in 1998 that deregulated the power industry. Developers targeted Meriden and Milford because they have essential components for the plants: access to the regional power grid, water andpipelines to supply the natural gas needed for the plants' operation. 
If completed, each plant would produce 544 megawatts of electricity, to be sold in Connecticut and beyond. A megawatt is enough electricity to power 1,000 homes. "I would expect both of these facilities to compete," said Joel Rinebold, executive director of the Institute for Sustainable Energy at Eastern Connecticut State University. Elected officials, both past and present, said they believed the plants will ultimately begin operations, cit "The plant will come on line because it is there --- it is just a question of when," said Fredrick L. Lisman, who was Milford's mayor when the plant was first proposed in the late 1990's.
In Meriden, Mayor Mark D. Benigni said, "Obviously we have a pretty enormous structure out there that you can see from just about anywhere in the city, and we want to make sure that that structure generates the tax revenue we were promised."
Milford did not provide any tax abatements to woo the plant. Meriden signed a long-term tax payment plan with the developer that would provide a steady revenue stream, eliminating fluctuations from reassessment and property depreciation.
Both the Meriden and the Milford projects began as a joint venture of the Power Development Comany of Boston and the El Paso Energy Corporation of Houston, but the Meriden project was sold in 2001 to NRG Energy, the power-generating subsidiary of XCel Energy, a Minnesota-based company. PDC-El Paso set a May 2002 start date for operation. NRG planned to start operating this summer. 
Neither plant is meeting its deadline. Construction stopped in May on the Meriden project, which is less than half way done. The Milford plant is near completion, but has no start date, according to the state board that regulates power plant construction.
Mortimer A. Gelston, chairman of the Connecticut Siting Council, said PDC-El Paso informed the council that the operation of the Milford plant is delayed because of lawsuits related to a February 2000 construction accident in which two workers died and a third was seriously injured. A special state court for complex litigation is hearing the cases. 
"We need that plant on-line -- I did not certify that plant to have it go through all these problems,' said Mr. Gelston, who is proposing that the council pull the plant's certification to operate if it is not running by next month.
A media representative for the Milford project, Ann Baldwin, declined to comment on the lawsuit, the delay in operation or the plant's future.
Meriden is dealing with a different situation -- the prospect that NRG, its developer, will file for bankruptcy.
Work stopped on the Meriden plant in May because NRG could not secure financing to pay for construction. Lesa Bader, a company spokeswoman, said NRG attributed the difficulties to the decline in investor confidence due to the California energy crisis and the collapse of the Enron Corporation. This is coupled with an overall downturn in the economy and a decline in the credit ratings of power companies due to a drop in the price of electricity.
"NRG believes that Meriden is a good project and continues to pursue efforts to see that it is built," Ms. Bader said. "We view the current situation as temporary." 
The Meriden City Council recently hired Braith Kelly, an energy consultant, and discussed buying the plant, completing it and collecting the profits from the sale of electricity. The idea drew little support because of the cost, risk and complexity, so officials are now looking to Mr. Kelly to find other ways the city can ensure the plant is completed.
"We are trying to explore what is available to the city to keep the project alive," said Stephen T. Zerio, City Council majority leader and a member of a committee monitoring the plant's progress.
Local officials said they believed NRG will sell the plant. "I think it is only a matter of moments before NRG is officially bankrupt," Mr. Benigni said. "Because the plant is approximately 40 percent built, I do think another buyer will come in and take over the power plant. My concern is for that purchase being sooner rather than later Ms. Bader, the NRG spokeswoman, said the company was working to restructure. Filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy is only one of the options being considered. The plant would be sold if an appropriate offer is made, she added.
Because of these uncertainties, the chairman of Meriden's Finance Committee Chairman, Brian F. Kogut, said he was hesitant to draw up a budget that relied on the tax payment due from NRG next year because of the uncertainties.
Rick Terrill, former chairman of the Meriden Conservation Commission, said he feared the plant will become an eyesore and burden on the city like the abandon factories left from Meriden's heyday as an industrial city.
But besides power plants, no other company or industry that delivers this much tax revenue is looking to move to Milford or Meriden, elected officials said.
"It is tough to bring manufacturing anywhere in the state of Connecticut," said Mr. Lisman, Milford's former mayor. "You don't have the big taxpayers you wish for." 
Mr. Zerio, the Meriden city councilor, pointed to the fact NRG will donate 790 acres of undeveloped land to the city and Berlin, a neighboring town, if the plant is completed. 
There are other advantages to power plants, Mr. Gelston, the siting council chairman, said, in comparison to other industries. They use few city services, bring little additional traffic and do not require hundreds of employees whose children crowd city schools. For example, the Meriden plant if complete will have an estimated 20 employees. Power plants are being considered in other communities such as Middletown and New Britain.
"It is a good industry," Mr. Gelston said.
Milford and Meriden are still deciding on whether this is true.

(George Ruhe for The New York Times); The Milford plant seen from the Stratford side of the Housatonic River. Construction of the plant has stalled. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Southampton Hospital Explores Merger 

BYLINE:  By JULIA C. MEAD

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON 

 BODY:
TO put Southampton Hospital on a firmer financial footing, its directors are talking with the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, and the New York Presbyterian Healthcare System, two of the nation's largest hospital organizations, about joining one of them. 
 Southampton's financial problems have been persistent. In the latest round, it has cut $3.6 million from its budget and has eliminated 49 jobs, about 6 percent of its work force. The latest cuts pale in comparison to $50 million in losses over a period of about three years in the late 1990's at the South Fork's only hospital. 
 Southampton has 168 beds and about 720 employees, making it the South Fork's largest private employer. Since 1996, it has been a partner in the Peconic Health Corporation, along with Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead and Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport.
Southampton is also affiliated with North Shore, a conglomerate of 18 hospitals on Long Island and in New York City, including North Shore University Hospital and the Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Affiliation is a rather loose agreement to share resources like computer software but not clinical services.
As for a merger, Annette Leahy, Southampton's new chief executive, said, "It is premature to say what will happen, but we are optimistic."
Terry Lynam, North Shore's corporate director of public relations, said that the merger talks began too recently to predict whether they would lead to a complete takeover or to a sponsorship, which would give the hospital some local control. A takeover would dissolve Southampton's board and put North Shore in control. Sponsorship would leave the board in place but would permit a greater sharing of North Shore's resources, resulting in more economy-of-scale savings.
"Southampton Hospital is attractive because it would give us a greater presence on eastern Long Island," Mr. Lynam said. Because Southampton has no competitors on the South Fork, it is an attractive target, both for the number of prospective patients in the area and the number of wealthy prospective donors. 
Mr. Lynam added that North Shore was interested in discussing mergers with Central Suffolk and Eastern Long Island, too, but was talking seriously with only Southampton so far. 
"We have a track record for turning around financially troubled hospitals," he said. Staten Island University Hospital's finances have been stabilized since North Shore became its sponsor, he said, and most of its sponsored hospitals operate in the black. The North Shore system reported a $79 million profit last year. 
Five years ago, North Shore and Southampton had discussed a merger but ended up as affiliates when North Shore balked at Southampton's debt. 
New York Presbyterian is even larger than North Shore. Its umbrella covers 35 member hospitals, nursing homes and medical centers in New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut, and it is affiliated with both Columbia and Cornell Universities. 
Myrna Manners, New York Presbyterian's vice president for public affairs, said that officials there "routinely have meetings" with other hospitals to discuss possible mergers. She confirmed that Southampton was one of them but added that "no concrete plans" had been made.
Ms. Leahy, North Shore's chief executive, said the layoffs and other spending cuts would save $3.6 million in this year's $79 million budget. The staff cuts will save $2 million, she said, and other cost-cutting measures, including closing the hospital's coffee shop, would save $1.6 million.
Earlier this month, 25 full-time and 14 part-time employees were laid off, and money for 10 vacant positions was eliminated from the budget. The layoffs include clinical workers in the breast health, cardiac rehabilitation, and pain management centers; a social worker; three lab workers; three medical or surgical staff members; five nursing administrators; and two emergency room employees. 
The 10 eliminated positions included those in the laboratory, radiology department and dialysis center. 
Ms. Leahy said that the budget shortfall stemmed from unexpected factors. She listed the nationwide nursing shortage, which makes the hospital more dependent on temporary employees supplied by agencies, and higher-than-expected costs for malpractice insurance, employee benefits and medical supplies.
Because of its location, the South Fork is a difficult place to recruit workers, she said, so the hospital has had raise some salaries to compete.
"None of this has any connection to the past," she said. "We now we find ourselves in increasingly challenging times. We have to consider something more substantive."
Ms. Leahy insisted the staff reductions would not affect patient care because the laid-off workers' duties would be "re-engineered," meaning that they would be redistributed among remaining employees. "We hope between that and increased revenue we will break even this year," Ms. Leahy said.
Government and civic leaders, concerned over the hospital's financial problems, said they would support a merger. 
Jay Schneiderman, the Town of East Hampton supervisor, said: "This hospital is absolutely critical to this community. I would not have a problem with ownership by a larger system because the hospital must do what it takes to survive."
Ann Kellett, the chairwoman of the town's health-care advisory committee and a former nursing professor at Columbia University, said a merger might be a special benefit for Medicaid recipients, who are now served by too few specialists. "A clinical affiliation with a larger system could attract more" specialists, Ms. Kellett said. "And it could also bring more services, innovative methodologies, quality measurements and continuing education. I can only see benefits in it."
James Needham, a former Southampton Town Board member who had been sharply critical of the hospital's financial problems in the 1990's, said of the latest financial problems: "I'm very upset. Everybody is. After all, this hospital is all we've got between Montauk Point and Stony Brook."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Southampton Hospital is cutting $3.6 million from its budget: eliminating 49 jobs will save $2 million, and closing the coffee shop and other measures will save another $1.6 million. (Doug Kuntz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Lawyers Move On; Power Balance Shifts 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
IN one of the larger recent power shifts among top Long Island law firms, a team of six lawyers have moved their entire corporate litigation and bankruptcy practice from the Island's largest law firm to one of its most high-profiled. 
 "It's a monumental move," said Barry R. Shapiro, who heads the team that moved from Rivkin Radler in Uniondale to Meyer, Suozzi, English & Klein in Mineola. "I can't remember another group with our degree of billings and name recognition that has moved on Long Island." 
 Stephen W. Schlissel, a lawyer at Schlissel, Ostrow, Karabatos, Poepplein, Sender & Fisher in Garden City, said, that moves of this sort may become more common. "There are a number of firms on Long Island that are getting larger, and as they do the practice of moving between firms that exists in places like New York City will occur more and more here." 
Mr. Shapiro said his group generated $3 million in billings last year. Departing with him were Erica Garay, Jill Rosen Nikolaff, Howard B. Kleinberg, Stella Lellos and Robert Howard, along with a paralegal and four secretaries. Ms. Garay, Ms. Nikolaff and Mr. Kleinberg were partners at Rivkin Radler; they plus Mr. Shapiro have been made partners at Meyer, Suozzi.
Laurie J. Bloom, Rivkin Radler's director of marketing and communication, said the departed team's income was actually about $2 million and that it was 15 percent less than in 2001. 
The managing partner at Meyer, Suozzi, Lois Carter Schlissel, who is not related to Stephen Schlissel, said her firm had been speaking with the Shapiro team for "a long time, and it became clear to us two months ago that this is a perfect match."
Their defection of the Shapiro group follows the May 2001 departure of another high-profile Rivkin Radler partner, Arthur Kremer, former chairman of the New York State Assembly Ways and Means Committee. 
Among the well-known partners in the Meyer, Suozzi firm are John V.N. Klein, the former Suffolk county executive; Harold Ickes, former White House deputy chief of staff in the Clinton administration; and Joseph Suozzi, the former Glen Cove mayor and father of the Nassau county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi. 
Jerry Reisman of the firm of Reisman Peirez & Reisman in Garden City said that moves of the magnitude of the Shapiro group's have been occurring among law firms in Manhattan for the last 15 years. "It's relatively new on Long Island because there are few large firms here," he said. 
A week after the Shapiro team moved, William M. Savino, the managing partner of Rivkin Ralder, announced that William Cornachio of Manhasset and Walter J. Gumersell of Lloyd Neck had rejoined his firm as partners, and that Dara A.L. Coope of New Hyde Park had joined as an associate. 
The recent additions brought the firm back up to about 135 lawyers, according to Mr. Savino. Rivkin Radler is by far the largest firm on the Island. Meyer, Suozzi, with 63 lawyers, is among the Island's top five largest firms.
"The move wasn't driven by economics," Mr. Shapiro insisted. "It was driven by a belief that there was a shared vision between us and the people at Meyer, Suozzi about how to grow a law firm, reach out to new clients and give back to the community. Meyer, Suozzi has deep roots on Long Island and wants to grow on Long Island, which is very important to us."
But Mr. Reisman dismissed such talk as nothing but a "public relations statement."
"The purpose of moves is money," he said. "When they say it's not about money, it's about money."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
The Man Who Turned Manhattanville Around

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

DATELINE: PURCHASE 

 BODY:
BEFORE Richard A. Berman's arrival at Manhattanville College here in 1995, the college, with less than $1 million in endowment, was losing more than $3 million a year. Its dorms, designed to hold 1,500 students, were more than half empty. It rarely turned down any applicant. With the college strapped for cash and defaulting on bonds, its buildings were falling apart. 
 Everybody agrees he has turned the college around, and though Mr. Berman did not wave a magic wand, it almost seems as if he did, longtime faculty and staff members say. Now the liberal arts college has an enrollment of 1,470, more than twice the 660 it had in 1995. Its acceptance rate is 55 percent. It has balanced its books, stopped selling its land and is paying back its debts on schedule. And more important to both its faculty and students alike, it has earned a spot among the top tier of northern American colleges ranked by U.S. News & World Report and found its way into at least three college guide books popular among high school students. Tuition at Manhattanville is $20,600 per year; it has increased less than 5 percent each year. 
 "People are constantly talking about how President Berman saved the school," said Vladimir Estiverne, a senior at Manhattanville and the vice president of its student government.
So how did hedo it? Members of his staff say he worked hard, he listened to students and people on his staff, and he knew the economics of higher education.
Mr. Berman, an energetic former management consultant of McKinsey & Company and former executive of New York University Medical Center, did not shrink from what he felt he had to do.
"We needed to save money wherever we could," he said. The first thing he did was to fire about 15 administrative staff members. Then he made everybody who stayed -- from faculty members to maintenance workers -- do more. Professors started to teach eight courses a year instead of six. Building staff workers painted the walls of the new dance studios and the photography labs. 
Mr. Berman, who lives on campus with his wife, Jean, has toiled alongside his employees, often putting in 16-hour days -- from 8 in the morning until midnight -- at the college. He has attended almost every sports event and student play, and he now knows three-quarters of the students by name. "My wife attends a lot of these events, too," he said, "so she can see me more." 
He promised every professor a pay raise of up to 60 percent as soon as the school's fiscal health improved. "That promise was fulfilled," Mr. Berman said. The starting salary for a faculty member, for instance, jumped to about $40,000 from around $25,000. As part of his duties, Mr. Berman sought out companies that could help the college. He went to MasterCard, which has a large campus in Purchase, for its old computers so that the college could build its first computer lab in 1995. He entreated a technology company to install modems and computer networks on campus and a utility company to replace its defunct boilers on credit He wooed Mary Corrarino, a Manhattanville graduate who had been a partner at a large Wall Street law firm, to join the college as its senior vice president, overseeing all nonacademic affairs. 
"Richard called me and asked whether I would consider working for Manhattanville," Ms. Corrarino recalled. "I said, 'Absolutely not.' But four months later, I was working for him." 
To turn around an ailing college is not easy. The market has not been kind to small private colleges without the brand name recognition and large endowment of, say, Williams or Amherst. Almost all experts on the economics of higher education agree that small regional colleges have been losing students to cheaper public institutions for years. Studies show that high school graduates today are less inclined to choose small regional colleges because of family or religious affiliations. The prospective students also tend to demand state-of-the-art facilities -- swanky gyms and fast computers -- that small schools cannot afford.
More than a half-dozen such colleges in the Northeast have shut their doors since 1995, including Notre Dame College in New Hampshire and Bradford College in Massachusetts. 
Manhattanville could have been one of them. The school had sold 150 of its 250 acres of land by 1995 to keep its door open as its enrollment eroded. Because the college lacked a large endowment, its finances are driven by tuition, which pays for 90 percent of operating expenses. In 1994, the faculty, already poorly paid, agreed to take a 6 percent salary decrease to help put a stop to the school's decline.
Now to many faculty and alumni, the appearance of Mr. Berman, who had been hired to search for a president for the school but was hired instead, seems like a miracle.
He has been, above all, a superb salesman. Knowing the importance to increase enrollment, he has traveled to cities like Detroit and Chicago to speak in high schools to extol the chief virtue of a small liberal arts college like Manhattanville: the caring intimacy that fosters growth and learning. He took out radio and newspaper advertisements in urban centers in California and Illinois. He has hired students to place more than 10,000 calls every year to applicants to sell the school. He touts the way the college has transformed inner city teenagers and catapulted a few of them into Yale Medical School, Cornell Law School and the Juilliard School. Backslapping and prone to hugging students and staff members alike, he demonstrated an enthusiasm that has been contagious.
With cash trickling in from gradually increased enrollment, Mr. Berman has installed Internet connections in every dorm, built a computer lab with the latest computers, renovated the gymnasium, converted the library catalog to an electronic database and sent students on trips to Nepal, Senegal and Mexico. 
But he has also made other small changes. The student dining hall serves, in addition to the regular fare of burgers and other sandwiches, sushi and Indian stew. The library stays open until 4 a.m. every day. He has opened a convenience store on campus that sells snacks and daily necessities.
"Look, it's not more expensive to make sushi than greasy food that nobody will eat," he said, giving the confident smile that many said is his trademark. "You just need to listen to the kids."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Richard A. Berman, who became president of Manhattanville College in 1995, in his office. The campus, above. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times, left, and Eddie Hausner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Too Much Spending In the Wrong Places 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re: "How Did Such a Rich State Get So Poor?" (Dec. 22, 2002).
 The problem behind the crumbling finances in Connecticut is not that taxes are too low; the problem is that many unnecessary expenditures have been allowed during the flush times of the past. 
 Connecticut needs a Hoover Commission to examine state government organization and expenditures. If unnecessary expenditures were eliminated, the state could probably abolish its income tax and gain competitive advantage by attracting more companies. 
For example, Connecticut could save substantial sums of money by combining its two separate systems of higher education into one system and eliminating duplicate administrative costs. The mission of the state university could be refocused upon education and millions more saved without harming educational services by eliminating Division I basketball and football teams with their high-priced coaches, and many other expenditures for entertainment provided by big-time sports that are unrelated to higher education. Combining or eliminating unnecessary state expenditures and lowering taxes would do much to invigorate the state's economy. 

DONALD GRUNEWALD
Wilton

The writer is a professor of management at Iona College.

HEADLINE: State Economics On Personal Level 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 After reading this article, I wondered if Fred V. Carstensen, the director of the Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis, lives in the same state I do. 
According to Mr. Carstensen, the state is doing moderately well both regionally and nationally on an economic level. 
 I was laid off from a good-paying job as a graphic designer 17 months ago. I have still not found full-time work in Connecticut. My current unemployment claim will run out soon. Economic analysts and demographic experts may see this as a rich state with budgetary problems. As a highly skilled resident who cannot find a job, I find Connecticut to be a state in economic depression.

JEFFERY BIRD
Branford
