HEADLINE: To Know Which Way the Wind Blows 

BYLINE:  By Adam Begley; Adam Begley is the books editor of The New York Observer.

 BODY:
 GREAT NECK
By Jay Cantor.
703 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $27.95.
 To call Jay Cantor the thinking man's Tom Wolfe is a little unfair to Tom Wolfe, who surely believes, and with some justification, that he's the thinking man's Tom Wolfe. It's also a little unfair to Jay Cantor, who for all I know abhors Wolfe's politics and his fiction as well. Yet the scope of Cantor's ambition in his teeming new novel, "Great Neck"; his avid desire to capture the American scene entire; his crowd of characters, each absorbed in a private drama; certain thrillingly compact episodes that stand out like a prodigy among dull schoolkids; the hankering after abandoned tradition (Cantor is fascinated by the cabala, Wolfe by the Stoics); the stern morality operating just below the surface of the narrative -- all these things, it seems to me, link these two writers, both of whom ardently believe in the power of fiction to bring an American moment to life.
If I were one of Jay Cantor's characters (and it's occurred to me that maybe I am: privileged, half Jewish, shadowed by the Holocaust, guilty about the dark side of America's past) and thought that my Wolfe-Cantor comparison was unfair, I'd indulge in several dozen pages of tortured introspection, a succession of brilliant, obsessive, Freud-haunted scenes staged entirely in the mind's theater. This kind of strenuous broody thinking explains why "Great Neck," though in other respects an impressively economical panorama of two decades in the life of America, from the civil rights era to Vietnam, from nonviolent antiwar protest to the Black Panthers and the Weathermen, stretches to 703 pages and often feels, I'm sorry to say, bloated. 
Can a novel be both economical and bloated? Some writers worry about how to get a character down the stairs and out the door -- not Cantor. He's a minimalist when it comes to stage directions and decor. A few deft touches, and there you are, an earnest Long Island teenage boy named Jesse at a fund-raising party for a civil rights organization, wandering through a Long Island ranch house with "colorful paintings covering the walls" ("painted Cokes and targets") and suddenly standing next to -- Andy Warhol! Two quick sentences is all it takes to fix Andy to the page: "Odd white hair, and the palest skin Jesse had ever seen. He looked smaller than the photos of him, like he might break." But Cantor is definitely a maximalist when it comes to covering emotional ground, especially the spasm of conscience. Can there be another novel in which a character engaged in armed robbery, with shooting and dying going on around her -- the action sketched with taut precision -- stops to ponder the true nature of her guilt? She hasn't, she decides, provided adequate child care for her 2-year-old daughter.
There are more than a dozen characters in "Great Neck" who regularly come in for full head scans; it's as though Cantor required a detailed topographical survey of someone's psyche -- anyone's psyche -- on every other page. The key players, all exhaustively mapped, are six teenagers, four boys and two girls, bound together by a tragedy and its eerie aftermath: the older brother of Laura, one of the girls in the group, is killed by the Klan in Mississippi, where he has gone in 1964 to register black voters. Though dead, Frank apparently continues sending letters to Beth, his girlfriend, the other girl in the group. 
The letters from beyond the grave are not just spooky, they're life-altering, mostly because one of the boys, Billy -- the artist in the group -- convinces the rest that he's in touch with Frank by some extrasensory means (he announces Frank's death a day before anyone could possibly know of it: "He's already dead. . . . I don't know how I know, I just do. They've murdered him and buried him under tons of earth"). Billy also announces that these posthumous letters spell out their mission in life: "We have to, like, keep Frank in our hearts and do acts of justice." He goads them on by creating an instantly popular comic-book series (it soon acquires a huge cult following) in which the six friends are transformed into crusading superheroes. Thus they lead their lives in the shadow of bright, seductive, two-dimensional alter egos engaged in the Zap! Kapow! of cartoon heroics. (You could say that Billy flattens his friends; Cantor, with his ceaseless psychological probing, restores depth and heft.)
Because he was murdered while serving the cause of civil rights, and because he communicates with them after death (or so it seems), Frank connects this bunch of pampered suburban kids to something "much larger than Great Neck." They feel doubly chosen. They're ripe for the late 60's and the turbulent passions of the campus antiwar movement. Cantor threads his gang of six through the maze of the decade's social and political issues (he even cruises New York's avant-garde, pausing to take in S-and-M clubs and the nascent vogue for performance art). All but one of the Great Neck crew is engaged in radical protest against the war; several gradually relinquish their allegiance to nonviolence. Beth graduates from S.D.S. to the Weather Underground -- that is, she embraces violence wholeheartedly and masterminds a series of bombings (all loosely based, like much of this novel, on actual events). Except for her, every member of the group abandons activism in the 70's to pursue more or less mainstream careers. By the early 80's, when the novel ends, their revolutionary ardor has all but died, yet Beth's still burns: though she worries that "guilt, like a sticky syrup, would slow her reflexes," one final flare of action rounds off the narrative. (In Billy's comics, Beth is Ninja B., or Deborah, a k a the Prophet or Athena X, relentless foe of the forces of evil.)
If your brother is killed by the Klan (Cantor makes us intimate with both black and white versions of that particular sorrow), it's a local manifestation of the wider historical tragedy of Jim Crow -- and behind that, the indelible stain of slavery. Alongside these New World horrors lies Europe's monstrous 20th-century equivalent. There are two Holocaust survivors in the novel (one of them Beth's psychoanalyst father, perhaps Cantor's most melancholy creation) and many victims of American racism, including, memorably, a Delta bluesman-turned-preacher who is beaten along with his wife -- while his church burns -- because he has urged his congregation to vote. For the Great Neck gang, man's inhumanity to man begins with Auschwitz and only later encompasses Parchman prison farm; they may have it backward chronologically, but at least the past means something to them. Cantor is adept at summoning history (a rapid glimpse, say, of Malcolm X in Ghana, "admonitory, precise," sipping tea and dispensing homilies in a bar in Accra), and even better at showing historical consciousness at work, claiming its role in the psychic drama along with guilt and lust and petty self-regard and the barter economy of moral reckoning.
If you want to "do acts of justice" in an unjust world, circa 1969, how do you go about it? "Great Neck" provides at least a dozen answers, each one plausible to the character who dreams it up. Laura's boyfriend, a physics prodigy at M.I.T., tripping on acid, whispers to her that he doesn't care if he dies in a demo -- because if I can't help stop them killing Vietnamese, I feel like I'll have to kill myself." Cantor convinces us that you wouldn't need LSD to feel something similar: a student in that torrid climate -- race riots, serial assassination, napalmed villages, the daily body count -- could easily find the role of nonviolent warrior too tame. For Beth, who lumps American imperialism with "the death camps that had nearly killed her father," passive resistance is tantamount to the acquiescence of the "good German." That may sound extreme, but there's a fabulous abundance in "Great Neck" of serious argument about how to combat establishment evil -- and some spectacular demonstrations of how the battle can go awry. (There's also, for my taste, too much reliance on Billy's comic books as a fantasy counterpoint to the daily struggle.)
Cantor's first book, "The Death of Che Guevara" (1983), another huge novel, was a channeling of that revolutionary icon; his second, "KrazyKat" (1988), was a brilliant high modernist riff on the great comic strip -- both books, sadly, are out of print. "Great Neck," a surprising amalgam of its predecessors, is so rich in character and incident that you can't help wishing it a long shelf life and many devoted readers. Overflowing with brainpower -- as though all the minds Cantor investigates were somehow networked and engaged in furious serial processing -- it finds room for heart, too. It is, after all, a novel about friends.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Tim Lane)

HEADLINE: 2 1/2 Cheers for Capitalism 

BYLINE:  By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is the Whitehead fellow at the New America Foundation and the author of "Made in Texas: George W. Bush and the Southern Takeover of American Politics."

 BODY:
 20:21 VISION
Twentieth-Century Lessons
for the Twenty-First Century.
By Bill Emmott.
373 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.
 "THE hunt for humbugs is one of the basic purposes of journalism, the quintessentially paranoid profession," Bill Emmott writes in "20:21 Vision," a provocative and thoughtful survey of global trends at the beginning of the 21st century. Emmott, the editor in chief of The Economist and the author of several previous books, finds plenty of humbugs to hunt.
This is really two books: one about geopolitics, the other about geoeconomics. In the first section, "Peace Challenged," Emmott examines, in succeeding chapters, "American Leadership," "Chinese Ambition," "Japanese Vulnerability," "European Envy" and "Turbulence and Terror." He predicts that "American leadership will persist, and offers a crucial hope to the rest of the world," though he qualifies his prediction by allowing for the possibility of American unilateralism or isolation. 
If a challenge does come to American military primacy, it may come from China. Emmott writes, "It is a mark of the way in which the terror attacks gripped the imagination and concentrated minds that China suddenly seemed a much less important challenger on 12 September than it had just a day or two earlier." According to Emmott, however, "terrorism can be contained, even if it cannot be entirely quelled." For this reason, he argues, "the pundits were right to put China high on their lists of possible challenges, and nothing that happened in the autumn of 2001 changed that." He is particularly concerned about a Chinese-American conflict over Taiwan: "If there is ever a fight between the United States and China, it is likely to arise from what would be the greatest and most fateful miscalculation in the history of mankind."
Adding to the tension in East Asia is what Emmott calls the increasing "vulnerability" of Japan: "A more nationalist government, a more powerful navy and air force, a more visible military presence in the region, even, in the end, a publicly acknowledged program of nuclear research and development: all these must be considered likelihoods for Japan during the first few decades of the 21st century." The crisis triggered by North Korea's acquisition of nuclear weapons, which began after the book went to print, makes Emmott's speculation about proliferation in East Asia look prescient.
Since its founding in the 19th century, The Economist has been identified with free-market liberalism, and it comes as no surprise that the second section of Emmott's book, "Capitalism Questioned," might as well have been titled "Capitalism Defended." But Emmott's defense is a nuanced one.
He points out that many people in the West and around the world, as well as in Marxist-Leninist countries, not only have believed that there was a coherent system called "capitalism" but have despised it in each of its historical forms, from the small, proprietary business to the impersonal, multinational corporation. In successive chapters, Emmott examines the objections that capitalism is (to cite the chapter titles), "Unpopular," "Unstable," "Unequal" and "Unclean." While he leaves no doubts about his own views, his defense of market economics is far more measured than the triumphalist manifestoes that conservatives, libertarians and even some liberals have issued in recent years. To cite one instance: "These are the bleak facts. Inequality between countries has increased rather than diminished, over a long period. . . . And some countries in sub-Saharan Africa have in fact become poorer in absolute terms."
Emmott has little trouble showing that much of the conventional criticism of "globalization" is inspired by sentimentality or bad data. For example, he demonstrates that "the comparison of companies' size to countries' G.D.P. is wholly misleading, not to say economically illiterate. . . . The correct way of comparing companies and national economies would be by comparing value added in both cases. . . . That, though, would make even the biggest companies look puny compared with all but the tiniest economies." 
He is less persuasive, however, when he offers his own formula for economic growth in developing countries. Emmott appears to concede a considerable amount when he writes: "This is not, to repeat, an argument for raw laissez-faire, anything-goes economies or societies. . . . Economic freedom is a broad concept which seems to require a great deal from government if it is to prevail and to work its living-standard-enhancing magic." But he immediately makes it clear that his ideal is still the classical liberal night-watchman state: "Government needs to set a clear, predictable regulatory and macroeconomic climate: protecting property rights, enforcing the law, avoiding inflation and, just as important, not taking all the money for itself." As valuable as this advice is, in all successful capitalist societies government has played a far more active role -- for example, by building expensive infrastructures for transport, energy and sanitation; by using tariff or nontariff barriers or subsidies to foster entire industries; and by subsidizing scientific and technological research and development. 
IN some of his previous books, Emmott criticized what he viewed as exaggerated claims for East Asian versions of capitalism, in which the state played a major role. It seems odd, therefore, that his discussion of economic development is not accompanied by a comparison of the different paths followed by countries that have successfully industrialized. 
Still, one need not share Emmott's version of classical liberalism to appreciate his call in his final chapter for "paranoid optimism." The saving strength of historical liberalism, in thought as well as practice, has been its resistance to totalizing systems -- including totalizing liberal systems. "What the 20th century showed, throughout its span, was that man's ability to take control of economic, social and political forces is severely limited. And the biggest human, economic and even environmental disasters occurred when people came to believe that they had discovered all the answers to the question of what needed to be done." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: BOOK REVIEWS (91%); WRITERS (77%); TRENDS (76%); LITERATURE (75%); TERRORISM (73%); TERRORIST ATTACKS (73%); NUCLEAR WEAPONS (72%); ARMED FORCES (72%); AIR FORCES (67%); MILITARY WEAPONS (67%); LIBERALISM (61%); NUCLEAR SCIENCE (60%) BOOKS AND LITERATURE; REVIEWS 

COMPANY: FARRAR STRAUS & GIROUX INC (58%)

INDUSTRY: SIC2731 BOOKS: PUBLISHING, OR PUBLISHING & PRINTING (58%)

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
Now That You've Asked...

BYLINE:  By NEIL GENZLINGER

 BODY:
WE'VE been surveyed again, and, as usual, we have come out sounding just a bit daft. According to this new survey, we think things are dreadful economically, we think our governor is a misfit, and yet a disturbing number of us are optimistic about the year ahead. Go, as they say, figure.
 The survey, whose results were released Jan. 24, is the work of the PublicMind research center at Fairleigh Dickinson University. The surveyors asked 801 of us questions like, "In the next 12 months do you expect to increase the unpaid balance on your credit card?" From the answers, assorted conclusions were drawn, among them that 93 percent of us did not buy or build a house last year, that even many members of his own party are not terribly comfortable with Governor McGreevey, and that lots of us do not seem to know how to take a decent vacation. 
 On the economic side, many of us feel that we personally and the business climate in general are worse off than a year ago, yet many of us also think that we and it will be better 12 months hence. Perhaps that's simply our way of saying that things couldn't possibly get any more glum than they are now. 
On the other hand, perhaps it's our way of saying that we don't pay much attention to the news. Does the phrase "looming $5 billion state budget deficit" ring a bell?
Polls like this one, while useful in that they give university institutes something to do, tend not to ask quite enough questions; they'll begin an intriguing line of inquiry but stop short of the one question that will allow the survey and those answering it to make sense. Let's close that gap right now. First, a question the folks at PublicMind did ask, then the question they should have asked next:
1. Do you think that a year from now you (and your family living there) will be better off financially, or worse? (Results: better, 48 percent; same, 20 percent; worse, 22 percent.)
1a. Do you think that within the next 12 months red oaks, New Jersey's state trees, will begin sprouting $20 gold pieces instead of acorns?
2. In the next 12 months do you expect to visit an Atlantic City casino? (Results: yes, 28 percent; no, 66 percent.)
2a. In the next 12 months do you expect to try to tunnel into the vault of an Atlantic City casino? 
3. In the past year did you go away on vacation for a week or more? (Results: yes, 49 percent; no, 51 percent.)
3a. In the past year were you ordered to take a permanent vacation by your now-bankrupt employer?
4. In the next 12 months do you expect to buy or lease a car? (Yes, 21 percent; no, 75 percent.)
4a. In the next 12 months do you expect to buy or lease the "Talking Pedometer," which came advertised in this month's Macy's bill? This apparently is a device that talks to you while you run, walk or jog. Does the idea of having an electronic voice hound you while you're exercising ("Move it, thunder thighs!") appeal to you? 
4b. Do you expect to be doing a lot more running, walking or jogging in the next 12 months because you can't afford gas, your car will have been repossessed and/or the roads won't be safe to drive on because the state doesn't have enough money to fill the pot holes?
4c. Were you able to pay this month's Macy's bill?
5. Do you think Governor McGreevey's policies have helped or hurt the New Jersey economy? Would that be somewhat or a lot? (Results: helped a lot, 4 percent; helped somewhat, 16 percent; hurt somewhat, 23 percent; hurt a lot, 18 percent.)
5a. If your name is McGreevey, do you think that a few years from now you will be looking for work?
6. In the past year did you purchase stocks or other types of investments outside your pension plan? (Result: yes, 28 percent; no, 71 percent.)
6a. Speaking specifically to the 28 percent: What are you, nuts?
7. In the next 12 months do you expect to buy a computer? (Results: yes, 21 percent; no, 75 percent.)
7a. In the next 12 months do you expect to boil your computer in a soup pot along with a few potatoes and maybe some red acorns?
8. In the next 12 months do you expect to purchase an airline ticket for a pleasure trip? (Results: yes, 44 percent; no, 52 percent.)
8a. If yes, will this be a one-way ticket?

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Is McGreevey Squeezing Until Everyone Yells 'Taxes'?

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
They come out of the governor's office shaking their heads, sputtering predictions of apocalypse, insisting that it can't be true. 
And at some point -- after they have gone through those stages of grief, denial, anger -- maybe they pick up a phone and get to work, doing precisely what Governor McGreevey hopes they'll do: start demanding higher taxes to make the pain go away.
 Mr. McGreevey has been warning for some time that he has to find a way to close a deficit of more than $5 billion in the budget. But rather than dropping the bomb about who will suffer cuts -- the mayors, the schools, the colleges -- when he delivers his budget address on Tuesday, Mr. McGreevey has been skillfully dribbling out the bad news piecemeal to the various interest groups who can be counted on to scream the loudest. 
 He told the public employees that there would be "universal pain and layoffs." He told the four-year public colleges and the universities that they would have to eat a 10 percent cut in their state allotment, on top of last year's cut. On Wednesday, the governor, in effect, told 16,000 low-income elderly residents that they would have to pay more for their state-subsidized prescriptions. And just to make sure the message got home, he told the drug companies, New Jersey's high-tech pride and joy, the same thing.
Is he just being nice, breaking the news personally, like a solicitous doctor? Or is there a plan at work here?
Thirteen years ago, another Jim in the governor's office, also a Democrat, was faced with a similar problem. Jim Florio's deficit was only $500 million ($688 million today when adjusted for inflation) compared with Jim McGreevey's $5 billion. In what has since become a cautionary tale that grandparents recite to budding politicians from one end of the state to the other, Mr. Florio seized the deficit by the horns along with any number of other pressing problems facing the state after eight years of Republican neglect, wrapped them all up in a $2.8 billion tax increase. He rammed it through the Legislature, and then saw his own career and those of many other Democrats thrown into the outer darkness by the fury that followed.
"We live in a state with a funny media environment, where it is difficult for even a governor to explain himself," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University. "Whether Florio did a good job or not, the citizens simply didn't get it."
While Dr. Rebovich was writing columns in The Trentonian praising Mr. Florio's courage in trying to solve the state's fiscal problems in a single bold gesture, the Republicans sharpened their knives, and Mr. Florio's fate was sealed.
"For better or worse, the failure of his tax policy was largely attributable to a communications failure," Dr. Rebovich said, "and whatever Jim McGreevey has up his sleeve, he's doing a darn good job of communicating."
Governor McGreevey has already boxed himself in on tax increases since he declared on any number of occasions that the three biggest revenue producers -- income taxes, sales taxes and corporate business taxes -- were out of bounds for increases. 
Yet members of his party leadership have begun talking about a surtax on the wealthy, just as Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, a Republican who faces a much smaller deficit, has discussed an income tax surcharge on incomes exceeding $1 million. 
New Jersey Democrats, being Democrats, are apparently talking about putting the surcharge on the income of working stiffs earning as little as $200,000 or even $150,000.
So suppose the pressure for a tax increase to offset the cuts that Mr. McGreevey has spent the last few days describing in such gory detail should come from the grass roots? 
Suppose the college presidents and the transportation interests and the public employee unions and the 16,000 elderly prescription users were to pick up their phones and declare that the money to reduce the size of the cuts had to be raised somewhere else?
"I think he's laying the groundwork so that there might be a groundswell of support for a large revenue- raising measure," Dr. Rebovich said. "I don't think he's going to come out and say, 'Hey, I talked to the interest groups and they want me to raise taxes on the wealthy.' I think he is going to sit back and see who goes to editorial writers, who starts to hold rallies, who starts meeting with their legislative members. Then he can go to the Legislature and say, 'The people are demanding this!"'

HEADLINE: Back From the Edge 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON 

 BODY:
AFTER five years of study, a five-month moratorium on shoreline construction and a string of often-contentious public hearings, the Town of Southampton appears near to banning new bulkheads, steel walls, seawalls, rock revetments and other hardened erosion-control structures along its fabled ocean shores.
 The nearly total prohibition on shoreline armoring, a landmark step that would formally change longstanding policies of coastal management and property rights, is part of a larger scheme for a measured and orderly retreat from the coast backed by environmental groups and gaining support among New York State agencies and the Army Corps of Engineers, which has jurisdiction over the country's navigable waters and seashores. 
"We are going to severely restrict people from putting hardened structures in front of their homes," said Steven Kenny, the Southampton town councilman who introduced the proposal. "As part of the generally accepted coastal policy of strategic retreat, we are going to get homes as far back from the dunes and oceanfront as possible."
 The measure could become law in the town as early as March. But local property owners with deep pockets have mounted a determined effort to hold their ground, which is valued at hundreds of dollars per square foot, and an initial push to hasten their retreat has weakened even as the anti-armoring effort has advanced. 
 Backers of the Southampton move, which would be carried out in amendments to the town's Coastal Erosion Hazard Law, say a ban on shore hardening is necessary to preserve the town's Atlantic beaches, regarded by some as among the finest in the world.
 They said that in cases where beaches vanish and water reaches armoring, the public right of use and passage below mean high tide, guaranteed by law, is taken away. A colonial patent also grants town trustees an easement above the high-tide line.
 "In an eroding area, if you have a hardened structure, over time you will actually have theft," said Carolyn Zenk, a Southampton town councilwoman and an environmental lawyer who supports the measure.
 Areas affected by the proposed amendments would include ocean shorelines in the hamlets of Water Mill, Bridgehampton and Sagaponack and in unincorporated areas on the Westhampton barrier island. Shorefront property within incorporated villages, including Southampton, Quogue, Westhampton Beach and West Hampton Dunes, would not be restricted. 
 The amendments would put Southampton in the forefront of towns, cities and resort communities along the East Coast in setting policies that prevent shorefront property owners from throwing up walls against the sea. Many coastal experts say these structures, while protecting private property, end up obliterating beaches and causing erosion in adjoining areas.
 "We've learned our lesson -- they are a disaster," Ms. Zenk said. 
 Existing armoring would be allowed to remain, but could not be rebuilt if -- or when -- it is destroyed by storm or a rising sea level. The only exception would be for one type of temporary structure, long tubes filled with sand, that the town would permit for a maximum of nine months for emergency protection or while buildings are repaired and/or relocated farther from shore. 
 The tubing could not exceed six feet in height and would be intended to get a homeowner through one winter storm season only, after which the tubes would be cut open to release the sand. Owners would also be strongly encouraged and given incentives to move their homesback. 
 Owners of oceanfront homes and properties in Southampton seemed to be taking all this in stride. But they are vigorously contesting a second part of the amendments that would increase home setbacks from 100 feet to 150 feet behind dunes and in other ways regulate the use of their land. 
 They said the additional amendments trampled on their private property rights and in many cases would leave owners with too little room to rebuild or relocate if homes were damaged, destroyed or threatened by storm erosion. The amendments would expand regulation under the coastal erosion hazard law to areas inland of the dune and also restrict the clearing of natural vegetation.
 The owners also take offense at suggestions that they imperil the shore.
 "It's shockingly undemocratic," said John Bennett, a lawyer in Southampton for a group of about 15 oceanfront property owners. "These people are wonderful stewards of their land. You see them planting dune grass and putting up snow fences and building up the dunes. They are the true stakeholders. The town board members who are pushing this just don't get the East End culture." 
 The owners' lawyers and coastal experts say there is nothing in the town's five-year study of its coastlines that suggests increased setbacks would have any impact on coastal erosion. Indeed, the amendments have given new momentum to a simmering campaign to create a new Village of Dune Hampton out of a seven-mile-long oceanfront area from the eastern boundary of the Village of Southampton to the East Hampton town line. Such a village, like the others in the town, could impose its own shoreline regulations. 
 "We are looking to control our destiny in our little special area," said Stuart D. Baker, a member of the incorporation committee and an oceanfront owner, who said the committee would pursue incorporation regardless of what the town did. 
 Laura Hildreth, a consultant to the committee, said the town board had alienated itself from the owners. "They just don't trust the town board anymore because of the way that they have acted and the attitudes they have shown," she said. "They seem not to be advocates, but more the adversaries of the people on the beach."
 But to the surprise of supporters, the owners seem far less focused on the armoring ban, a signal of a general acceptance of the notion that private shore-hardening projects may be a thing of the past.
 "If this were just about hardened structures and clearing restrictions, the law would have passed already," Mr. Bennett said.
 Steven Kenny, the town coun-cilman who with Ms. Zenk advanced the amendments, said he made changes to provide incentives for owners to move homes farther from the beach and to ease proposed restrictions on setbacks on the inland side of properties. The changes will also make it easier for owners to rebuild homes.
 "We wanted to recognize property owners' pre-existing rights along the coastline," said Mr. Kenny, a professor of economics at Suffolk County Community College.
 Mr. Kenny, who spent summers on the ocean in what is now the highly developed Village of West Hampton Dunes while growing up in Freeport and Bay Shore, said that what he described as the suburbanization of ocean shore areas detracted from the town's heritage and natural beauty. "We are beginning to see lawns and tennis courts," he said. "There has been a trend in these beach areas of these looming structures right on the property line."
 Mr. Bennett, who lives and practices in Southampton, sees a different picture. "I have European clients who say what's so wonderful is that the beach is so lightly developed," he said.
 Mr. Kenny, a resident of Remsenburg since the mid-1970's, said he hoped for a meeting of the minds. "This is one of those classic public policy issues where the private interest comes into conflict with the public interest," he said. "And at the end of the day I am hoping that the property owners can share in preserving the natural beauty of the coastline."
 Mr. Kenny and Ms. Zenk, who is from Hampton Bays, now appear to have the support of the Town Board's swing vote, Dennis A. Suskind, a Democrat from Bridgehampton. Of the three, Mr. Suskind, a retired general partner in Goldman Sachs who lives in an oceanfront area, is the most connected to the affected property owners.
 In July, Mr. Suskind reluctantly joined the other Democrats, Mr. Kenny and Ms. Zenk, in approving a five-month moratorium on new construction in oceanfront areas within the town, provided it was not extended. The moratorium expired late last month.
 The board's two Republicans -- the town supervisor, Patrick Heaney, and Councilwoman Linda Kabot -- opposed the moratorium.
 Now Mr. Suskind is again in the swing position. After initially opposing the proposed amendments to the Coastal Erosion Hazard Law as "a little heavy on property rights," he said last week that the changes offered by Mr. Kenny had won his support.
 "As it is written now, except for little touch-ups, it accomplishes its goal of setting the stage for maintenance of our beaches as well as protecting the rights of people who built homes there over the last 50 years before we understood what was happening to the beaches," he said. 
 Mr. Suskind said he "basically embraced" coastal retreat. "On the other hand, you don't have to retreat to Ronkonkoma," he added. 
 Donna Giancontieri, an executive assistant to Mr. Heaney, said Mr. Heaney wanted to review the most recent changes in the amendments before commenting. Ms. Kabot did not return calls seeking comment.
 The backers have been warned that a fourth vote may be necessary. Mr. Bennett and other lawyers contend that a super-majority is needed because the amendments, though couched within the Coastal Erosion Hazard Law, amounted to zoning changes. Mr. Bennett said that when enough owners protested such a change, as he said they had, state law required the super-majority.
 Mr. Kenny said he believed he would get the fourth vote. But backers acknowledged that the amendments, even in softened form, were unwelcome among owners. "There are some people, I am sure, who would like this to go away forever," Ms. Zenk said. 
 Mr. Suskind said he had been repeatedly buttonholed. "People I have known for many years and some people I don't know have come to see me and said they don't want us to do anything," he said. "They say they will protect the beaches because they care about them. I believe them, but I don't think the town can just depend on 300 people doing what they think is right. And you also don't know who they are going to sell their house to."
 Six states -- Maine, Rhode Island, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas and Oregon -- have rules against armoring shorelines. But Orin Pilkey, a professor emeritus of earth and ocean sciences at Duke University in Durham, N.C., said exceptions made many of the restrictions ineffective.
 "Southampton is a community that has been trying to get to the bottom of this problem for many years," said Dr. Pilkey, an opponent of hardened structures. "I'm impressed with their toughness."
 Dr. Pilkey said sea level rise made retreat from the ocean shore inevitable over the next several generations. "We could either retreat in a planned and strategic fashion, or in tactical disarray in response to natural disasters," he said. "Of course, we can build massive walls that will hold the shoreline in place for a longer time, but then you won't have a beach." 
 Dr. Pilkey said he was not surprised that oceanfront owners in Southampton were paying more attention to setback requirements than a ban on armoring. "People on the shoreline in general are very shortsighted," he said. "The setback requirement is an obvious limitation to development. They won't get quite the same view of the sea, so that's an immediate problem." 
 Robert DeLuca, president of the Group for the South Fork, an environmental and planning organization, said the ban on armoring was the most meaningful part of the amendments. "From our standpoint, that's the primary objective," he said. "It is the strategy of getting out of the way of the ocean as opposed to standing in its way." 
 But Jay Tanski, a coastal geologist at New York Sea Grant who has studied South Shore erosion, questioned a blanket ban on hardened structures. "As a rule, prohibitions against any particular form of erosion control is not necessarily the best way to go," he said. "The decision should be made on a case-by-case basis. In some cases that might mean you would allow a bulkhead."
 Mr. Tanski said that property owners' legal challenges to local restrictions left judges to manage shorelines. "And a judge probably has a lot less of an understanding of what's happening on the shoreline than a lot of the other people involved," he said.
 Wayne D. Bruyn, a lawyer in Southampton for several oceanfront property owners, said future challenges to the armoring prohibition were probable. "The time will come when there are significant erosion issues, and the review of this statute, if it gets adopted, will be right in the forefront," he said.
 Mr. Bruyn argued that existing town regulations already effectively prohibited hardened structure on the beach. He said the amendments would take away owners' rights to apply to the town's zoning board of appeals for variances.
 The amendments now under consideration had their roots in the winter of 1998, when a series of punishing northeasters tore away ocean shores east of Southampton Village in an area where owners had sued the town for permission to erect steel bulkheads.
 One owner, the real estate magnate William Rudin, had erected a cofferdam that jutted into the sea, blocking public passage along the shore. Prior to the 1998 storms, Mr. Rudin replaced the cofferdam with a 20-foot-high embankment of sand tubes to protect his $1.6 million home. The town agreed to the structure as an alternative to a steel bulkhead. 
 In January 1998, the structure, whose cost Mr. Rudin declined to reveal but which was locally estimated to have cost more than $1 million, was exposed by waves and collapsed. Mr. Rudin's house was damaged beyond repair and the remains of the exposed structure and the house became a spectacle.
 "This really strange, bizarre structure sat on the beach sort of like something from outer space, and visible for miles," said Ms. Zenk, who cited the event as her reason for running for the town board. Mr. Bruyn, a lawyer for Mr. Rudin, said Mr. Rudin now planned to build a new home.
 The sand has now returned to the shoreline area where the Rudin house stood, people familiar with the area said.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1849 words

HEADLINE: A Glimpse At the Bench From the Inside 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: SOMERVILLE 

 BODY:
BARRY T. ALBIN was a bit taken aback when his 5-year-old son looked up from playing with his robots the other day and told his father, "With great power, comes great responsibility."
 At first, he thought his son, Gerald, was a genius, having perfectly crystallized the thoughts that had been weighing on the mind of the newest member of the state Supreme Court these last few months. Then he realized the boy was simply quoting from his new favorite movie, "Spiderman." 
 So maybe the full meaning of his position as one of seven members of the highest court in the state has not sunk in with his young son, but it has not been lost on Mr. Albin, who has spent much of his career taking the side of the underdog, never dreaming he would be expected to make decisions that would affect the entire state -- and sometimes beyond. 
In a rarely granted interview by a sitting member of the state Supreme Court, Mr. Albin last week gave an insider's look at what it takes to get appointed to the bench, the behind-the-scenes decision-making process of the state's highest court, and the thinking and personality of its newest member. 
Mr. Albin, who is originally from the Bayside section of Queens, is not the typical Supreme Court justice -- most of whom spend years in public service, either in the state attorney general's office or sitting on lower benches before being named to the highest court in the state. InsteadMr. Albin spent his last 20 years in private practice as a partner at the renowned Woodbridge firm of Wilentz, Golman & Spitzer. There he handled some of the toughest criminal and civil rights cases, often against the very public servants who might have aspired to a seat on the Supreme Court. 
And over those same 20 years, he became the favored son of the firm's titular head, Warren Wilentz, and developed a tight bond with James E. McGreevey, crossing paths in 1982 at the Middlesex County prosecutors office, where Mr. Albin was just leaving as the future governor was arriving. In the intervening years Mr. Albin and Mr. McGreevey became close allies, especially after Mr. McGreevey was elected mayor of Woodbridge. 
"We instantly became friends, and that friendship grew and evolved over the years," said Mr. Albin. "From the earliest days, he was a hard-working, hard-driving person who had as a primary goal public service and doing something good with it. And I had a similar motivation."
While he described himself as "never a politically overt person," Mr. Albin was a generous contributor to Mr. McGreevey's various campaigns, dating to the governor's successful run for state Senate in 1993. When it came time for the governor to make his first pick for the Supreme Court, the 51-year-old lawyer was at the top of the list. Mr. Albin declined to speculate on how much his personal connections to the governor played into his selection except to say that "a governor doesn't put someone on the Supreme Court unless he or she thinks that person has the legal ability, intellectual acumen, experience and judgment."
Others in the state's legal community had predicted the selection.
"I knew he had a close relationship with Jim McGreevey and that he thought highly of him, but regardless of who the governor was, Barry would be on anyone's short list for the Supreme Court," said Alan Zegas, a criminal lawyer from Chatham. "He's one of the finest trial attorneys I've ever met in my life anywhere." 
Now Mr. Albin finds himself seated beside six justices appointed by Gov. Christie Whitman. As a Democrat replacing Justice Gary Stein, a Republican who is retiring, Mr. Albin tipped the political balance on the bench, which now consists of four Democrats, two Republicans and one independent. With Justice James Coleman reaching the mandatory retirement age of 70 later this year, there has been some pressure on the governor to replace him with a Republican. While acknowledging that his party choice reflects his value system, Mr. Albin insisted that one's party affiliation has no bearing on the Supreme Court.
"The politics of party play no role whatsoever in the discussions of the court," he said. "There's no political partisanship, no political labels are tossed around. We are interpreting the Constitution and do not decide cases along a political construct."
Just how they do make their decisions is a puzzle to the general population, and the desire to demystify the process was one reason Mr. Albin agreed to be interviewed. 
"If people could look into the conference room, I think they'd be very proud of how dedicated these justices are," he said. "I sometimes wonder how we are able to dispose of so many matters, that seven people could be so productive in the course of a day."
Thinking this would be a "life style change for the better," Mr. Albin said he has been most surprised by the volume of work involved. Rather than spending more time with his wife, Inna, and his two sons, Gerald and Daniel, 3, Mr. Albin -- the self-described "rookie on the bench" -- is putting in more time than ever poring over the law books. 
The court sits for two days every other week from September through May, hearing oral arguments on a total of about 150 cases a year -- or about 10 percent of the cases the judges are petitioned to hear. In weighing the merits of hearing a case, Mr. Albin said the judges apply two standards: if the case raises an issue of paramount public importance, or if it should be decided in the interest of justice.
In addition to reviewing the petitions and hearing cases, the court also handles any case that had a dissenting vote at the appellate level, all death penalty cases, all the administrative rules governing the legal profession in the state, and about 1,500 motions from the lower courts each year. 
The 1,500 petitions of certification are divided among the seven judges, who meet every other week in conference to discuss which cases they will take and to debate the cases they heard the previous week. The process is very democratic, Mr. Albin said, with each justice getting a chance to go first in presenting his or her opinion.
Once a cases is decided, the chief justice assigns the judge who will write the majority opinion, as well as who will write the dissenting opinion if it is a split vote. As it is the job of each judge to persuade fellow justices, Mr. Albin said the discussions are intense, but always collegial.
"I've never witnessed a single word uttered in anger," Mr. Albin said. 
Depending on the complexity of the case, it can take the justices from one to six months to issue an opinion. Since joining the bench in late September, Mr. Albin has written one opinion -- as the lone dissenter on a case of a man denied admission to a pre-trial intervention program based on previous arrests. In his opinion, Mr. Albin argued that the prior charges were either unsubstantiated or dismissed, and therefore should not be a factor in determining eligibility in the pre-trial program. 
Darren Gelber, a partner at the Wilentz firm, was not surprised by his former colleague's position.
"The first opinion he offered was a dissent," Mr. Gelber said. "That should tell you something about him.. 
Another member of the firm, Blair Zwillman, pointed to the role played by Mr. Albin -- on the court only about two weeks -- in the widely followed debate over the state Democratic Party's 11th-hour move to replace Robert G. Torricelli with Frank R. Lautenberg in last fall's Senate campaign .
"He's not taking a back seat to anybody," said Mr. Zwillman. "In the Lautenberg case, he took a leading role in the questioning. He's not timid and he's not intimidated."
Mr. Albin gained a reputation in his years in the courtroom as a tough adversary. In fact, he was asked to join the Wilentz firm after beating Warren Wilentz in an arson case while serving as an assistant prosecutor in Middlesex County.
"I was 28 years old, and Warren was one of the majestic figures of the law," said Mr. Albin, a graduate of Rutgers University and Cornell Law School. "I worked like the devil to prepare for that case, knowing I had to make up for what I lacked in experience with hard work.".
After joining the firm, Mr. Albin was taken under the wing of Mr. Wilentz, the brother of Robert Wilentz, a former Supreme Court Chief Justice, and son of the firm's founder, former Attorney General David Wilentz, who prosecuted Bruno Hauptmann in the Lindbergh baby kidnapping case. Today, Mr. Albin calls Mr. Wilentz his "best friend, mentor and father figure." 
He took it particularly hard when Mr. Wilentz was paralyzed in an automobile collision last December. Despite his demanding court schedule, Mr. Albin has spent a good deal of time at the bedside of his 79-year-old mentor, who is being treated at the Kessler Institute in West Orange. His own father, Gerald Albin, died in 1980, just months after Mr. Albin met Mr. Wilentz.
Mr. Albin says his interest in public service was awakened when he was 8 years old and John F. Kennedy was president, and was further shaped by the working-class neighborhood in which he grew up in Queens and by helping his father in the pressroom of The New York Times. His empathy for the underdog developed in his years as an assistant prosecutor and as a criminal defense lawyer.
"I've had paraded before me the entire spectrum of human folly," said Mr. Albin. "People are frail, they have weaknesses and foibles. All this is part of the human condition. When you are exposed to so many, you tend to become less judgmental."
The highlight of his career as a defense attorney came in 1998, when he represented a doctor from Cyprus who had died after being shot by the police in Mount Vernon, New York, then taken to Mount Vernon Hospital. Mr. Albin spent six years living with both a brutality case against the Mount Vernon Police Department and a negligence case against the hospital. During the three days of jury deliberation, Mr. Albin admits the thought crossed his mind that "I might have brought the firm into an economically bad situation." But when the jury came back with guilty verdicts and awarded the family $17.5 million -- one of the largest in a federal civil rights case -- his self-doubt disappeared.
An avid reader of history and a born storyteller with strong opinions, Mr. Albin has had to watch what he says and with whom he talks with since joining the Supreme Court. 
"I've had to become a very boring, uninteresting person, even in expressing my personal opinion," said Mr. Albin, who, for instance, would not discuss his views on the death penalty or Roe v. Wade. "I have to be careful that people don't think I'd prejudge some issue that might come before the court."
While he does not view his service on the Supreme Court as a mandate to impose his values on the rest of the world, Mr. Albin does see it as a chance to shape the future.
"This job permits me to address the great legal issues that are confounding the law and society," he said. "I have the unique opportunity of being able to have an extraordinary impact on the development of the law. How many people have that opportunity?"

HEADLINE: On the Street, Looking for Work 

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: PALISADES PARK 

 BODY:
THEY gather along East Columbia Avenue near Route 46 some of them even before the warming sun comes up -- standing in doorways and in front of stores on these frigid, gray mornings, waiting for contractors to pick them up and take them to jobs in construction, painting or, when the weather dictates, shoveling snow. In the other months they can be found cutting grass or blowing leaves. 
 Eric Carreto, a 22-year-old Guatemalan, is one of thousands of day laborers in the state -- mostly Hispanic men in baseball caps or watch caps pulled down over their ears who emerge from crowded apartments every morning and gather at such places as Morris Street in Morristown or Warren and Blackwell Streets in Dover or Throckmorton Street in Freehold. 
 "I come by walking, by bus," Mr. Carreto, who fled the poverty and civil strife of Guatemala, explained in Morristown one recent morning. "I come for a better life." 
No one can say with any certainty how many there actually are. Barrie A. Peterson, associate director of the Institute on Work at Seton Hall University, who is one of the authors of a 2000 study on immigrant workers in New Jersey, estimated that of the 8 to 12 million undocumented people in the United States, about 400,000 of them live in New Jersey. Of that number, Mr. Peterson said, about 100,000 could be day laborers, "although this is a really wild guess."
In a country of immigrants, the sight of impoverished groups of men arouses sympathy in those who recall the plight of their own parents and grandparents. But in a landscape dotted with million-dollar homes, luxury cars and teenagers roaming upscale malls with cellular phones in hand, they also arouse anger and resentment. As recently as two years ago, two Mexican day workers who were picked up in Farmingville, on Long Island, by two men posing as contractors were driven to an abandoned factory and attacked with construction tools and a knife. 
More common, however, are complaints by merchants that the laborers block their doorways and intimidate customers. Residents say the men often litter and relieve themselves on their property.
"If you drive up in a pickup truck and you're surrounded by three dozen guys yelling, 'Me work! Me work! Me work!' -- a lot of people don't like that," said Howard J. Lewis, who owns Moore Hardware and Industrial Supply in Morristown. 
Mistrust on All Sides
For their part, local governments and police departments say there is little they can do, noting that anti-loitering ordinances have been struck down in case after case. Still there is a measure of mistrust and resentment on all sides. 
"Sometimes the police go around and stare you down and make you feel bad because you know they're making you feel little or small," said Santos Ruiz, a 20 -year-old Guatemalan who lives in Palisades Park.
To Daniel J. Tichenor, an assistant professor of political science at Rutgers, the hostility displayed toward this latest wave of immigrants is not surprising. 
"If you look at public opinion polls and editorials over the years, I think it's fair to say over the long haul Americans have always celebrated their immigrant past but have been ambivalent about the immigrant present and future." said Professor Tichenor, who wrote "Dividing Lines: The Politics of Immigration Control in America" (Princeton University Press, $22.95).
Moreover, since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, some polls show a decline of whatever sympathy for immigrants or support for mass immigration that once existed. 
In other regions of the country, some municipalities and counties have managed to set up alternate locations -- separate areas and hiring halls in buildings or trailers -- where workers and contractors can gather without causing congestion and where English courses, labor counseling and health services are also available. But many opponents have questioned the legality of the halls, since they would attract undocumented workers as well as legal immigrants. 
Still, Pablo Alvarado, national coordinator of the National Day Laborer Organizing Network, based in Los Angeles, said sweeps of street corners by the Immigration and Naturalization Service were not the answer to a community's dilemma. 
"This is not an issue of immigration," Mr. Alvarado said. "This is an issue of public health and public safety."
In Nassau County, on Long Island, the executive Thomas R. Suozzi, said he felt that way when as mayor of Glen Cove he opened an indoor hiring hall for day laborers, the first on Long Island.
"The people in our community are not against new immigrants coming into the community," Mr. Suozzi said. "In fact, my father was an immigrant, and many in Glen Cove were immigrant families. What people are against are people who flout the laws of the community." 
Efforts in New Jersey to create similar sites have been spotty at best. Morristown has been debating the subject for several years. Dover's attempt has fallen through at least temporarily. Freehold has reluctantly provided a small area near its train station lot but little else. And Bergenfield has offered an area behind Borough Hall where men seeking workcan congregate. A Bergen County task force, commissioned to look for a site to get day laborers off the streets of Palisades Park, failed to do so in the mid-1990's, although the new county executive has indicated that he wanted to resume the search. 
Before 1990, Palisades Park -- a one-square-mile enclave of 18,000 people -- was rooted in a blue-collar ethos that was basically Italian American. But from 1990 to 2000, the population increased 17.5 percent, primarily though an influx of Koreans and Hispanics that gave rise to cultural stresses that the town has yet to resolve.
More than that, the surge of immigrants here reflects the larger picture in New Jersey, where the foreign-born population rose 53 percent from 1990 to 2000 and the number from Latin America doubled, from 324,875 to 634,084 -- making them the largest immigrant group in the state.
Santos Ruiz came to Palisades Park four years ago from a section of Guatemala where, he said, "the military would just kill and nobody knowing why they killed." Today he lives in an apartment here with three brothers, and he sends home a portion of his pay.
"I came here to work," Mr. Ruiz said through an interpreter at at the Palisades Park Library, where he was taking a class to learn English. "And then I send money back to my family, and that's how they can kind of stabilize their lives." 
Mr. Carreto, speaking at the offices of an advocacy group in Morristown called Wind of the Spirit where he, too, takes English language courses, said he showed up on Morris Street in Morristown five and six days a week for a year seeking work, but not long ago found a permanent job as a bus boy.
"I did painting, landscaping, carpentry, and roofing," Mr. Carreto said. "Sometimes I would stand two and three hours. If you go early, you find job. If you go late, you no find jobs." He added, "Better working in restaurant than on corner."
Valerie Massaro, a Leonia resident who organized an English class for day laborers here, said: "Many will work for three months for this company and then go on the street again. Some of them have had the same job for years."
Of course, picking up odd jobs presents other problems. Angel Patino, an organizer at the Wind of the Spirit Immigrant Resource Center in Morristown said workers regularly came in to complain of being cheated of wages. 
"We tell the day laborers to keep records," said Mr. Patino.
But this involves getting the name of the employer, plus an address or a phone number, which contractors are often reluctant to give.
"These people are in a desperate situation," he said of the workers. "They need some money to pay the rent and buy food. So they accept these conditions."
According to Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Labor, said his agency received about 12,000 such complaints a year. But Mr. Smith said he could not estimate how many of these came from day laborers because the department does break down its statistics that way. Nor, for that matter, does it have the jurisdiction to check workers' immigration status.
"The federal government has reserved that right for itself," he said. "When we get into these investigations, our first concern is basically to recover the money due to the worker."
And when on a dangerous job, the workers are usually on their own. A laborer who fell from a ladder and seriously injured was dropped off by his employer at the side of a road on the outskirts of Morristown.
"He didn't even bring him inside the town," said Diana Mejia, a co-founder and executive director of Wind of the Spirit. "Somebody called me and we went to bring him to the hospital."
Mr. Peterson of the Institute on Work said that contrary to the accepted wisdom, even illegal immigrants benefited the economy. The study he helped to write, "Immigrant Workers in New Jersey: A Preliminary Assessment of Available Statistics, Issues and Policy Options," found that half of the state's undocumented workers paid millions of dollars into Social Security and unemployment insurance, even though they never get the benefits.
"They are making the prices of restaurant meals and landscaping services and light manufacturing less for everyone," Mr. Peterson said. "And we're exploiting them because their pay is pretty low and the employers in fact are not even paying them and when they do, there is very little likelihood unemployment insurance or workers compensation is being taken care of." 
'There've Been Complaints'
Mayor Sanford Farber of Palisades Park, while allowing that he appreciated the work ethic of day laborers and sympathized with their plight, said he was also the recipient of many complaints from residents.
"There've been complaints from parents saying my daughter and their friends had suggestive remarks made to them by these people standing in front of the buildings," Mayor Farber said. And he added, "I myself have observed people urinating on people's lawns."
One recent morning, almost 300 men, by one count, lined Columbia Avenue and Broad Avenue, the main thoroughfares here. 
"We're a very small town," he said. "It makes the town look very, very bad to have several hundred people standing on the streets."
By about 1992, day laborers became a visible presence in Palisades Park. As a feeder road for Route 46, Columbia Avenue was a convenient spot for the workers and contractors to hook up. In addition, it is accessible to workers who live in surrounding towns like Cliffside Park, Ridgefield, Fairview and Leonia as well as northern tier towns of Hudson County. 
In January 1993, the police began enforcing a 1972 loitering law that almost a year later was struck down as unconstitutional by a municipal court judge.
With that, the police began issuing traffic tickets to contractors, making it more difficult for workers and contractors to hook up. The town had already passed an ordinance limiting the number of people who could occupy a room in an apartment or boarding house.
To defuse the situation, Denis J. Johnston, director of the Immigrant Rights Program for the American Friends Service Committee, and the Rev. Richard Wittig, pastor of the Leonia United Methodist Church, called for the creation of an alternative location where the workers could gather , a compromise that was rejected by Mayor William Maresca of Palisades Park.
In November 1994 the workers finally got the ear of County Executive William P. Schuber, who conferred with a group of officials who had successfully set up a hiring hall in Montgomery County, Md.
Ellie Spiegel, a Leonia resident who was part of a group that visited the center in Montgomery County, said, "They had a great program that could serve as a model." 
CASA of Maryland, a non-profit community action and social services organization, had worked with Montgomery County officials in 1993 to secure state and county financing to buy and renovate a house in East Silver Spring. The CASA Employment and Training, Center, which now draws up to 300 workers a day, supplies lists of professional and unskilled laborers to registered employers. In addition, it offers workers English and computer classes, health services and assistance with housing.
"The solution is to be together, that everybody be involved," said Gustavo Torres, executive director of CASA of Maryland. "And it's very important that the workers be involved because if you make a decision without the workers, they are not going to buy into it."
In February 1995, Mr. Schuber formed a task force to find a location for such a hiring hall. But by 1997, the group -- made up of the county's department of human services, the mayors and other representatives from Palisades Park, Ridgefield, Cliffside Park and Fairview as well as several day laborers -- could not agree on a site, and Mr. Schuber disbanded the group. . 
"We just couldn't achieve consensus on that," said Mr. Schuber who is no longer the county executive, "and that was really one of my regrets."
The issue arose again last May when the decomposed body of a day laborer was discovered in a disabled truck in an area of warehouses in Palisades Park.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Schuber's successor, Dennis McNerney, said that the executive favored creating a central site, and that he wanted to move quickly on it.
"We're searching for that location right now," said the spokeswoman, Julie Roginsky.
Although she declined to say where the county was looking, one official knowledgeable about the subject said the search was again focusing on the parking lot of an athletic field in the Palisade Park section of Overpeck County Park about a mile from Columbia Avenue. 
'A Sense of Urgency'
"Mr. McNerney thinks there is a sense of urgency on this issue, especially because of the weather and because of this recent death that really focused attention on this issue and because he feels it's the right thing to do to protect the day laborers from being hit by cars or picked up by unsavory contractors," she said. "It will also alleviate a lot of the pressure these towns are facing."
Mayor Farber, though initially opposed to the idea, said he had changed his mind. 
"It's gotten out of hand, and something has to be done," he said. But, he added, he is only in favor, if the county picks up the expenses. Ms. Roginsky said she did not know about financing, but added, "The county would take some sort of lead."
To Mr. Alvarado of the National Day Laborer Organizing Network, the protracted struggle in Bergen County is not unusual. "Some of these work centers are funded by local municipalities, some of them by general use funds; some use community development block grants; and some centers are run by private foundations; and, like in L.A., it's both private money and public money," he said. 
In Morristown, where the Hispanic population has doubled, to 5,000, in the last decade and amounts to a fourth of the population, the day laborers who line Morris Street each morning have contributed to the shock of rapid change in the three-square mile community. 
To be sure, the arrest of a Honduran day laborer in the murder and sexual abuse of a 10-year-old son of Guatemalan immigrants two years ago has contributed to the community's wary attitude. Officials in Morristown say they have not been successful in finding a neighborhood in which to locate a hiring hall. 
Paul Miller, executive director of Morristown One Community, a nonprofit agency whose aim is to bring together the diverse community, said the owner of an abandoned building on Spring Street pledged to donate the site if he and Wind of the Spirit could get the building demolished and get a prefabricated building put up in its place. But so far, the town council has seemed declined to set up a committee to explore the proposal.
"We're trying to be creative in solving challenges facing the community, and when we faced the council, everyone seemed to point out the challenges rather than how to make it work," said Mr. Miller. "It's a political hot potato; there's no doubt about that. It's an issue that touches us all differently."
If there is not a hiring hall in Freeehold, there are at least some picnic tables in an area off Throckmorton Street near the railroad station where day laborers gather. 
"It was a very good effort by the Freehold police and Hispanic affairs to get the word out," said Lesbia Marrero, program director of the Hispanic Women Resource Center Program, who worked with the officials. "The public responded very positively to the intervention." 
But Joseph Bellina, the borough administrator, says there are some drawbacks. "It's taxing on the police department to monitor this," said Mr. Bellina . "There's a litter issue as a result of them throwing coffee cups all over the place and public urination. This is something the borough has to deal with." 
One town -- Dover, in Morris County -- seemed to be dealing with the issue. A center opened its doors about a year ago in a back office of the Morris County Organization for Hispanic Affairs on Bassett Highway. Unfortunately, the center faltered, said Paul C. McDougall, the clerk and administrator in Dover, partly, he added, because the Organization for Hispanic Affiars did not have enough volunteers to work there. And, he said, contractors were reluctant to register at the center because of "tax issues." 
"I was also told the laborers weren't happy because the guy who was closest to the door was the one that got hired," Mr. McDougall said. "There wasn't that equal opportunity there as in the wide open on the corner."
Mayor Richard M. Newman said the town was exploring its options, but added: "I don't know what our next step is. It depends of how things go. There's been talk about buying a building, but I'm not buying a building on taxpayers' money."
In Bergenfield in Bergen County, the government and the police department have arranged for day laborers to meet behind the Borough Hall, where bathrooms are available.
"Here in Bergenfield, as the day laborer population grew there was a desire not to be hostile and to organize it," said the Rev. Stephen Giordano, pastor of the Clinton Avenue Reformed Church and president of the Bergen County Council of Churches.
As Mr. Giordano, who served on Mr. Schuber's task force, put it, "If we as communities don't create a positive and healthy alternative, then we have no right to crack down on day laborers."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Nassau and Suffolk Gained 6,200 Jobs in December

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch

 BODY:
Employment in Nassau and Suffolk rose slightly in December from November's figures, according to the State Labor Department. 
The Island gained 6,200 nonagricultural jobs, for an increase of 0.5 percent. The largest number of new jobs were in the services sector; retailing alone added 4,400 jobs. The unemployment rate remained flat at 3.9 percent.
 In New York State, the number of jobs in December stayed even, at about 8.4 million, and the unemployment rate edged up to 6.1 percent, from 5.9 percent. Nationally, the number of jobs remained flat at 134.2 million, with the unemployment rate holding at 5.7 percent.

HEADLINE: No-Smoking Signs Spread Slowly Across Africa 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 30 

 BODY:
President Yoweri Museveni said recently that his prayers would be answered if a thousand major cigarette companies operated in Uganda instead of just one.
 That one, British American Tobacco, provides about one-sixteenth of Uganda's total tax revenue and provides work, either directly or indirectly, for more than half a million people in a country in need of every job it can get. The company's philanthropy benefits AIDS orphans and war victims. 
 But Phillip Karugaba, a Ugandan lawyer and leading antismoking activist, has a different view of the company, an integral part of the economy of East Africa since the days of British colonialism. "If we had 1,000 B.A.T.'s we wouldn't have any population left," said Mr. Karugaba, who is trying to help Africa catch up with the antismoking movements raging elsewhere. "B.A.T. is so powerful and has so much money that it is not considered an evil monster here. Not yet." 
British American Tobacco, which is based in London and has subsidiaries throughout Africa and the world, earned $1.5 billion on revenue of more than $18 billion in its last fiscal year, and boasted recently that its Africa divisions had never lost a lawsuit filed by the antismoking lobby. (Brown & Williamson of the United States, which the company owns, has been the division most besieged by lawsuits.) Lately, however, African judges and lawmakers have left the company on the defensive here, an area that has long been a smoker's paradise.
Smoking is still allowed on many domestic airlines in Africa. Smoke clouds the air in most restaurants and bars and buildings. Some hospitals here even allow patients to puff on a cigarette as they mend.
Generally, the more destitute a country the less likely that smoking is controlled. South Africa, with sub-Saharan Africa's strongest economy, leads the way when it comes to tobacco regulation. Uganda, which still relies heavily on foreign economic assistance, is far behind.
"Relative lack of tobacco legislation in many African countries continues to make African countries a target of multinational tobacco companies," a group of African health ministers said last fall in preparation for talks next month at the World Health Organization on strict global tobacco regulations.
British American Tobacco, the world's second-largest tobacco company after Philip Morris, and the numerous other tobacco companies that operate around the continent have fought to keep Africa a smoking zone. Slowly, however, no-smoking signs are gaining in popularity.
Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania are enacting laws to restrict smoking in public places. In Uganda, a High Court judge, at Mr. Karugaba's urging, recently ordered the country's National Environmental Management Authority to enforce such restrictions within a year. British American Tobacco executives asked if the company could take part in the first planning meeting, but the government said no.
Antismoking advocates here say their goal is to regulate tobacco, not outlaw it. They are receiving backing from an array of groups in the United States like the San Francisco Tobacco Free Coalition that have been taking on the tobacco industry for years.
In Uganda, the activists are currently sparring with British American Tobacco over the warning labels on cigarette packs. Mr. Karugaba is seeking a court order that would strengthen the severity of the warnings, which now read, in capital letters: "Ministry of Health warning: Cigarette smoking can be harmful to your health."
When that warning label was under consideration by the Ugandan government in the late 1980's, British American Tobacco told policy makers that it did not believe cigarette smoking was harmful. "We think it would only be fair to have a form of words which is not excessively strong," the company wrote in 1988 to the Ugandan government, which was just the sixth African country at the time, along with Libya, Kenya, Senegal, Sudan and Mauritius, to put labels on cigarettes.
Since then, the company has acknowledged the health effects of smoking, albeit in a carefully worded way. Mr. Karugaba wants explicit warnings on packs that identify the diseases that can afflict smokers. He holds up as a guide the warnings in Canada, which show gruesome photographs of suffering smokers.
In another telling sign that the antismoking movement in Africa has advanced, lawsuits filed by individual smokers are no longer anomalies. While British American Tobacco successfully challenged separate lawsuits filed by two smokers in Uganda in 2000, a Nairobi lawyer recently filed a suit that is still in its early stages against the company's Kenyan subsidiary, accusing it of selling products that caused his client, an elderly farmer who suffers from vascular disease, to lose a leg.
Henry Rugamba, a spokesman for British American Tobacco's Uganda subsidiary, acknowledged that the company had been forced to deal with "a couple of lawyers who have made tobacco their issue." Nonetheless, he said, "I don't feel under siege. I think it is healthy -- if I can use the word -- to raise the issues."
Worried about its image, the company has begun a public relations campaign. It recently hired Wafula Oguttu, an antismoking activist who is the editor of the Monitor, Uganda's independent newspaper, to lead community discussions on smoking. In addition, British American Tobacco has voluntarily withdrawn much of its advertising, although it still blankets Kampala's bars and nightclubs with promotions for its Sportsman and Benson & Hedges brands.
Most of all, though, the tobacco industry is relying on its many friends in government. Uganda's finance minister, Gerald Ssendaula, is a tobacco trader himself. He recently interceded in a tax dispute on behalf of a small rival to British American Tobacco that makes products distributed by his family.
Meanwhile, the minister of tourism, trade and industry, Moses Ali, has invited Ugandans to smoke as a form of patriotism. "Nobody is forced to smoke but if you do then we welcome you because we shall get taxes from you," he told reporters recently.
The biggest cheerleader of all for British American Tobacco, however, has been Mr. Museveni, who has described the company as a lifesaver for a country so destitute. One of Mr. Museveni's media advisers, John Nagenda, is on the company's board of directors. 
The president plays down the dangers of cancer among Africans, who Mr. Museveni says smoke but do not inhale. "We puff it out," he said last year. "That is how my father has smoked for the last 70 years and stayed alive. We look at the Europeans swallowing the smoke, then hear they have a lot of cancer in Europe. I'm not surprised. Why do they swallow the smoke?"
Even with such high-level endorsements, however, British American Tobacco has found its Uganda cigarette sales -- about a billion sticks a year -- on the decline, and not just because of the antismoking movement. Smugglers have been bringing in lower-cost cigarettes from Kenya that are made by the company's rivals, like Supermatch produced by Mastermind Tobacco Limited. Also, other expenses have made cigarettes, which cost less than $1 a pack here, more of a luxury. The spread of cellphones in Africa, for instance, has left many people with less disposable income for cigarettes.
As for the health effects of smoking, officials with British American Tobacco scoff at the notion that tobacco is anywhere near as serious as the many other challenges facing Africa.
"If you go down to the Ministry of Health, they have serious issues with AIDS, malaria and child malnutrition," Mr. Rugamba said. "You only have a million smokers in Uganda. It's hard to talk tobacco when people are dying of AIDS."
The company's target market, young males, seem to have a mixed view -- which may be a sign the antismoking movement is having an effect. "I know it's harmful but it's not as big a health hazard as people make it to be," said Jefferson Mwaura, a 20-year-old Kenyan smoker. "It makes you look cool and sophisticated."
Mr. Mwaura's twin brother, Geoffrey, thinks differently. "It's like knowingly killing yourself," he said.
