HEADLINE: S.U.V. and Pickup Sales Are Likely to Grow 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
Sport utility vehicles and pickups will maintain their growth in the American market as competition from Asia intensifies, auto executives said over the weekend as they gathered here for an annual conference with car dealers.
 Industry executives also defended their largest vehicles against a tide of recent questions raised by federal regulators and environmental advocates. 
 Controversy has not deterred competition in the lucrative market. The latest salvo came on Friday, when the chief of the Hyundai Motor Company, the Korean conglomerate that has made its name mostly in low-priced cars, said the company would probably enter the full-size sport utility market by 2007. Hyundai is also considering building its first pickup around the same time, as well as a new minivan, and is evaluating whether to start a luxury brand. 
"We are developing a full-size S.U.V. We think the market will continue to grow," the chief of Hyundai, D. J. Kim, said before the National Automobile Dealers Association meeting started on Saturday.
The new products would be part of Hyundai's goal of tripling American sales, to one million vehicles, by 2010.
While the Big Three dominated sport utility sales in the 1990's, Asian automakers, particularly Toyota, have lineups that today look more like the domestics. The next battleground appears to be the pickup. Last month, Nissan unveiled its first full-size pickup, the Titan, at the Detroit auto show, joining Toyota in a battle with Detroit automakers for one of its most lucrative markets.
"It should be clear that the truck segments are now coming under attack," Wolfgang Bernhard, the chief operating officer of the Chrysler Group, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, said in a speech. "Anyone who believes pickups won't represent the next big product offensive of the imports is wrong," he added.
Top executives of General Motors and the Ford Motor Company defended the S.U.V., a cornerstone of their profitability, from recent campaigns against its effects on the nation's oil consumption by a range of groups, from religious leaders to the columnist Arianna Huffington. Automakers and car dealers said they saw no move away from such vehicles by consumers.
"S.U.V.'s are under a lot of scrutiny these days, and yet the S.U.V. buyer is a very loyal lot," said William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Ford. "We think the attacks are unfair, but we can't change that."
But Mr. Ford, in speeches on Friday and Saturday, said environmental responsibility, a low priority in most buyer surveys, would become an important measuring stick.
"Many are becoming impatient," he said, "with the social and environmental tradeoffs that have become associated with the automobile."
The S.U.V. has also been bruised of late on safety. G. Richard Wagoner Jr., chief of General Motors, took issue with recent comments by the Bush administration's top auto safety regulator, Dr. Jeffrey W. Runge, head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
In a speech last month, Dr. Runge, a former emergency room doctor, said he would not put one of his children in a sport utility that did not perform well on rollover tests.
"I didn't understand his choice of a vehicle for his teenage kids because I go exactly the opposite way," Mr. Wagoner said. 
The traffic safety agency is toughening its rollover testing, making it reflective more real-world driving conditions. The agency is also considering new tests and regulations aimed at making S.U.V.'s and pickups less dangerous when they collide with smaller vehicles.
On the economic front, Mr. Wagoner was upbeat, saying he expected an added 1.8 million vehicles in industrywide sales in the United States by the end of the decade. Last year, 16.8 million vehicles were sold.
"A new American auto boom is ours to loose," Mr. Wagoner told auto dealers. "Let's not screw it up."

HEADLINE: As Broadband Gains, The Internet's Snails, Like AOL, Fall Back 

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
America Online now has some company in the Internet doghouse. Last week, the company said the number of subscribers to its flagship Internet service, by far the nation's largest, had fallen in the fourth quarter, the first decline in its history, further contributing to the woes of its parent, AOL Time Warner.
 But executives at the America Online division can at least find solace that its plight is shared by the other leading dial-up Internet access providers, EarthLink and Microsoft's MSN, which also have shrinking numbers of dial-up subscribers. 
 The problem is speed. Consumers have been dropping their slow dial-up services and switching to faster service, called broadband. AOL and the other dial-up leaders do offer broadband service, but the latest quarterly results show that consumers are shunning these offers, despite increased promotion. Rather, they are buying broadband services offered by cable and telephone companies. 
"People still look to the telcos and the cable guys first for broadband service," said Jed Kolko, who is an analyst with Forrester Research.
Final results are not in from every company, but it appears that broadband subscriptions in the United States increased to about 16 million at year's end from 10 million a year earlier, out of about 60 million total households online. The broadband offering by the three big dial-up players totals no more than 2 million subscribers.
A recent study by Nielsen/NetRating found that the number of people who connect to the Internet at home over dial-up connections had actually started to decline as broadband users increased by 59 percent over the last year. 
"We were surprised by the rapid acceleration of broadband adoption in the home," said Bob Visse, the director of marketing for MSN at Microsoft. 
At year's end, America Online, had 26.5 million subscribers, a loss of 176,000 from the previous quarter. For last year, it added only 1.2 million subscribers, far less than the 3.7 million it added in 2001. 
AOL said its marketing campaigns were less effective in the fourth quarter than it expected. As a result, the number of dial-up customers paying the full $23.90 monthly price increased only slightly.
But AOL reduced the number of customers that are offered free or discounted service as an attempt to keep them from canceling altogether.
At year's end, AOL had about 650,000 broadband subscribers, up only a handful in the fourth quarter, despite a new television campaign and heavy promotion on its own service.
Even more surprising, Microsoft, which thought it would capitalize on AOL's problems with a fancy new product and a $300 million multimedia blitzkrieg for its butterfly mascot, saw no growth in the quarter; it has nine million subscribers for its various MSN Internet services.
Microsoft said the total included a decrease in use for its narrowband Internet service and MSNTV service, formerly WebTV, offset by increases in its broadband service and its Hotmail extra-storage service (which offers a larger e-mail box). John G. Connors, the company's chief financial officer, told investors last month that the company would not meet its earlier goal for subscriber growth in the first half of this year.
EarthLink, the third-biggest Internet service provider, kept its subscriber count flat in the final quarter of last year, at 4.8 million. But that masked a reduction of 70,000 dial-up subscribers, offset by acquisitions that added 130,000 subscribers and the addition of 98,000 broadband subscribers. If it were not for acquisitions, EarthLink's dial-up subscriber count would have declined by 8 percent last year, Goldman, Sachs estimates.
"This is no surprise for us," said Charles G. Betty, EarthLink's chief executive. "We saw the narrowband market peak two years ago." Mr. Betty estimates that four million households got dial-up Internet access for the first time last year and that fewer than three million newcomers will enter the market this year.
He said that EarthLink was betting the market would split and that many customers would move to broadband service and many more would gravitate to lower-cost dial-up services. EarthLink has bought PeoplePC to compete with United Online's growing $9.95-a-month dial-up services.
America Online is still by far the leader in one important measure: profits. Last year it had Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, of $1.8 billion on sales of $9.1 billion. That is down from Ebitda of $2.3 billion in 2001, and this year the measure will decline again, analysts estimate. 
Still, EarthLink and MSN have never made a profit, although they both intend to soon. United Online, posted its first profit, of $1.5 million, in the third quarter. And even SBC Communications, the phone company with the most broadband subscriptions, is still losing money on them. (The cable companies do not report publicly on their broadband profitability.)
The other full-price dial-up services are also losing ground. SBC's dial-up service, mainly the venerable Prodigy service it had acquired, has fewer than half of the customers it did a year ago. And even a venture with Yahoo to add features to SBC's dial-up offering could not prevent the service from losing 150,000 subscribers in the fourth quarter alone. AT&T will no longer discuss how many subscribers it has for Worldnet, its dial-up Internet service provider, which had 1.4 million subscribers a year ago, according to ISP-Planet, a Web site.
The major telephone companies are all expanding their broadband subscriptions for what is called D.S.L. or digital subscriber line, service at an annual pace of more than a 50 percent. In the last quarter of 2002, SBC Communications added 245,000 subscribers, Verizon Communications added 148,000, and BellSouth added 97,000. 
The cable companies have been growing slightly slower because they have a greater share of the market, but most have yet to report their fourth-quarter results. 
Last week, AOL Time Warner said that Road Runner, the high-speed service of its cable systems, added 291,000 subscribers in the fourth quarter, more than any broadband service to report results so far. That leaves Time Warner cable with 2.6 million broadband data subscribers, or 24 percent of its total customers.
AOL, by contrast, sells broadband service to only 2.5 percent of its users.
"AOL, the world's largest Internet service provider, only has 650,000 subscribers, while Road Runner has 2.6 million -- go figure," said Michael W. Harris, the president of Kinetic Strategies, a consulting firm in Phoenix. AOL's strategy of charging $10 a month more for America Online's broadband service than for Road Runner does not appear to be working, he said. 
"Most people who are coming to broadband want the most speed at the lowest cost," he said, "and they are getting that from their cable companies."
In a conference call with investors last week, Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, said the company would redouble its effort to justify the price premium of the AOL broadband offering.
"While a number of people are getting AOL over broadband now, the product isn't really differentiated in a way that we would like," he said, noting that the company would soon introduce a new service with more features. "I don't think you are going to be able to look for clear indications of how the new broadband initiative is being taken up by consumers until midyear, because before you start throwing lots of marketing dollars after it, we want to put the product together -- we want to do some test marketing."
Microsoft, too, is looking to refashion its MSN service as a premium add-on for customers with broadband service from local companies. It spent $500 million to develop new features for MSN 8.0, like a software system to detect junk e-mail messages. But the advertising campaign to promote it did not stem a decline in customers for its dial-up service.
Microsoft said it was hobbled by a large number of defections among customers who had signed long-term contracts a few years ago in return for rebates of as much as $400. 
"Those customers are very price-sensitive, and they have been going to whatever offer is most attractive," said Mr. Visse, the marketing director.
Mr. Kolko, of Forrester Research, said that for all of Microsoft's advertising, it had not been able to establish itself in the fastest-growing part of the market.
"The butterfly doesn't tell people anything specifically about the broadband service," he said. 
As of the end of the third quarter, Microsoft had 500,000 broadband subscribers as part of a joint venture with Qwest Communications International. It also has a small number of additional subscribers through arrangements where it buys and resells D.S.L. lines from other phone companies. But Mr. Visse said these arrangements were not profitable and so it had not marketed them.
"We've decided that we will only grow this business if we can grow it profitably," Mr. Visse said. 
Mr. Betty, of EarthLink, however, questions how big the market will be for the add-on services that Microsoft and AOL are planning, given that they add $10 or $15 a month to the already high broadband bills.
"I'm not convinced that the market for a premium service is anything other than a very small market," he said.

HEADLINE: Shuttle's Effect On Economy May Be Small, Analysts Say 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The destruction of the space shuttle Columbia, which filled the airways and newspapers all weekend, adds to the list of bad news investors have absorbed recently, including the threat of a war with Iraq, a nuclear standoff with North Korea, declining consumer confidence and slowing corporate earnings growth.
 But unlike the other events, it does not appear that the shuttle tragedy should have a significant impact on consumer confidence or on financial markets, several analysts said yesterday. One reason is that the destruction of the shuttle has not been linked to anything, like terrorism, that would point to increased risk in the future. 
 Even before the latest round of bad news, several strategists and economists argued that investors should effectively ignore the possibility of a war with Iraq in their investment decisions, although they agreed that the war threat has been a drag on the economy and the stock market. 
Instead, they said, investors should concentrate on the economy and if they thought a rebound was likely this year, then it was a good time to buy stocks. Some analysts even said that the start of a war with Iraq would give the stock market a lift, as the fighting could end the uncertainty of what will happen and when.
"The only way this has an effect, to my view, is if it is tied into terrorism," James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, said yesterday, speaking of the shuttle's breakup as it re-entered the atmosphere on Saturday morning.
Douglas R. Cliggott, president of B& P Research, said, "It is clearly a huge personal tragedy for the seven families involved, but in terms of trying to map it into confidence and spending, I don't think it is going to register very high."
That does not mean that stocks of companies involved in the shuttle program will not fall as investors worry about what caused the breakup of the shuttle. But, analysts said, it will probably take a more direct link to a faulty part for a company's stock to face major selling. 
Boeing and Lockheed Martin, through an equal equity stake in United Space Alliance, are the main contractors for the shuttle program. There are more than 120 subcontractors, including Honeywell and Alliant Techsystems.
As for the overall stock market, it is already under pressure from the other bad news. The economy all but ground to a halt in the fourth quarter, when the gross domestic product inched up just 0.7 percent. Consumer confidence fell in January and is not far above the nine-year low it hit in October. And after a nice rally in the first trading days of the year that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up 6 percent, all three main market gauges are now down for the year, with the Dow off 3.5 percent and the Nasdaq composite index is down 1.1 percent.
"What is going to continue to weigh on the market is the poor fundamentals," said Jeffrey Applegate, an independent market strategist.
In January 1986, when the shuttle Challenger exploded on takeoff, the stock market was in the midst of a long rally that ended only with the 1987 crash. On the day of the Challenger explosion, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.2 percent while some stocks of companies linked to the shuttle program, including Morton Thiokol, which was the contractor that made the booster for the shuttle, fell sharply.
The analysts who say a war with Iraq should not diminish investors' focus on the stock market are not advising a headlong rush into equities. But they say stocks will be attractive if the economy revs up to a 3 percent pace in the first half of the year and a little higher in the second half.
Nor do analysts seem to favor so-called war plays, in part because they have been bought and sold already. Military and aerospace stocks are down 26 percent from the end of June, based on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Defense Index, and did not get a significant lift last week after reports that President Bush would ask for a one-third increase in his military budget over the next six years.
"What investors should keep their eyes on is whether the economy gets traction," said Mr. Paulsen, of Wells Capital Management. "It's the economy that will determine the performance of the stock market this year. The war won't be there at the end of the year. The war will fade." His firm is recommending an asset allocation of 75 percent in stocks.
He predicts that the economy is going to grow steadily because it now getting a push from lower interest rates, increased government spending and a weaker dollar, which helps American exporters.
Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at ITG/Hoenig, said, "If you have a long-term outlook, you are supposed to wager that the world works out O.K." But in the current environment, he said, "there is no appetite for risk and there is a ghoulish fascination with the myriad of things that could go wrong."
The current aversion to risk combined with taking a long-term view, he said, makes "this is a good time to buy stocks." He said he was "much more aggressive" in his investments right now.
Besides playing down the threat of a war on investor decisions, analysts argue that there are not many other alternatives this year, outside stocks, that offer a chance of acceptable returns.
Interest rates are so low that money market funds barely pay 1 percent. Bond market rates are higher, but if the economy does pick up speed and Congress and the White House can approve plans to stimulate the economy, interest rates will move higher, cutting into the returns from bonds as their prices fall.
Other havens, like gold, which hit a six-year high of $370 an ounce on Jan. 28, could fall once the uncertainty about the war with Iraq passed. That decline would pull down the price of gold company stocks, which as a group have jumped 25 percent since December.
While a threat of war should not divert investors from stocks, analysts still said that investors have to be prepared for all eventualities. "Investors more than ever should expect the unexpected," said Frederick B. Taylor, chief investment officer at the United States Trust Company.
This means that investors need to be more diversified than usual and more careful in their selections of stocks, he said. "I want companies," Mr. Taylor said, "where managements are able to adjust to uncertainties in uncertain times."
Mr. Cliggott, of B& P Research, put it this way: "An investor should still be extremely cautious. But not so much because of the uncertainty of the military and political situations. But because we have many months ahead of us of disappointing economic growth and disappointing earnings growth."

HEADLINE: U.S. Opposes Proposal to Limit Who May Give Legal Advice 

BYLINE:  By ADAM LIPTAK 

 BODY:
A proposal by the American Bar Association that would prohibit anyone but lawyers from giving advice about the law is drawing opposition from the federal government, which says it is intended to stifle competition and could subject real estate agents, income tax preparers, credit counselors and other laypeople to civil and criminal penalties. 
 The proposal, which will be discussed this week at the association's meeting in Seattle, would also prohibit nonlawyers from negotiating on behalf of others and "selecting, drafting or completing legal documents." The association will vote on the proposal in August. 
 The bar association's president, Alfred P. Carlton Jr., said that the proposal was intended to provide a simple and clear definition of what constitutes the practice of law. Mr. Carlton also said that it would encourage nonlawyers to provide services they now hesitate to offer, for fear of stepping over the line that now separates the practice of law and other businesses. 
"There is a chilling effect on those industries," he said, "because there is not, in most jurisdictions, a well-understood or bright-line definition of what is and is not the practice of law."
But the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice are concerned about the scope of the proposal and submitted objections in a letter to the bar association in December. In whatever states adopted it, the agencies said, the rule could subject tenants' associations, claims adjusters, tax preparers, real estate agents, investment bankers, business planners, hospitals, labor unions andothers to penalties.
In an interview, Thomas M. Gordon, a lawyer with Halt, a legal consumer advocacy group in Washington, gave an example of the definition's scope. "Dear Abby would be subject to prosecution every time she answered a reader's letter that dealt with a legal issue," Mr. Gordon said.
The bar association's own antitrust law section opposes the definition. Robert T. Joseph, the section's chairman, said the proposal would prevent credit counselors from helping consumers negotiate payment plans with their creditors or laypeople from helping immigrants fill out Immigration and Naturalization Service forms.
Mr. Joseph said the association should instead encourage open competition, by explaining to the public why lawyers provide superior services at reasonable prices.
Jerry Ellig, the deputy director of the office of policy planning for the trade commission, explained why the government made its unusual submission.
"We don't think it's good public policy to constrain competition in the absence of really strong evidence that the constraint has an offsetting benefit," Mr. Ellig said. "We haven't seen evidence of how consumers are more protected if an attorney is present."
Dudley Humphrey, a North Carolina lawyer who is a member of the bar association task force that drafted the proposal, said the government was making a power grab.
"Quite frankly," Mr. Humphrey said, "it proceeds from the F.T.C.'s desire to assert what jurisdiction it has over the legal profession."
Monte Davis, the president of the Claims Group in Austin, Tex., said his company was the subject of an investigation by Texas officials for practicing law without a license.
His company assists people making claims in class-action settlements involving defective hardboard siding. Under the bar association proposal, his group's nonlawyers would be barred from doing that. 
"It really scared the pants off of us," Mr. Davis said of the investigation.
The Texas investigation was eventually dropped after Mr. Davis filed a lawsuit over it, but he remains perplexed and wary. If companies like his did not assist consumers, he said, the class-action money would go unclaimed.
His lawyer, Peter Kennedy, said the local bar had no interest in competing for the work. "They didn't teach me how to identify Masonite siding in law school," Mr. Kennedy said, adding that he "didn't go to law school to go out in the Texas heat to look at siding."
The bar's central concern, though, is with real estate closings. State laws differ sharply on who may conduct them. About 10 states, mostly in the East, require that lawyers be present.
James R. Maher, the executive vice president of the American Land Title Association, said that more than 80 percent of real estate closings were conducted by lay specialists. "Attorneys are great if you need them," Mr. Maher said, "but the state should not provide monopoly protection in the guise of consumer protection."
Mr. Humphrey said the organized bar would not easily give up this fight.
"Real estate work has been the bread-and-butter work of lawyers," he said. "It's the thing that keeps the doors open and the lights turned on. Certain elements in the real estate community, to speak quite frankly, are increasingly pressing to drive down prices."
Part of the problem, experts on each side of the bar association proposal said, is the difficulty of defining what amounts to legal work.
Geoffrey C. Hazard Jr., who teaches legal ethics at the University of Pennsylvania, said the enterprise was a difficult one.
"There isn't too much trouble in defining law practice for lawyers appearing in courtrooms and before administrative agencies," Professor Hazard said. "The difficulty is that most of what lawyers do is office practice, and what they do in office practice is often about the same thing as lots of nonlawyer officials in companies and governments do."
He said the bar association "is going to have a lot of difficulty with a definition that is intelligent and meaningful but not overly broad."
"I just don't see how that can be done very well," he said.
The proposed definition is widely considered to be expansive when compared to the existing prohibitions on the unauthorized practice of law in almost every state.
"It's breathtakingly broad," said Steven Lubet, who teaches legal ethics at Northwestern University. "It doesn't include what most states call the ancillary professions exception."
The problem with the bar association proposal, Professor Lubet continued, is not only economic. "It really reflects the worst of the profession, which is to assume that lawyers own the law and legal discourse," he said. "It's antidemocratic. In a democracy, everyone has an interest in discussing the law. The content of the law, rights and remedies, is meant to be part of the public discourse."

HEADLINE: The Best of America 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Astronauts speeding in from outer space, 40 miles above the earth, 16 minutes from touchdown . . . 
 We don't pay much attention to our astronauts until calamity strikes. And yet the grief that accompanies the spectacular loss of these brave strangers, men and women with unfamiliar names like David M. Brown and Laurel Clark, is extraordinary. 
 The posthumous television images of the smiling, healthy, enthusiastic crew of the space shuttle Columbia touch feelings that are usually reserved for those much closer to us. They're very difficult to watch. 
For Americans, in some sense, it's like watching the loss of our better selves. The astronauts may not get a tremendous amount of attention under ordinary circumstances, but they are the last unspoiled American heroes. They have not been laid low by scandal, or exposed as phonies. They carry none of the taint of bad faith that clings so stubbornly to so many in politics, the world of business and the media. Their motives, as far as we can tell, are still pure. They have come to embody whatever remains of the American ideal.
Dr. Clark, a Navy flight surgeon, had been conducting life-science experiments aboard the Columbia. The experiments were part of a wide range of studies by the crew that were aimed at improving the health and safety of humans on Earth and in space.
At a time when much of the world is gripped by the oppressive fear of war and terror, the crew of the Columbia was devoting its considerable talent to work that was creative, cooperative and constructive. Theirs was a mission of peace.
Gen. Omar Bradley, a hero of World War II, delivered a speech in Boston in 1948 that is remarkably appropriate for the violent and chaotic world of 2003. "The world has achieved brilliance without wisdom," he said, "power without conscience. Ours is a world of nuclear giants and ethical midgets. We know more about war than we know of peace, more about killing than we know about living."
Americans in 2003 are not just struggling with forces that are wildly uncertain and dangerous. We're also struggling, on a variety of fronts, with doubts about the direction and the soundness of our national mission. There is a uniform commitment to fighting terror, but public support for an invasion of Iraq varies considerably from week to week. Bitter arguments are raging over civil rights, civil liberties and immigration policies. And there is nothing close to a consensus on the fairness of the nation's tax policies and social welfare programs.
Mixed with the anxiety over war and terror and the threat posed by a weak domestic economy is an underlying feeling that this great and powerful nation could -- as Jack Kennedy contended -- do better, that its ideals are still important and that you court real danger if you continue giving them short shrift.
When our attention is drawn to the astronauts, even in the midst of tragedy, we are pleased to see them as powerful symbols of the most admirable aspects of American life. They are not superhumans. Saturday showed that they're fragile like the rest of us. But they hold in trust for us the spirit of adventure and exploration and decency and accomplishment that is so important to our view of ourselves as Americans.
No one wants to look in the mirror and see something low or mean. The astronauts help save us from that.
President Bush praised the crew of the Columbia for its "service to all humanity." He said, "These astronauts knew the dangers and they faced them willingly, knowing they had a high and noble purpose in life."
That was not hyperbole, but the simple truth.
Some time will go by and the press of world events will cause the astronauts and all they represent to slip again from our consciousness, which is too bad. It would be so much better if this terrible tragedy could somehow prompt a renewed commitment to America's "high and noble" ideals and aspirations. One quick example: The nation's great wealth and good fortune could be used to build a sparkling new generation of schools to educate the millions upon millions of young people whose talents and energy will have to be called upon if the U.S. is to continue to flourish.
That is one way in which we could honor the astronauts whose lives -- and tragic deaths -- remind us of our own deeply held aspirations, our ideals, those aspects of ourselves that we admire most.

HEADLINE: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE CHALLENGER; 
Lessons From Uneven Challenger Investigation Help Create Attitude Change

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
The space agency's description tonight of a cascade of warning signals from the computers aboard the shuttle Columbia in the seven minutes before it disintegrated was striking for more than just the picture it painted of the last, fiery seconds of a doomed craft.
 It was exactly the kind of information that NASA withheld for more than two weeks after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger 17 years ago. And for months, the investigation into the causes of that disaster was a cat-and-mouse game that pitted the space agency against dissident engineers who began leaking information about a long history of design failures that were hushed up in the interest of keeping the space program's financing alive. 
 It is too early to tell how the Columbia investigation will turn out. NASA will certainly face months of scrutiny about what it knew about the weaknesses of the insulating tiles that protect the orbiter as it re-enters the atmosphere and the structural vulnerabilities of the shuttle fleet's oldest craft. 
But in the hours after the Columbia disaster on Saturday, according to Bush administration officials and experts familiar with changes in the space agency over the last few years, there was a recognition that NASA could not afford another cover-up, another scramble to hide ominous signals of impending disaster.
"There is a big attitude change," said Donald J. Kutyna, a retired four-star general in the Air Force who was a member of the commission that investigated the Challenger. Referring to the administrator of NASA,he said, "Sean O'Keefe has seen the damage the agency did to itself when it covered up what happened."
The change seemed apparent tonight as Ron D. Dittemore, the space shuttle program manager, led reporters through a chronology of events, compiled from the early trove of data transmitted from sensors aboard the Columbia, of a flight that began to go awry as it entered the airspace over California. 
As in the Challenger disaster, the warning signs are evident only in retrospect. As in that disaster, the crew apparently had no warning that the readings they were seeing were evidence of a far greater problem.
But it was not until the night of Feb. 14, 1986 -- 17 days after the Challenger disaster -- that NASA released a chronology of the rapid-fire events that had spun out of control. And back then, they did so after evidence was leaking out that agency officials knew there was tremendous danger in launching the Challenger in the frigid cold, and that a series of previous shuttle launchings had nearly ended in disaster.
Today, NASA described at length what it knew about troubles with its protective tiles, and what programs it had put in place to find and solve the problem. And officials vowed today to hold two news briefings a day to maintain the flow of information.
The tiles will undoubtedly be a major subject of investigation, along with the General Accounting Office's conclusion, in a report issued last week, that NASA has put "little emphasis on end results, product performance and cost control" when dealing with its contractors, who consume $12.7 billion a year, or 90 percent of the agency's budget.
In some ways, the Columbia investigation may prove more difficult than unraveling the mystery of Challenger.
Because the Challenger explosion took place 73 seconds after liftoff, there were telltale photographs that showed how the flight began to go awry less than a half-second after the engines ignited. Those photographs of mysterious puffs of smoke could be correlated to the sensor data and, eventually, to large chunks of the shuttle that were recovered from the ocean.
But the pictures of the Columbia are taken from a distance of 40 miles. Much more will have to be pieced together from the data received from sensors, some of which went dead. Others showed a significant increase in the temperature in the left wheel well. But Mr. Dittemore would draw no public conclusion tonight, saying, "I'm thinking the same thing you are thinking, but I can't go beyond that."
But the fact that he was thinking out loud is itself a change.
In the Apollo 1 disaster, the details of NASA's mistakes, which contributed to a flash fire in a cockpit that killed three heroes of the early space program, took months and years to come out. It was the cold war, and an admission of error seemed an admission of weakness.
In the Challenger case, NASA had been under great pressure to design a truck to the skies. Its claims about the economic efficiency of the shuttle depended on an aggressive schedule of launchings, upwards of 24 a year. Bad news about O-rings and burn-throughs and evidence of flights that nearly ended in calamity were suppressed. Now the shuttle schedule is more reasonable; the Columbia flight was delayed for two years.
But the pressures for faster-better-cheaper still exist, and there is little evidence that the agency is getting the best new scientific and engineering minds it attracted in the glory days of space exploration. Today, the number of NASA employees older than 60 is nearly three times greater than the number under 30. 
A General Accounting Office report published in January notes that in 2001, just as President Bush was coming to office, "NASA's shuttle work force had declined significantly in recent years to the point of reducing NASA's ability to safely support the shuttle program," and many of those who remained "showed signs of overwork and fatigue."
While the agency has begun to address the issues, the report indicated, "these challenges have not been mitigated."
The strategy the agency is following now is to extend the life of the shuttles to 2020 -- a strategy that may require significant review if it turns out that the Columbia's age, or some kind of structural failure, contributed to the disaster.
One major question is whether the panel of outsiders Mr. O'Keefe appointed on Saturday will have the mandate or the political heft to address those questions. That is the advantage of a presidential commission, like the one President Ronald Reagan appointed, run by former Secretary of State William P. Rogers. Even that commission was charged with whitewashing the worst news out of the Challenger disaster because Mr. Reagan made it clear he wanted NASA strengthened. But there is a risk, former members of the Challenger commission noted today, that any panel without presidential authority could end up ratifying the status quo.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The investigation into the Challenger disaster was marred by cover-ups. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ON COLLEGE SPORTS; 
What Women's Sports Can Be

BYLINE:  By Jere Longman 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C. 

 BODY:
A decade ago, Duke did not charge admission for women's basketball. And now this on Saturday night: a full, throbbing house at Cameron Indoor Stadium. A paid house.
 "All week, everyone talked about 'the game,' and it was the women's game," said Heidi Hullinger, a distance runner at Duke. "It shows that a big matchup can hold the interest of an entire university." 
 The 9,314 who bought tickets to Cameron's first sellout for women, and others who watched on national television, were rewarded with a tense, breathtaking match between Duke and Connecticut, No. 1 versus No. 2, the last undefeated teams in major college basketball, sneakered infantry on the battle lines of Title IX.
UConn took a 51-23 lead, then Duke woke up, whittling its deficit to 71-65 before losing, 77-65. The game reconfirmed that given equal opportunity, determined university support and suitable news media attention, women can provide competition every bit as engaging and remunerative as their counterparts on men's teams. These were women at their finest, demonstrating great skill, purposeful teamwork, the awakening of youth, a taut refusal to succumb.
"It proves there is a big fan base for women's sports, that it's not just a charity cause," Amelia Booth, a rower at Duke, said.
On the court, these were true student-athletes. Every player who completes her basketball eligibility at the two universities graduates, year after year. For too many men, college is a delusional steppingstone to the pros. For women, it's more often a chance to have an education.
And yet, this galvanizing moment was flecked with wariness. Title IX, the 1972 law that forbids gender discrimination at universities receiving federal funds, is under the threat of rollback by the Bush administration. There is growing fear among advocates of women's sports that opportunities may soon disappear, as UConn's 28-point lead nearly did.
It can only be hoped that UConn-Duke was a sign of what is to be enhanced, not diminished. As the Huskies rebuffed the Blue Devils, so did they rebuke the myth that women are not as interested in sports as men. There is no evidence of this. We know only that women have had many fewer decades in which to express their interest.
As USA Today recently noted, a federal court ruling in a Title IX case involving Brown University remarked that the larger number of men in athletics reflected historical discrimination, not lesser interest among women.
"Interest and ability rarely develop in a vacuum," the court noted. "They evolve as a function of opportunity and experience."
Athletes from Duke's track, crew and lacrosse squads helped to fill Cameron in a rah-rah sisterhood of support for the basketball team. It was a night to celebrate women, too long seen as the enemy, cleverly pitted by football against nonrevenue men's sports and made the scapegoat for dwindling men's teams in wrestling, gymnastics and swimming.
Women have become a convenient but misdirected target. Consider this about wrestling: According to the Coalition for Women and Girls in Education, 53 wrestling programs were cut from 1984 to 1988, during a period when Title IX enforcement was suspended by the United States Supreme Court, and 55 programs were pared over the next 12 years, after the law was restored. This suggests wrestling is a victim of market forces and opportune pruning, not women's intrusion.
Women are not forcing the curtailment of some men's teams. Rather, it is a failure of imagination and commitment by many universities and an unwillingness to confront the money pit of football. Football should receive favorable treatment because it brings in millions of dollars, its supporters argue. Yet, according to various surveys taken by women's groups, half to two-thirds of football teams operate in the red, meaning they don't even pay for themselves, much less other teams on campus.
There is no reason that universities need 85 football players on scholarship, when N.F.L. teams limit rosters to 53, even though they face yearly free-agent turnover in numbers similar to graduation. A reduction in 25 scholarships would save $750,000 to $800,000, estimates Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College, enough to pay for wrestling and another sport. Not coincidentally, Duke and UConn are universities at which the football tail does not wag the academic dog.
After Saturday's great escape, UConn Coach Geno Auriemma said he had never heard a crowd so loud as when Duke made its furious second-half charge. He had witnessed a mesmerizing contest, featuring the country's two best players. Alana Beard willed Duke back into the game, then Diana Taurasi countered with two important baskets for UConn. At the end, Taurasi pumped her fist at the Duke students who had taunted her, putting her thumb and little finger to her face, gesturing, "Give me a call."
"This Title IX stuff drives me nuts," Auriemma said. "Hopefully, people are watching and say, 'Why would you want to mess with anything that can be this good?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alana Beard of Duke maneuvering among Connecticut defenders Saturday night in a game that attracted a sellout crowd of 9,314. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: FLORIDA; 
Grief Is Mixed With Worries For Economy On Canaveral

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 2 

 BODY:
A day of worship turned into a day of mourning today as residents of this Space Coast region came to church to pray for the families of the Columbia crew and for their own livelihoods.
 At the Park Avenue Baptist Church in Titusville, the Rev. Richard Lord addressed a congregation of about 1,600 people with a message of unity. He told the worshipers that he had received condolences from church leaders as far away as Ireland. 
 "People all over the world are praying," Mr. Lord said. "God is going to carry us through this."
"We have lost the personal contact with astronauts and with some of the families," he said, but he added, "We have to stand together."
At the First Baptist Church of Merritt Island, the Rev. Curt Dodd pointed out that people here had a special link to the shuttle.
"I pray especially for the family members and the employees of NASA and the contractors involved with the space program," Mr. Dodd said in leading worshipers in prayer. "Many in this congregation have touched with their hands Columbia."
Beyond the emotional toll of the space shuttle loss, many church services touched on the potential for great economic loss for the region. "We are so dependent on the space program," the Rev. Ray Johnson of the First Baptist Church of Titusville told parishioners. "If you want to pray to protect your job, it is O.K. We pray in our weakness that our economic health will be vital."
Indeed, some people said that beyond the thoughts and prayers for the astronauts' families, they were also concerned about the possible economic effects caused by delays in future shuttle launches.
"There is no doubt there will be an impact on the economy," said Bob Hudson, 82, a former owner of The Star Advocate in Titusville, who attended a church service at the First United Methodist Church there. "We felt the impact after the Challenger," Mr. Hudson said of the 1986 explosion of that space shuttle. "We had a recession."
Karen Forester, executive housekeeper at the Holiday Inn in Titusville, said a big part of the hotel's business was from guests who came to watch shuttle launchings. "Most of our revenue is generated from shuttle launches, so if launches were postponed, it would have a huge impact on our business," she said.
At the Kennedy Space Center's visitors complex, thousands of Floridians and vacationers gathered, carrying flowers and heavy hearts. "I am feeling heartbroken," said Larry Kornweiss of Orlando. "I came over here this morning to pay my respects. Things like this bring people closer together. We should work as one and focus on each other."
Dave Sayles of nearby Merritt Island, wearing an American flag emblem on a blue shirt, showed up to play bagpipes at the site of the Astronauts Memorial Foundation, based at the space center. People wept as he played "Amazing Grace." "I just felt I had to do this," Mr. Sayles said, his voice quavering.
Dr. Stephen Feldman, president of the foundation, said a steady stream of mourners had visited the site since the early morning hours. "People are looking for a place to mourn and express their grief," he said.
Valerie Hesser of London, Ontario, sobbed as she looked at the names of the dead astronauts. "We have a daughter that wants to fly the shuttle," she said. "I feel for the families," she added, unable to speak further and hugging her family for support.
Ilyse Gerber of Orlando said he was drawn to the space center to express his grief and added that he wanted the space program to continue. "I hope the space program will move forward without batting an eye so the government can say we are strong."
Rick Schult, a geophysicist at Patrick Air Force Base near here, who had attended a service at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Cape Canaveral, said he and his wife tried to explain the loss to their two young sons. It was the second such conversation since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Mr. Schult said. "We just said that like the airplane that ran into the building, people die and sometimes bad things happen."
At the Prince of Peace Lutheran Church in Orlando, Dave Parsch, the pastor, prayed for the astronauts' families. "We ask God to wrap his arms around them," he said.
Some people said they attended the church services to honor the astronauts for their bravery.
"They were people who sacrificed themselves for the good of mankind," said Marlene Schmidt of Orlando. "They gave their lives to bring something back for us. They sacrificed themselves not only for America but the whole world."

HEADLINE: When a Mantra Against Taxes Starts to Seem Unspeakable 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
In this season of State of the State addresses and budget rollouts, the region's three governors have nothing good to say. They have no money, they will not find more soon, and they have to inflict pain just to keep their governments in business. 
 Govs. George E. Pataki of New York, James E. McGreevey of New Jersey and John G. Rowland of Connecticut are all suffering the damage from the Sept. 11 attack and the battering of the financial services industry, damage made worse by their states' heavy reliance on personal income taxes. 
 At the same time, all three governors have said they will not propose raising taxes.
How each fares under threat of fiscal calamity will tell much about the future of their parties -- Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland are Republicans, Mr. McGreevey is a Democrat -- and about public tolerance for higher taxes. At the least, they will be forced into a discussion that in recent years has frightened politicians even more than voters. That issue is whether, after a spree of tax-cutting in the 1990's, any governor can reverse direction, whether by force of personality or the political skill to make it appear that a tide of protest compelled it. 
Even while 41 states fell short of revenue projections in the last fiscal year, according to the National Governors Association, those nearest New York are more broke than most. The deficit that Mr. Pataki projects for the coming fiscal year is more than 10 percent of the state's current budget; Mr. McGreevey's is about 21 percent; and Mr. Rowland's is 15 percent. Nationwide, the average is 5 percent to 15 percent. 
But even since the last downturn, a decade ago, "there has been a shift in the climate," said Raymond C. Scheppach, the executive director of the governors association. "When I look at the '92 recession, they closed those gaps two-thirds by raising taxes and one-third by cutting spending. Now it looks like the reverse is happening."
In his budget address to the Legislature last week, Mr. Pataki said he refused to consider "job-killing taxes." Mr. McGreevey, who is to announce his budget plan tomorrow, still promises no increase in the income, sales or business taxes -- but last week made several proposals that would cut benefits and tax rebates to high earners. 
Mr. Rowland, who campaigned in 1994 on a promise to eliminate the income tax, startled people by agreeing in December to the "millionaire tax" he vetoed in the spring. Now he threatens to veto a Democratic plan extending the increases to incomes over $50,000. 
So far, the governors would rather shrink their governments. Mr. Pataki's plan cuts deeply into education and health care. Mr. Rowland has already laid off state workers and wants more concessions. Mr. McGreevey promises deeper cuts in government operations across the board, though some administration officials say privately that such reductions cannot come close to bridging the $5 billion budget gap that he projects. 
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland, both running for re-election last year, were reluctant to mention either higher taxes or cuts in services -- which, their critics say, has made the recent reckoning that much tougher. 
"The state's budget gap really emerged last year, but it was papered over," said Frank J. Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute in Albany, a state tax research group. "The governor got through the election without having to talk about it."
Mr. Mauro said that when the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, estimated last summer that the state faced a shortfall of $8 billion to $10 billion in the 2004 fiscal year, administration officials quickly replied that the data was not fully researched. Mr. Bruno, a Republican, "turned out to be uncannily accurate," Mr. Mauro said: the governor's own estimate of next year's deficit is $9.3 billion. 
Mr. McGreevey, meanwhile, having taken office just last year, has had the comparative luxury of pleading poverty at every turn, and blaming his Republican predecessors. Now Republicans accuse the governor of painting doomsday situations to soften the climate for tax increases, and many Democrats as well say he might approve them if he can blame the Legislature.
But legislators, who are all up for re-election this year, are steering clear of the idea. And Mr. McGreevey, like Mr. Pataki, says the solution is not higher taxes but "cutting government to the bone, to its essentials," said his press secretary, Micah Rasmussen. 
"That's what the population wants, isn't it?" said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, a national consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "That's politically the most palatable approach, to cut." 
Public opinion surveys indicate, however, that voters can endorse a tax increase on very high incomes.
In a poll released Thursday by the University of Connecticut Center for Survey Research and Analysis, 78 percent of those surveyed said they supported the Rowland plan, raising the top bracket to 5.5 percent from 4.5 percent on income over $1 million.
A Quinnipiac University poll, released the same day, showed 58 percent of respondents in New Jersey approving higher income taxes on "the wealthy." The governor "doesn't need a poll to tell him he can get away with that," said Clay Richards, the assistant director of the poll. 
The Connecticut proposal and a similar plan circulating in New Jersey would raise no more than a few hundred million dollars a year, where billions are needed. And both states, already highly dependent on millionaires, have fewer than they did a few years ago.
"There are a lot of Republican governors advocating tax increases," said Michael Mazerov, a state tax analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington. "If anything, it seems to me there are more Republican governors recommending tax increases than Democrats."
A few of Mr. Pataki's and Mr. McGreevey's proposals do in effect raise taxes. Governor Pataki wants to eliminate the sales tax exemption on clothing under $110. Mr. McGreevey does not rule out means-testing; last week he proposed an assets test for applicants for a state-subsidized program for prescription drugs and the elimination of property-tax rebates for households making more than $100,000 a year. And his "restructuring" -- he refused to call it an increase -- of the corporate business tax last year nearly doubled payments.

HEADLINE: Behind Walkout by Doctors, Chronic War With Lawyers 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
Mindy Cohen lives a reclusive life marked by fistfuls of painkillers and the drone of daytime television.
 A former school psychologist who lives in Randolph, Ms. Cohen, 47, has been largely bedbound since 1997, when doctors were forced to remove a portion of her thigh after a liposuction procedure went awry. The unceasing pain, the narcotic-induced fog and the crushing depression, she said, make mundane activities nearly impossible. 
 "I desperately miss being out in the world," said Ms. Cohen, who took part in a news conference last week featuring several medical malpractice victims. "I'm just a shell of a person." 
Dr. Elliot Kaplan, a thoracic surgeon in Morristown, endures a different sort of anguish, one brought on by what he and his colleagues describe as a malpractice insurance crisis in New Jersey. He was forced to stop working for a month after malpractice insurers in the state, calling his specialty a magnet for litigation, refused to issue him a policy. When he finally found one last January, his annual premium, $60,000, was 40 percent higher than the previous year's for just a third of the coverage.
With reimbursements from health maintenance organizations and Medicare holding steady or falling, Dr. Kaplan, 44, wonders how much longer he can keep working in New Jersey. "I'm very anxious because I love what I do," he said. "But if there are any more increases, I won't be able to remain in practice." 
The battle between physicians like Dr. Kaplan and lawyers representing patients like Ms. Cohen has been waged in fits and starts for decades. But it will escalate as never before when a one-day walkout on Monday by thousands of doctors across New Jersey leaves private practices shuttered and elective surgeries postponed.
The showdown follows similar strikes by doctors in West Virginia and Nevada that sought to limit what critics say is an explosion of sky-high jury awards that saddle doctors with the cost of turning malpractice victims into millionaires.
President Bush, too, has taken aim at what he describes as "frivolous lawsuits" and is pressing Congress to pass legislation that would limit malpractice awards.
In New Jersey, the war is being waged with sober statistics and emotional claims. Malpractice victims speak of botched procedures and lives destroyed while doctors recite stories of patients, and of lawyers, who are awarded millions of dollars they do not necessarily deserve.
Insurance experts and consumer advocacy groups say that focusing solely on huge awards further muddies a complex problem that requires more than just a $250,000 limit on pain-and-suffering awards, the goal sought by doctors in New Jersey. The entire insurance industry, these experts say, suffers from a chronic malady stemming from the way malpractice insurers invest their premiums, a business model that turns customers into cash machines during economic downturns.
The National Association of Insurance Commissioners counters that insurance companies are prudent investors. A study by the association found that only a quarter of insurance companies' assets were invested in stocks in 2001.
The consumer groups say that the rush to cap awards ignores the problem of medical negligence in America, which accounts for 44,000 to 98,000 preventable deaths a year, according to a 1999 study by the Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences. "The so-called crisis with medical malpractice is another symptom of a health care system that is broken and out of control," said Dena Mottola, acting director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group. "There's a lot of misinformation out there, but whether or not you agree with the numbers, until we fix the underlying problems, nothing will change."
For the moment, medical professionals in New Jersey are united in their belief that aggressive lawyers and greedy patients are to blame for the spike in premiums. Many doctors see their fight against large malpractice payouts as part of a noble stand against freewheeling litigation, an issue that riles many Americans. "It's more than just a medical problem, it's a societal problem," said Dr. Donald Allegra, an infectious-disease specialist in central New Jersey, who said he planned to treat only the most gravely ill patients on Monday. "I've never seen doctors so galvanized by an issue." 
But an unlikely coalition of trial lawyers and consumer watchdog groups say that doctors and insurers are overstating the problem of runaway malpractice payments. Although big headline-grabbing awards have increased, state figures show the overall number of malpractice cases dropped to 1,650 last year, from 1,780 in 1998, a 7 percent decrease that many attribute to a 1995 state law intended to weed out baseless lawsuits. And despite a shift toward bigger awards, the total amount of money paid out to patients rose only 2 percent, to $235 million in 2001, from $231 million in 1998. 
The two sides in the debate over caps disagree over whether they would have a real impact on rising premiums. A study by Medical Liability Monitor, a trade publication, found that premiums in the 25 states with award limits did not decline, although they did rise a little more slowly than in states without them. One exception was California, which has a $250,000 cap, and where premiums have grown only half as fast as the national average. But consumer advocates attribute that to legislation, adopted in 1988, that strictly regulates the insurance industry.
Still, a study commissioned by the Medical Society of New Jersey, which supports Monday's walkout, found that caps alone would reduce premiums by 7 percent. 
In aiming to reduce payouts for pain and suffering, the society is not seeking to limit monetary awards that help an injured patient pay for medical care and provide income lost as a result of a malpractice-related disability. But because such economic damages are partly based on a victim's salary at the time of the injury, consumer groups and lawyers say that the poor, the elderly, women and children tend to receive negligible payments. Their only recourse, the advocates say, is the pain-and-suffering category.
In recent years, such awards in New Jersey have averaged $300,000, Ms. Mottola said. "If you're poor and the victim of malpractice that leaves you disfigured or in chronic pain, you're not going to be living high on the hog with that kind of money," she said.
A medical society spokesman, John Shaffer, said that more and more people are treating the tort system like the lottery. In the late 1990's, one of the state's largest malpractice insurers, Princeton Insurance, reported three to four payments in excess of $1 million each year. Now the company pays out such amounts almost weekly, he said. "There's absolutely no formula for a jury to use when figuring out these awards," he said. "If you can make a jury feel bad for you, you can get $4 million."
Dr. Robert S. Rigolosi, president of the medical society, said that because of this, many doctors are leaving the state and some are retiring early. Countless others, Dr. Rigolosi said, are avoiding performing difficult procedures, a defensive strategy that effectively limits public access to health care.
"These jackpot awards are the problem," he said. "They're sacrificing the health care of millions of people in New Jersey."
The uproar over malpractice insurance rates is not new. Twice before, during recessions in the mid-1970's and mid-1980's, doctors were buffeted by soaring premiums. Although a handful of states addressed the problem, the issue faded away as the economy recovered, insurance company profits rose and premiums stabilized or fell.
Opponents of limits say that doctors, swayed by misinformation from insurers, have overlooked the connection between high premiums and the health of Wall Street. Because companies plow a portion of their premiums into the bond and stock markets, lower investment yields often lead to higher insurance rates.
In New Jersey, the down side of this industry cycle has been compounded by the insolvency of two large insurers and the decision by a third to withdraw from the malpractice market. "The doctors have misdiagnosed the illness and prescribed the wrong cure," said Bruce H. Stern, president of the Trial Lawyers Association of New Jersey. "The real problem is bad business decisions by malpractice insurance companies."
Others say the debate over rising malpractice rates ignores other factors, including sloppy health care and a system in New Jersey that critics say fails to deal with the handful of doctors who commit the lion's share of malpractice. Citing federal statistics, Public Citizen, a consumer group in Washington, said that fewer than 6 percent of all doctors in New Jersey accounted for 60 percent of the state's malpractice payments during the 1990's. Public Citizen and others contend that such "repeat offenders" often go unpunished by state regulators, contributing to the rise in premiums. 
Patients like Ms. Cohen say that pain-and-suffering awards also serve to make doctors more cautious. "It isn't a get-rich-quick scheme," she said. "It's about fairness for people who get harmed."

HEADLINE: WOMEN'S ATHLETICS; 
Staying Power Is Lingering Question

BYLINE:  By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
"No one ever said it was going to be easy," said Lynn Morgan, president and chief executive of the Women's United Soccer Association. "Leagues take time to establish themselves."
 The Women's National Basketball Association is six years old, and the W.U.S.A. is two years old. Now they appear to be at a crossroads, struggling with their evolution from single-entity ownership start-up operations to profitable enterprises. 
 Two W.N.B.A. teams have folded and two have relocated since the N.B.A., which owned and operated the league's teams, voted last October to allow individual ownership. The Miami Sol and the Portland Fire are gone, leaving two dozen players out of work. Next season, the Orlando Miracle will be playing at a casino in Uncasville, Conn., and the Utah Starzz will be playing in San Antonio. 
The players want a new collective bargaining agreement, a pay raise and free agency, and they have threatened to strike if they do not get what they consider a fair deal. W.N.B.A. officials met with the players union last Wednesday to discuss employment issues created by the league's contraction to 14 teams. But the players have voiced displeasure over the pace and the tenor of contract talks.
"A lot has been going on, and the players are certainly concerned about a number of changes over the past few months and how they will impact us," said Sonja Henning, president of the players association and a guard with the Seattle Storm. "The fact that it's now January and we haven't had a meaningful negotiation is also raising concerns."
The W.U.S.A. has its own problems. The league is trying to raise its profile and increase attendance, television ratings and revenue. To cut costs, the W.U.S.A. moved its headquarters from New York to Atlanta last year and streamlined its front office staff. Attendance was down by 15 percent in the second season. Television ratings were so low that the Turner network decided to stop broadcasting games after the first season. The league is in the second season of a two-year deal with Paxson Communications to broadcast games.
"It's no secret that in these times, most professional sports are struggling financially and you don't want to see anyone fold, from women's sports teams to hockey teams to baseball teams," said Tiffeny Milbrett, a forward with the New York Power and the league's most valuable player in 2001. "But you deal with realities, and we understand that the W.U.S.A. is a pioneer for women's sports around the world."
The challenges the W.N.B.A. and W.U.S.A. face have raised questions about the viability of women's summer sports leagues and single-ownership leagues. Neither the W.U.S.A. nor the W.N.B.A. has made a profit.
"The W.N.B.A. made one fundamental error that it has never recovered from by insisting teams play in N.B.A. cities," said Lawrence Gottesdiener, chairman and chief executive of the Northland Investment Corporation. Northland, a real-estate development firm, made a bid to take a W.N.B.A. franchise to Connecticut. Last week, the W.N.B.A. awarded the franchise to the Mohegan Sun casino.
"Those cities have access to myriad sports, including men's basketball," Gottesdiener said of N.B.A. cities. "The league has to go into markets that don't have access to men's pro sports."
But Val Ackerman, the W.N.B.A. president, and Morgan, of the W.U.S.A., said they would not necessarily do things differently if they were starting over.
"We would not have started the league under a different model," Ackerman said. "When we initiated the league we had the right start-up structure and right structure to incubate."
Most sports leagues lose money and most new sports leagues lose a lot of money, Ackerman said.
Morgan said that single-entity ownership "is the right way to go" for a start-up league.
"What you need to do during development is to control costs," she said. "You don't want renegade owners to be part of a start-up, making decisions that may not be in the best interests of the league."
The W.N.B.A. and the W.U.S.A. have exceeded their attendance projections -- 6,000 and 6,500 a game, respectively -- though attendance in each league slipped last season to about 8,500 fans in the W.N.B.A. and to about 6,900 in the W.U.S.A. 
The leagues' problems may be a reflection of the battle for fans and sponsors in a fluctuating economy. Nevertheless, advocates of women's sports worry that any signs of weakness could have a devastating effect on women's professional sports in the United States and abroad.
"Just as it's important for Major League Soccer to be successful for the good of the sport, it's equally important for the W.N.B.A. to be successful for the good of women's sports," Morgan said. "The W.N.B.A. is brave enough and wise enough to know that in order to take that next leap, they've got to make some changes."
Supporters of the W.N.B.A. and the W.U.S.A. say the leagues' troubles may be exaggerated.
There has been attendance erosion and small television ratings, but Milbrett said she thought there might be a simple explanation for the low television ratings for the eight-team W.U.S.A.
"People can't watch the games if they don't know where to find them on TV or when they are on," she said. "To increase the TV ratings, we've got to be able to market the games better and obtain an ideal time slot so we can attract the maximum amount of viewers from our demographic and from regular sports fans."
W.N.B.A. and W.U.S.A. supporters also point to the troubles of the highly promoted XFL, which was gone after one dismal season and millions of dollars in losses. Meanwhile, the the National Women's Football Association, a pro league, will be entering its third season in April.
The National Women's Basketball League, a pro league, begins its third season next week with W.N.B.A. stars like Sue Bird, Tina Thompson, Nikki McCray and Swin Cash. Its season ends in April, before W.N.B.A. training camps start.
Their problems notwithstanding, the W.N.B.A. and the W.U.S.A. are drawing interest from investors who want to acquire franchises. Northland and the Mohegan Sun casino both sought to obtain one of the three defunct W.N.B.A. teams. The rights to the Orlando franchise were sold to the Mohegan tribe, which owns and operates the casino.
Other cities have approached the league about investing in new franchises, league officials said.
That response has convinced Ackerman that the change in ownership direction has put the league on the right track. She said the W.N.B.A. would most likely be back to 16 teams by the 2004 season.
Ackerman said the change in ownership structure would benefit teams "in terms of long-term prospects."
"Teams will have revenue opportunities they didn't have under the original model in the form of expanded local sponsorships," she said.
W.N.B.A. players are scattered around the world and are only beginning to weigh in on the effect the restructuring may have on the league, their lives and livelihood. Pamela M. Wheeler, the union's director of operations, said the change made sense.
"It's indicative of what we believed or thought would happen: that the league would go into markets where it made sense for W.N.B.A. basketball and for the league to be successful," she said.
Henning, the Seattle guard, said the restructuring could give players greater flexibility to market themselves and allow for some form of free agency, issues that have been raised in contract talks.
"Individual owners paying salaries leads right into free agency," Henning said. "The same with marketing rights. With teams given greater opportunity to go out and market teams, players should have better opportunities to go out and recruit sponsors."
There may be difficult days ahead, but Ackerman sees a new day not only for the W.N.B.A. but also for women's sports in general.
"All leagues have to find their own way and restructuring is our way of finding ours," Ackerman said. "We here remain optimistic about the prospect for women's team sports. The interest continues to grow, particularly at the youth level. We're at the apex of our sport. And we still have the N.B.A. behind us."

A sports article on Feb. 3 about financial challenges confronting the Women's National Basketball Association and the Women's United Soccer Association misstated the average attendance for the W.N.B.A. last season. It was 9,228, not 8,500.

HEADLINE: A Time of Mourning for Shattered Dreams; 
Israelis Grieve

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Israel is gripped with the horrendous news about the space shuttle Columbia, the six American astronauts killed and, of course, our own Ilan Ramon -- the first Israeli in space (front page, Feb. 2). 
Our deep involvement in the shuttle mission, through Colonel Ramon and the Tel Aviv University scientific experiments, was a tremendous source of pride in these dark times of terror and recession in Israel. 
 The tragedy was a psychic roller coaster ride, from the heights of pure exhilaration to the depths of shocked, disbelieving grief, all in a space of a few minutes. Israelis shared one collective thought: finally something good happens to us -- and then this! 
 Once again, the fates of America and Israel seem, somehow, to be woven together. We grieve for you -- and you, for us.

DANNY SHAPIRO
Shoham, Israel, Feb. 2, 2003

HEADLINE: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: ISRAEL; 
After Sending an Experiment and a Hero Into Space, Israeli Students Grieve

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: QIRYAT MOTZKIN, Israel, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
The experiment was envisioned as pure science -- how crystals grow in space -- but nothing in Israel is completely sealed off from politics.
 The students at the high school here decided to use cobalt and calcium for their experiment that was put aboard the space shuttle Columbia. Their crystals would be blue and white, the colors of the Israeli flag, an expression of their pride in their country and in its first astronaut, Col. Ilan Ramon. 
 Today, with the delicate crystals lost in white streaks across the blue Texas skies, the students searched for further meaning in the disaster.
"Maybe someone didn't want us to be happy," Dor Zafrir, a 16-year-old in torn jeans and work boots, said of Colonel Ramon's voyage. "No matter what we do, nothing comes up right." The voyage, he said, "was almost the only good thing in Israel."
Israel reeled today from the loss on Saturday of Colonel Ramon, who flew with six Americans aboard Columbia. Flags flew at half staff, and radio stations played the sorrowful ballads that are usually heard in the aftermath of attacks here.
At the beginning of his weekly cabinet meeting, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon sent condolences to the United States. He spoke of Colonel Ramon as "a man who should not have been taken from us so suddenly, along with the hopes, dreams, history and future of all of us, to a place higher than we can realize."
With their hero's homecoming denied in the final minutes of his flight, many Israelis wrestled with a crushing disappointment, and with a more familiar sense of despair. In the newspaper Haaretz, Ari Shavit wrote of "this hope that keeps shattering, the hope of freeing ourselves from our gravitational destiny, of floating in some weightless normalcy in utter disregard of the gravity of our existence."
Students here are accustomed to that gravity. To reach school, they pass through a guarded steel fence, then walk by a memorial to graduates who have died fighting in the army.
Almost four years ago, this school in northern Israel selected about 35 of its students to compete in a NASA program to send high school experiments into space. The students gathered after classes for extra work in astrophysics, as they tried to dream up an experiment worthy of a trip into space. In the end, they wanted to know how crystals would grow if they were freed of gravity. 
NASA picked experiments from six high schools worldwide. Photographs of the Israelis' "chemical garden" sent back from Columbia told the students that their experiment had yielded an intriguing result. While on earth both materials fought gravity to grow upward, in space the calcium crystals grew in the shape of a sphere, while the cobalt "was all messed up, like spaghetti," said Pini Shekhper, 14. Pini and his friends were hoping that when they analyzed the crystals, they would find the reason. 
Today, after students here passed the memorial to fallen graduates and walked into the school's entrance hall, they saw flickering votive candles. The candles were set out beneath pictures cut from newspapers of Columbia's lost crew and of the stunned, aching expression of Colonel Ramon's wife, Rona, when she learned that her husband was not coming home. The colonel, 48, had four children, ages 14, 12, 9 and 5.
"From the heavens, he was supposed to emerge like some sort of messiah," read a poem laid before this memorial.
Members of the scientific team assembled in the office of the principal, Marga Segal. 
On a sheet of black paper, someone had scribbled the word "consolation" in white. The students had then contributed their comforting thoughts -- "for science," "national pride," "role model" and "hero." On a second, white sheet, the word "disaster" was written in black, along with others like "sadness," "injustice" and "sympathy with the families."
The students had met once with Colonel Ramon. "I had a lot of hopes for Ilan and the other astronauts," said Adar Moritz, 17. "It was a disaster for me."
The students were solemn about the shuttle's loss, but they could still tease each other, to bursts of laughter, about their sudden celebrity. At such moments, they seemed like young people anywhere.
But they are young people in Israel, and so they spoke about the national troubles from which the shuttle's voyage and their experiment had distracted them: the miserable economy, Israel's ethnic and religious divides, the conflict with the Palestinians. They spoke about a temptation to leave the country, about a choice between doing what is best for one's family and what is best for one's nation.
Ilana Zibenberg, 16, spoke of the many options that Americans have after high school. "We have to go to the army," she said. "In the army, we lose a lot of friends, mostly boys."
The students wondered if Israel, and Jews, were being singled out for suffering. Some noted that there was also a Jewish astronaut aboard the Challenger when it exploded in 1986.
Many Israelis talked today about coincidence, fate or God, about how a spacecraft carrying the first Israeli astronaut could break up over the town of Palestine, Tex. The journalist Arik Bechar captured this reaction in a column today in Maariv.
"Ilan Ramon fell victim to the same curse that has turned the Israelis into a paranoid people," he wrote. "And how can they be blamed? The representatives of 30 nations have already hitched a ride with the American space fleet, and all of them returned safely to Earth to be able to tell their grandchildren, when the day comes, that the tortured Earth looks much better from afar."
But, Mr. Bechar concluded, "history will remember Ilan Ramon not as the victim of a collective Jewish sin, but as another Israeli pioneer who fell before the camp."
Dor, who gathered members of the science team at his house Saturday night, said: "It makes you doubt your dreams. But you can't give up. Especially with our situation here in Israel, we can't afford to give up."
