HEADLINE: Some Breaks in the Budget For Causes Small and Large 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
At a time of scarce dollars and widespread needs, Edie Mesick plowed through Gov. George E. Pataki's budget proposals last week, prepared to find little assistance for the anti-hunger group she runs and its nutrition program to help needy people get food stamps.
 To her surprise, Ms. Mesick found that Mr. Pataki not only spared her program but also doubled its support to $2 million this year. 
 "We're just plain thrilled," said Ms. Mesick, executive director of the Nutrition Consortium of New York State. "I certainly recognize that there are competing needs, so I don't take anything for granted."
The money for the nutrition program was just one of the unexpected allocations for causes large and small sprinkled throughout Mr. Pataki's three-volume budget last week. Overshadowed by his cuts in education and health care, they included proposals to expand nutrition and day care programs, buy more medicine for AIDS and H.I.V. patients, create tax breaks for high tech businesses and reward residents restoring historic homes in struggling areas.
Mr. Pataki also called for spending at least $80 million on housing and services for residents of adult homes for the mentally ill, as part of a larger effort to overhaul a long-neglected system that has come under recent criticism. 
Most of his proposals were modest in cost, amounting to mere pocket change in a $90.8 billion budget. But in a year when nearly everything else was being scaled back, the budget additions surprised no one more than the special interest groups who had lobbied for them.
"We went through the motions, but to tell you the truth, we didn't expect this to be the year," one longtime lobbyist confided. 
Gay rights advocates found themselves in the unusual position of hearing that they might get more money than they had requested. More than 40 groups had lobbied for a $20 million increase in a program that supplies medicine to AIDS and H.I.V. patients; Mr. Pataki proposed a $49.8 million increase. 
"I can't remember the last time this happened," Ronald Johnson, associate executive director of Gay Men's Health Crisis, said. "It's a bittersweet victory because there are some horrendous cuts in the budget."
The numbers in a governor's budget always provide a road map to his priorities for all to see. In Mr. Pataki's case, it is jobs and the economy, law enforcement and the environment, among other things. 
In less obvious ways, the decisions about who gets what in the budget -- and who is left out -- also reflect a myriad of political factors such as campaign promises, closed-door lobbying, and the opinions of influential aides, legislators and contributors.
"In good years and bad years, there's always good and bad in the budget," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a veteran of 28 state budgets. "It's bare-knuckled politics, that's what it is. There's a whole host of influences on the governor and his staff."
For instance, Mr. Pataki, who ran for re-election last fall, had more reason to care about AIDS financing this year after receiving a key endorsement from the Empire State Pride Agenda, the state's largest gay rights group. Joe Tarver, the group's spokesman, said it raised the issue of AIDS funds with Mr. Pataki in a 2001 meeting. "There was no direct commitment," he said, "but it's always been sort of a subtext."
Mr. Pataki also proposed an income tax credit of up to $50,000 for homeowners who fix up historic properties in distressed areas, after two dozen preservation groups pushed for it through an e-mail and letter-writing campaign last fall. They argued that renovations would mean money for local economies, tapping into one of the governor's favorite themes: economic development.
"This is not about giving money away to preservation, but about generating local economic recovery," said Daniel Mackay of the Preservation League of New York State.
Similarly, the governor proposed tax incentives for small companies that provide high-tech jobs to resuscitate the upstate economy.
In tough times, though, even political alliances may not offer protection. Mr. Pataki has benefited repeatedly from the support of a powerful coalition of health care workers and hospitals led by Dennis Rivera, the president of the 1199/S.E.I.U. union. In 2000 and again last year, Mr. Pataki and the Legislature adopted health care programs that included government subsidies for the health care industry and salary increases for workers. 
This year, Mr. Pataki's budget, while preserving the salary increases, calls for cutting Medicaid funds by more than $1 billion and reinstating an assessment on hospital revenues and home care services. A spokeswoman for Mr. Rivera said the industry would be devastated.
The governor's budget decisions may also reflect more personal interests. Mr. Pataki, an avid outdoorsman, spared environmental programs from drastic cutbacks, even as he proposed a $2.25 fee on new tire purchases, which would raise about $44 million a year for cleaning tire dumps and a tire recycling program. 
Brian Nickerson, director of the Michaelian Institute of Public Policy at Pace University, said that new money for programs -- no matter how small -- can effectively carve out pockets of good will for Mr. Pataki in a difficult year.
"It's actually a really good public relations strategy," he said. "It makes the governor look like a champion if he's able to give even small increments to special areas in times of doom and gloom."
Others said the governor's budget created a system of winners and losers dictated by politics rather than policy.
"When you find these tiny bits of good news, it's not because anyone's made a principled decision to help the aged or infirm," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky. "It's because somebody has a politically powerful protector."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Doctors Hold Back Services In Insurance Protest 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
The doctor was out for patients all across New Jersey today as thousands of physicians stayed away from their offices and hospitals to protest what they consider to be ruinous increases in malpractice insurance rates.
 What had been planned as a one- or two-day protest threatened to stretch on, as organizers of the effort -- the largest of several job actions undertaken by doctors around the country in the past year -- urged physicians to keep refusing to provide most nonemergency care until state officials met their demands for limits on jury awards. 
 "We will continue to see emergency cases, we will continue to do deliveries of pregnant women," said Dr. Robert Rigolosi, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, "but elective cases will not be seen, routine office visits will not be done, routine mammographies will not be done. They will not be done until we can get some meaningful tort reforms." 
Dr. Rigolosi estimated that 70 percent of the state's 22,000 physicians took part. The doctors sought to keep the tone of their protest muted, out of respect for the space shuttle astronauts, but its message of defiance was as clear as the sign carried by a doctor at Christ Hospital in Jersey City: "When your water breaks, call your lawyer."
Doctors managed to respond to emergencies and see seriously ill patients as well as attend rallies at hospitals around the state, where they heard sympathetic legislators promise action on their demand for a limit of $250,000 on pain and suffering awards in malpractice cases. The doctors say they do not want limits on reimbursement for economic losses -- compensation for lost future earnings, essentially -- that result from a doctor's actions.
Today's rallies were a prelude to a march on the State House on Tuesday morning, just two hours before Gov. James E. McGreevey is to deliver his annual budget address. There, organizers said, thousands of doctors will continue their attacks on Mr. McGreevey and other Democrats for refusing to support their legislation, and to hear from doctors from other states, who, Dr. Rigolosi said, will warn them against ending their job action too soon.
There have been similar, limited walkouts in a number of states, including West Virginia, Florida and Nevada. 
The doctors say that sharp increases in malpractice insurance premiums result from excessive jury awards for the pain and suffering claims of patients. The trial lawyers who bring those suits say the increases are a result of insurance companies' efforts to make up their investment losses in the financial markets.
One of the day's largest rallies was at the Shore Medical Center in Neptune, where 800 people, mostly doctors in green surgical garb or white lab coats, denounced the trial lawyers and heard stories of doctors being forced to leave the state in search of lower premiums. Several hundred doctors also rallied at St. Francis Medical Center here in Trenton, where Assemblyman Eric Munoz, a surgeon, said, "If we don't get tort reform now -- well, this is politics, and we'll play politics."
Although several of the day's demonstrations were boisterous -- the police had to separate doctors and a malpractice lawyer in front of the Jersey City courthouse this morning -- medical society leaders said they wanted to keep the events low-key out of respect for the Columbia disaster. In several cities, prayers replaced angry chanting, and many doctors in Bergen County lined up to donate blood after a rally at the Paramus community blood center.
"We had two colleagues on that shuttle, and the president said today was to be a day of mourning, so we wanted to tone it down a little, " said Dan Strechay, a spokesman for the medical society. "But tomorrow we'regoing to be in Trenton, and it's going to be political."
A check of several hospitals found a surge in emergency room admissions today -- as many as two or three times the normal number -- as patients who could not see their own doctors turned to the hospitals. The law requires a report from hospitals when essential emergency services are going unmet, and Dr. Clifton R. Lacy, commissioner of health and senior services, said that no hospital had done so by late afternoon. 
He warned doctors, however, that they could face disciplinary charges if they shirk their responsibilities to patients.
"The Board of Medical Examiners have told me that they take this very seriously, and so do I," Dr. Lacy said. "I believe that a work stoppage adds nothing productive and potentially creates problems of patient access to care."
Governor McGreevey's chief of staff, Jamie Fox, has been dismissive of the doctors. On a New Jersey Network news program on Sunday, he said: "On Monday, they'll be striking. On Tuesday, they're going to march on the State House. And on Wednesday, they're going to play golf."
The doctors recognize that they are attempting a complicated political calculus by trying to win the public to their cause and direct anger toward Trenton. Many doctors believe they can win a popularity contest with lawyers, but some also conceded today that they might anger their patients. 
"We are concerned that pushing hard risks a backlash," said Dr. Jack Tohme, president of the Valley Hospital medical staff in Ridgewood, "but there's no question our cause is just."
Joanna and Led Mendoza, who were waiting to see a doctor for Mrs. Mendoza's nausea and cough in the overcrowded emergency waiting room at Christ Hospital in Jersey City, had no sympathy for the doctors.
"She's in tremendous pain," Mr. Mendoza said. "They should feel the pain of what people are suffering."
Bruce H. Stern, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of New Jersey, also criticized the doctors.
"They think this $250,000 cap for noneconomic damages is fair?" Mr. Stern said in an interview. "Will you tell me that $250,000 is all someone who was made blind is entitled to? Or the woman who had an unnecessary double mastectomy?"
Mr. Stern said the problem should be shifted to the insurers, by placing limits on their premiums.
Dr. Lacy, the health commissioner, said the doctors' focus on limiting certain jury awards was too narrow. He said the McGreevey administration favored having the state subsidize insurance premiums for the most heavily affected specialties, such as neurosurgery and obstetrics.

An article and a picture caption on Tuesday about a slowdown by doctors in New Jersey misstated the name of a hospital in Neptune, N.J., where a large rally was held. It is the Jersey Shore Medical Center, not the Shore Medical Center.

HEADLINE: January Auto Sales Fall 2% As Analysts See Tough Year 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Auto sales dropped 2 percent in January from a year earlier, carmakers reported today, signaling what many analysts say will be a tough year for the industry. Consumers are expected to benefit, though, from a wave of new products, particularly from foreign automakers like Nissan Motor, and cheaper prices because of the competition. 
 Ford sales were up 4 percent, while G.M. sales fell 2 percent and Chrysler sales fell 12 percent. Sales were also down sharply from December as Detroit and particularly General Motors stepped back from lavish end-of-the-year incentives. 
 Analysts said the numbers would have been worse had they not been propped up by sales to fleets, which are less profitable for automakers. One of the most popular vehicles last month was the Buick Century, a staple of rental car fleets; its sales rose 174 percent. 
Product plans disclosed by automakers in the last few days indicated that the industry was ranging widely in its efforts to lure customers.
Ford Motor executives said the company planned to produce fuel-efficient hybrid vehicles for several of its global brands this decade. Ford has already said it will sell a hybrid version of the Escape sport utility, but executives said the company might also build a hybrid Ford sedan and offer hybrid vehicles from the company's Volvo and Mazda units. 
General Motors, meanwhile, said that it would make a pickup version of its Hummer H2 sport utility next year. The company also surprised analysts by announcing that it had four new minivans in the works, though two are replacements of existing models. Minivans have been losing market share. 
Ford executives said the Escape hybrid would be available by the end of the year, as previously announced, but only to government or corporate fleet customers. The general public will have to wait until the middle of next year. Ford said it expected annual sales of 20,000 to 30,000 Escape hybrids. 
Hybrids supplement the internal combustion engine with electric power. While only 150,000 hybrid vehicles have been sold by Toyota Motor and Honda Motor since the late 1990's, they are increasingly figuring in the industry's product lineups. 
General Motors plans to enter the market in 2005 with a hybrid version of the Saturn Vue sport utility; Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, plans to produce a small number of hybrid versions of its Dodge Ram pickup.
"Ford's decision signals that the race is on to be the industry leader in clean-car technology," said Daniel Becker, director of the Sierra Club's program on global warming and energy. 
Chris Theodore, vice president for Ford, Lincoln and Mercury product development, said the company had designed its Escape hybrid system to be easily adaptable to other models. 
"You can plug and play almost -- that's a bit of an exaggeration -- but you can transfer the basic module to other vehicles," he said. 
A hybrid car is not to be confused with the hydrogen cars that President Bush promoted as the automotive technology of the future in his State of the Union address. 
All of the major automakers are working on cars powered by hydrogen fuel cells, which generate electricity through chemical reactions, but they are considered to be years away from mass production. 
"Fuel cells, there is a time factor involved," said Prabhakar Patil, the chief engineer on Ford's Escape hybrid project. "In my estimation, mass production, 100,000 units or higher, is not going to happen for at least another 15 years. Hybrids are ready."
Mr. Patil added that the development of fuel-cell vehicles would be aided by production of hybrids, because both use electric drive systems. 
The Escape will operate much like the existing Toyota Prius. An electric motor will power the vehicle at low speeds, and the gas engine, generally, will take over at 20 miles per hour or more. The vehicle will also use a technology that traps energy used in braking. Ford says that it will get close to 40 miles per gallon in city driving, where the hybrid system is most effective. City mileage in current Escape models ranges from 18 to 23 m.p.g. 
Automakers reported that sales of sport utilities, pickups and minivans -- the crucial profit center for the auto industry -- were sluggish last month. 
Over all, Toyota sales fell 6 percent and Volkswagen sales fell 16 percent, while Honda sales rose 6 percent and Nissan was up 1 percent. 
"It was an O.K. month," said Paul Ballew, the chief industry sales analyst for G.M. "If it were to persist over a quarter, then I would become concerned."
Bill Hopkins, a G.M. dealer in Marianna, Fla., a rural area about 65 miles west of Tallahassee, said the balky economy and tensions in the Middle East had weighed on buyers. 
"It's the uncertainty of the times," he said. And, he added, it was cold last month -- as low as the single digits in his area. With that kind of cold in Florida, Mr. Hopkins said, "we can't function."

Liftoff Damage Is Focus Of Space Shuttle Inquiry

Dittemore, manager of the space shuttle program, went to great lengths to emphasize his personal responsibility for the decisions made and the paths of action chosen since the Columbia's takeoff as he presided over his third press conference since the Columbia broke apart over Texas on Saturday morning. HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: DOMESTIC DEFENSE; 
Ridge Says Request for Homeland Security Is Enough

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that its first complete budget for the Department of Homeland Security, calling for a 7.4 percent increase in spending on domestic security programs, reflected its full support for the department. That assertion immediately came under attack from Congressional Democrats who said the new superagency was being dangerously underfinanced.
 The sharply different assessments of the adequacy of the department's $36.2 billion spending request suggested that the issue of domestic security spending could dominate budget negotiations this year in Congress and become a major issue in next year's presidential campaign. 
 "The president has requested a budget which reflects his continuing and very clear commitment to standing behind the priorities and the mission for the new department," said Tom Ridge, who was sworn in last month as the first secretary of homeland security. "We're building a foundation." 
But Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, who has been designated by fellow Senate Democrats as a spokesman on domestic security, said in an interview that the budget was clearly inadequate and reflected the "quirky notion of the White House that you can improve homeland security without spending the dollars. It makes no sense."
The department went into business two weeks ago and will eventually consolidate 22 federal agencies, including the Customs Service, the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Secret Service and the Border Patrol, and more than 170,000 employees.
The White House budget sharply increases spending on a handful of the agencies and programs that are being incorporated into the new department, especially the Coast Guard, which would receive an extra $600 million next year, much of it directed to overhaul the aging fleet.
Spending for programs labeled "information analysis and infrastructure protection," including the department's intelligence division, would more than triple, to $829 million next year.
But spending among agencies elsewhere in the department would increase far more modestly, and some domestic security programs face budget cuts in the new fiscal year. Overall spending for border and transportation security would drop by about 1.5 percent, to $18.1 billion, in part reflecting the one-time start-up costs this year of the Transportation Security Administration.
Budget specialists in and out of government say that the spending figures for domestic security programs -- and for the new department -- are difficult to analyze, since so many of the programs did not exist before the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, and have been created within so many different agencies of the federal government.
But according to the figures released today by the White House, the budget for all domestic defense programs, including those within the Pentagon and the Department of Health and Human Services, would increase by about 10 percent next year, to $41.3 billion, a figure that includes the budget of the Homeland Security Department.
Several private analysts said that the budget requested by the White House reflected only a modest increase in spending on the domestic war on terrorism.
"It's largely flat," said Steven M. Kosiak of the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments. "To be fair to the administration, it's not clear that the kind of massive increases we had seen over the last couple of years would be necessary again next year, but it does raise concerns about whether there will have to be a trade-off between domestic security and other government priorities."
At a news conference today to discuss the spending request, Mr. Ridge acknowledged that the budget would not satisfy some Democratic lawmakers and other critics of the Bush administration who have called for a far larger budget for his agency.
But he suggested that a sharper increase next year would not necessarily improve the department's performance, especially not in the first months of the its existence.
"We have to be very, very focused on outcomes," Mr. Ridge said. "Some people in this town might think you construct a 10-story building by starting on the 10th floor. This is a long, difficult, challenging process. We're building a foundation, and this budget gives us a chance to move up and do just that."
In a study released last month by the Brookings Institution, a panel that included members of the Clinton administration recommended a total domestic security budget of $45 billion next year, almost $4 billion more than the Bush administration.
Mr. Schumer said an initial Democratic analysis of the White House budget showed that the administration was engaged in accounting gimmickry, and that spending for some crucial domestic security programs was actually being cut.
He said the Democratic analysis showed that, with inflation factored in, spending on customs and border protection would increase by only $52 million next year, a 1 percent increase. "There's almost a schizophrenia," he said. "This White House will spend almost anything we need to support the war on terrorism overseas, but they will actually spend fewer dollars than last year on homeland security."
Mr. Schumer said that he believed that the domestic security budget would be "one of the two or three major issues on the Hill this year" and would be seized on by Democrats who are seeking the party's presidential nomination next year.
Several of the early Democratic candidates for the White House, including Senators Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and John Edwards of North Carolina, have repeatedly accused the Bush administration of failing to devote enough money to domestic security programs.

HEADLINE: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: FLORIDA; 
A Region Where Fortunes Rise and Fall With NASA

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Workers here in the Space Coast region of central Florida returned to their jobs today for the first time since the shuttle disaster, with many worrying how it would affect the local economy even as they mourned the loss of the Columbia's crew.
 Nearly everyone here recalls the slump that followed the destruction of the shuttle Challenger 17 years ago. Shuttle launchings were suspended for more than two years, leading to mass layoffs and business closings, and many fear that may happen again. 
 "A lot of people who worked at the Space Center during Challenger lost their jobs and their homes," said Melissa Fortier-Sherbin, who is on the board of the Titusville Chamber of Commerce. "Every family I knew felt some sort of impact. My mom's business had to close, and my father lost his job after a while. He worked for the company that made the O-rings." 
The Kennedy Space Center is the pride of the Space Coast region, about 40 miles east of Orlando, and its economic mainstay. People here listen for the sonic booms when they know a shuttle is scheduled to come home. And they count on the launchings and landings to support the local economy.
About 15,000 people work at the Kennedy Space Center, with only about 1,600 of them NASA employees, according to the agency's public affairs department. Contractors and subcontractors employ the bulk of the work force, with relatively high-paying, stable jobs. These businesses would suffer a huge blow from a weakened space program, and so would the local tourism industry.
"We are keenly aware that after the Challenger tragedy that two to three years had an impact," said Sam Gutierrez, a spokesman for Space Gateway Support, which provides services like road maintenance to the space center. "We hope that does not occur again."
Economists and tourism experts say it is too soon to know how the economic landscape may change, but they note that the longer NASA suspends regular shuttle launchings, the more difficult it will be.
"A lot of people will be unemployed if the shuttles are grounded for a long period of time," said Antonio Jorge, economics professor at Florida International University. Some businesses diversified and sought other customers after the Challenger disaster, but nothing can completely replace the space program in the region.
"If it's going to be grounded for years, it will be a major disaster for the area," Professor Jorge said.
Florida has one of the strongest economies in the nation. While the job market in most of the country has continued to worsen over the last year, Florida's has improved. Its unemployment rate fell to 5.3 percent in December from 6 percent a year earlier, according to the Labor Department. In that period Florida gained 64,300 jobs, more than any other state.
The state's economy has been buoyed in part by a robust health-care industry serving its many elderly citizens. And because Florida's manufacturing base is relatively small, it has been less affected by the layoffs and plant closings that haunt other states. But the area around Cape Canaveral has not fared quite so well as the rest of the state.
It lost about 1.9 percent of its jobs between December 2001 and December 2002, making its economy look more like the rest of the country's, according to the Florida Agency for Workforce Innovation. Like Orlando's, the region'stourism business fell off after the 2001 terrorism attacks and was slow to recover.
The average income in Brevard County, which includes Cape Canaveral, is about $32,800, the Economic Development Commission of the Florida Space Coast has reported. So the evaporation of 100 jobs would total about $3.3 million in lost wages. By some estimates, as much as $61 million -- 1 percent of the county's estimated $6.1 billion annual payroll -- could disappear in a significant layoff, the commission said.
Gov. Jeb Bush acknowledged today that there would be "some negative impact" on the local economy and added that he had told NASA officials that the communities around the Kennedy Space Center could not afford a two-and-a-half year hiatus of the space program.
"They are very cognizant of that," Governor Bush said, speaking to reporters at Apopka Elementary School in Apopka near Orlando. "The state is prepared to do whatever it can to deal with a slowdown if it happens, including job-training programs," Mr. Bush added.
Some experts say that because many businesses diversified after the Challenger loss, the area is better prepared to absorb a NASA-related downturn. 
"The economy was much more dependent on the space program then than it is now," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "It's still the largest employer there, but unless NASA shuts down and doesn't conduct any more activity, it shouldn't be a big problem out there."
That is little comfort to Brenda Mulberry, whose business depends on tourists who come to see the space shuttle launchings. 
"We'll be busy for now and then we'll drop like a brick," said Ms. Mulberry, owner of Space Shirts, a company that prints space-related apparel and is two miles south of the space center gate. "I'm worried because I have seven employees, and I don't want to lay them off."
Ms. Mulberry's concerns were echoed by people in bars, restaurants and cafes throughout the region.
"Most people here are involved in the space program," said Sara McCandless, manager, Dunkin' Donuts in nearby Titusville. "They're remembering what happened last time and are scared that's going to happen again."
Paul Salisbury, owner of Paul's Smokehouse Restaurant & Lounge in Titusville, is worried, too. His business is just a few miles from the space center, and offers a clear view of shuttle launchings. Mr. Salisbury estimates that two thirds of his business comes from tourists and NASA-related employees.
The local business "pays the bills" Mr. Salisbury said, and the tourist business provides his profits. "We have a full house during any launch, and a buildup up two weeks in advance," Ms. Salisbury said. "If we don't continue to launch, it has a direct effect on our business."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sara McCandless, a Dunkin' Donuts manager in Titusville, said most people in the area had ties to NASA.; In Titusville, near Cape Canaveral, Sandy Yetter served vacationers, Earl Gausman, left, and June Patrick. (Photographs by Gregg Matthews for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gays Respond Quickly to Killings in Cape Town 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
The bodies are gone, but blood still stains the wooden floors at 7 Graham Road. For two weeks now, dozens of mourners have come here to weep and leave flowers in memory of the nine gay men who were killed in an attack on the massage parlor.
 The massacre was front-page news and the story is now well known: on Jan. 20, killers believed to be looking for two gay prostitutes involved in a drug deal entered the massage parlor and shot everyone inside, execution style, even though they could not find the prostitutes they were looking for. Some of the men had their throats slit and their hands bound with tape. 
 What is less commonly known is how gay people here rallied to speed the investigation and to help the families of the dead. Within hours of the killings, the Triangle Project, which counsels gay and lesbian clients, was passing along tips to the police and extending its counseling hours.
The killings of the men -- who were all white and were mostly in their 20's -- have outraged this city known for its tolerance and diversity. Cape Town, the lovely, mountain-ringed city on the southernmost tip of the continent, has even been marketed in recent years to gay tourists from Europe and the United States who flock here for the beautiful scenery and lively night life.
Many of the young men killed were runaways who worked as prostitutes in the white house on Graham Road in Sea Point, a seaside neighborhood that has been increasingly plagued with drugs and crime. Initially, advocates for gay people feared that the victims would be ignored because of their jobs in the sex industry and because the killing was linked to the drug trade. 
But that has not happened. Good Hope Metropolitan Community Church, which ministers to a predominantly gay congregation, has raised money to cover funeral costs for one of the victims, whose family was struggling to pay for his burial. 
The Lesbian and Gay Equality Project, which works for social and economic equality, has put the police sketches of two suspects on its Web site. Hundreds of people, including local politicians in the governing African National Congress, attended memorial services around the city to honor the dead.
"I was surprised by the extent of the response," said Evert Knoesen, national director of the Lesbian and Gay Equality Project. "It was overwhelming. 
"I think men in the gay community are able to understand the difficulties faced by young gay men in a society where poverty is rife and are far more sympathetic to the plight of sex workers generally," he said. "I think people did identify this as an attack on the gay community. People want this thing to be cleared up. They want to know that it's safe to be out there."
The police have worked hard on the investigation and have opened channels of communication, handing the cellphone numbers of senior officials to advocacy and service organizations. Leaders in local government have promised to fight crime more aggressively in the Sea Point community.
"The police have been so receptive to us," said Glenn de Swardt, the manager of clinical services at the Triangle Project. "These guys were sex workers, but they also have partners. They also have mothers. They also have friends. People have really come together around this."
No one has been arrested yet and the police are still struggling to sort out exactly what happened. Investigators are looking for two suspects -- one white and one mixed-race -- between the ages of 25 and 35. The police have said the killings seem to have occurred when the angry killers could not find the drug-dealing prostitutes they were looking for. But detectives are investigating additional leads, which they refuse to discuss.
Relatives of the owner of the massage parlor, Aubrey Otgaar, are maintaining hope that the killers will be caught and put to justice. They are still mourning Mr. Otgaar, who was 56 and, they say, refused to allow drugs to be used in his business.
Mr. Otgaar's relatives said they were wary of politicians getting involved in the memorial services, but they welcomed the outpouring of support from other people.
"It surprised us, how people from all walks of life came out to support us," said Cheryl Cunningham, Mr. Otgaar's sister.
Lauren Cunningham, Mr. Otgaar's niece, said she was particularly touched by the flowers that were tucked in the white picket fence outside the massage parlor on Graham Road. "People came every day," she said. "There was always someone interested in watering the flowers."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fanus Fouche, left, and Juan Meyer, right, were among the gay men killed by gunmen on Jan. 20 at a massage parlor in Cape Town. (Photographs from Die Burger)

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE OUTLAYS; 
From Fuel Cell Cars to Slaughterhouse Inspection: Where the Money Goes

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Department of State
The State Department budget includes substantial increases for treating AIDS, rebuilding Afghanistan and assisting poor countries that institute economic and political reforms. 
 But it pays for many of those increases by trimming other programs, including development aid to countries in Central Europe and Latin America. Over all, the plan calls for an increase of $2.9 billion, or 11 percent, for international affairs, to $28.5 billion, State Department officials said. 
 The budget includes four new initiatives: $1.3 billion for the Millennium Challenge Account, for poor countries that fight corruption and encourage economic and political freedoms; $450 million to combat AIDS, particularly in Africa and the Caribbean; $200 million in emergency food assistance; and $145 million to encourage democratic institutions in Arab countries.
The administration, which has been criticized for failing to invest more heavily in the reconstruction of Afghanistan, included at least $500 million for such programs, including $150 million to equip a national army there. 
To help pay for the new programs, assistance to the independent states of the former Soviet Union, for example, would fall to $576 million from $755 million. Russia alone would lose $75 million under the plan. 
The budget would also cut money for international peacekeeping operations, to $550 million from $725 million. And it eliminates $25 million in annual aid to Iraqi opposition groups, underscoring the administration's confidence that President Saddam Hussein will be removed by October, when the 2004 fiscal year begins. JAMES DAO

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: White Plains: Home Prices Rise In Westchester 

BYLINE:  By Stacy Albin (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Despite a troubled economy, prices for existing homes rose sharply last year in Westchester and Putnam Counties. 
In Westchester, the average cost of a single-family home rose to $525,000, up about 17 percent from the previous year, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service, a realty group. In Putnam, homes sold for an average of $305,000, up about 21 percent. P. Gilbert Mercurio, the chief executive officer of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said that demand remained high because of a limited stock and because the houses were less than one hour's commuting distance from Manhattan. Stacy Albin (NYT)

HEADLINE: Front Row 

BYLINE:  By Ruth La Ferla 

 BODY:
Insiders' Insider, for the Best Seats
 Fashion has its share of master puppeteers, adept at pulling the strings that jerk events into motion. One of the most skillful is Pierre Rougier, a publicist whose nod assures insiders tickets to the hottest shows of Fashion Week, which opens in New York on Friday. 
 Mr. Rougier represents Nicolas Ghesquiere, the designer for Balenciaga, who presents his fall collection on Feb. 13 at an undisclosed location. About 200 guests are expected to rub flanks and strain in unison for a front-row glimpse of Asia Argento, the actress who is Mr. Ghesquiere's friend and sometime muse, or Nicole Kidman, whom the designer has also dressed. Neither Ms. Argento nor Ms. Kidman has confirmed attendance. 
Another of Mr. Rougier's clients, Proenza Schouler, will show on Feb. 12 at the National Arts Club. The club admits 120 guests, compared with 1,000 or more accommodated by the largest of the tents at Bryant Park, the official setting for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, leaving hundreds of others out in the cold. Will some be miffed? You bet. "Shows with limited seating create a kerfuffle about who's in and who's out," said Sally Singer, an editor at Vogue, who counts herself on the in-list.
Such tactics are calculated "to drive people crazy," said Fern Mallis, executive director of Seventh on Sixth, which produces Fashion Week. Another source of her ire is the scheduling of the Proenza Schouler show at 5 p.m., a slot reserved by Ms. Mallis for a Seventh Avenue veteran, Donald Deal. "Proenza will just have to move," Ms. Mallis said. "Why not? They haven't sent out their tickets." Mr. Rougier said he would not move the show. 
He never intended to gum up the calendar, Mr. Rougier said, or send the uninvited to their analysts to work through feelings of rejection. He conceded that limiting the size of shows creates a "certain furor." Not that he is gloating. The glare of the spotlight has Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, the designers for Proenza Schouler, feeling "quite stressed," Mr. Hernandez said. "We are feeling the pressure to develop a fashion signature," he said, adding that the collection will "play with the idea of contradiction, showing matte fabrics versus shiny, and layering cashmere and a lot of classic fabrics." 
Classicism tweaked with whimsy is also the signature of Palmer Jones, a line designed by 24-year-old identical twins, Kathryn and Lindy, who are both former design assistants to Ralph Lauren. Their presentation on Sunday at Christie's in Rockefeller Center will be built on tailored pieces leavened with wit -- as in a blue velvet jacket embroidered with magpies toting Swarovski crystals in their beaks. 
Theirs is a playful but polished style that, for Ms. Singer of Vogue, signals a return to elegance. "In this economy people want value for money," Ms. Singer said. "That means good tailoring in a dress you can wear a few years."
Influential retailers will also scrutinize the collections for signs of a ladylike silhouette. "I'm looking for elegance, but with a little bit of punch," said Linda Dresner, who caters to an upscale clientele. Referring to last year's surfeit of bondage and paramilitary influence, Jeffrey Kalinksy of Jeffrey New York chimed in: "I'm hoping to see something less aggressive. Show me something with a bunch of buckles on it, and I could care less."

Ryder Chosen by Jacobs
Was it only three months ago that Winona Ryder mesmerized Americans at her shoplifting trial, in part because of the chic Marc Jacobs outfits she sometimes wore to court? One person who noticed was Mr. Jacobs, among fashion's leading provocateurs, who has cast Ms. Ryder in his spring advertising campaign. 
Ms. Ryder was convicted of stealing $5,560 worth of goods from Saks Fifth Avenue, including a Marc Jacobs sweater priced at $760. 
Yesterday, Mr. Jacobs was quoted by Women's Wear Daily asserting that he was inspired to use Ms. Ryder "because I thought she looked so beautiful in all these pictures that we've seen recently," both at the trial and elsewhere. The ads, photographed by Juergen Teller, show the actress lounging in a posh hotel room clad in a white robe and pale pumps by Mr. Jacobs, one of the designer's handbags propped at her feet.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Front Row column of the Fashion page on Tuesday about preparations for New York Fashion Week referred incorrectly to the twins who design the Palmer Jones line. Only one, Kathryn Jones, was formerly an assistant to Ralph Lauren; her sister, Lindy Jones, was not.
The report also misstated the sisters' ages. They are 38, not 24.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: ECONOMIC ASSUMPTIONS; 
Projection of Economy Takes a Cautious View

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Compared with President Bush's nearly euphoric budget two years ago, the one the president put forward today was a splash of cold water.
 The White House's economic outlook, which provides a crucial basis for its budget projections, assumes that growth this year will be uninspiring, that unemployment will barely decline either this year or next and that tax revenues will be nearly stagnant. 
 The outlook is in some ways more cautious than those of private economists. Between that caution and the impact of Mr. Bush's big tax-cutting proposals, the White House predicted today that the federal government would run up an accumulated deficit of $1.08 trillion by the end of 2008. 
That is a stunning deterioration from just two years ago, when President Bush predicted a $5.6 trillion surplus over 10 years. But by not using overly optimistic assumptions to make the long-run numbers look better, Mr. Bush won some praise for candor.
"At a stroke, the new White House budget forecasts have shifted from utterly implausible to realistic," said Ian Shepherdson, a senior economist at High-Frequency Economics, a forecasting and consulting firm.
Other analysts disagree, noting that the administration provided only a five-year projection for the budget as a whole and that some of Mr. Bush's tax cuts will not affect the budget until several years later.
The budget does not include extra money for a possible war in Iraq, though White House officials restated today that Mr. Bush would immediately ask for extra money in a supplemental appropriation if a war did take place. Indeed, the White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., said last Thursday that the administration might ask for more military money even if there was no war in Iraq.
The budget also leaves out the cost of changing the alternative minimum tax, something that Mr. Bush has not formally proposed but that Republicans and Democrats agree is needed to prevent millions of families from facing sharply higher taxes in the years ahead as their higher incomes qualify them for the tax. 
A change in the alternative minimum tax could cost about $500 billion over the next 10 years, some analysts say.
In the past, overly optimistic assumptions about economic growth have often been an important tool for budgetary mischief because they allow a president to assume the existence of more tax revenue and avoid making painful trade-offs among favored goals.
The economic assumptions this year are not especially optimistic.
The budget assumes that economic growth will be 2.9 percent this year, weak for a country coming out of a recession but in line with private forecasts. Growth is projected to climb to 3.6 percent in 2004, which is slightly more optimistic than the Congressional Budget Office but in line with private forecasts. 
The White House was even more cautious in predicting tax revenues, which it said would decline slightly in 2003 and climb only modestly in 2004.
The budget assumes that unemployment, which is stuck at 6 percent, will remain at 5.9 percent this year and drop only slowly after that. Even at the end of five years, the administration estimated, joblessness would still be 5.1 percent, well above the low levels reached at the peak of the last economic boom.
The predicted upshot is that the federal deficit will hit a record of $304 billion in 2003 and climb to $307 billion in 2004. Though the deficit would decline after that, it would still be $190 billion in 2008. 
The contrast with two years ago could not be starker. Then, as now, President Bush was proposing big tax cuts to stimulate the economy. But in 2001, Mr. Bush assumed that the good times of the late 1990's would continue more or less uninterrupted and that the government faced a future of surpluses as far as the eye could see.
Mr. Bush's current budget implies a significant gamble.
Though White House officials are loath to draw comparisons, the combination of tax cuts and spending increases and projected deficits are at least as radical as those of President Ronald Reagan's 1981 "riverboat gamble," the budget characterization immortalized by Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, then the Republican majority leader.
What few lawmakers or administration officials like to discuss, however, is that skyrocketing deficits forced Mr. Reagan to swallow tax increases a few years later. The first President Bush, in a decision that many Republicans still regret, felt compelled to agree to further tax increases as the deficit set records in the early 1990's.
White House officials say times have changed. Today's deficits, they say, are still less than 3 percent of gross domestic product, in contrast to 5 percent under President Reagan and 6 percent in the last year of the first Bush presidency.
 Looked at another way, they say, the deficits are easily affordable. Interest payments on the national debt make up only 8 percent of government spending. In the heyday of deficits, they were about 15 percent.
But administration officials have doggedly refused to answer the question of how big a deficit has to be before it ceases to become manageable and starts to become alarming.
"I don't know," Mr. Daniels, the budget director, said today. "All I can say is that if you look at history and you take in the context, we're not there now, or close."

HEADLINE: Mattel's Profit Is Up by 35%, Led by Sales Of Barbies 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Mattel Inc., the world's largest toymaker, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 35 percent after the company reduced costs and increased sales of Barbie dolls in the United States for the first time in at least two years.
 Net income climbed to $186.1 million, or 42 cents a share, from $138 million, or 31 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales increased 6.9 percent, to $1.67 billion. 
 Barbie sales in the United States climbed 9 percent, led by new products like Barbie as Rapunzel and My Scene Barbie dolls. Robert Eckert, Mattel's chief executive, is extending Mattel's traditional lines by introducing variations like the new Barbies and Chicken Dance Elmo. He is also expanding Mattel's sales outside the United States and has widened margins by reducing inventory and paring packaging costs.
"They are doing a lot of things to make operations more efficient," said Mark Greenberg, the manager of the Invesco Leisure Fund, which holds Mattel shares. "Toys aren't a high-growth business."
Excluding $25.4 million in pretax costs to settle suits tied to the 1999 purchase of the Learning Company, Mattel said it would have earned $190.3 million, or 43 cents a share. On that basis, Mattel was expected to earn 38 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call.
Shares of Mattel, based in El Segundo, rose $1.03, or 5.2 percent, to $21.03.
Mr. Eckert said he expected the retail environment that led to store closings and the reorganization of companies like Kmart to continue this year. Retailers' holiday sales at stores open at least a year showed the smallest gains in about three decades as consumers concerned about the economy pared spending.
Mattel will stop giving earnings forecasts, Mr. Eckert said on a conference call with investors, after reiterating the company's goal of increasing profit by at least 10 percent.
"The whole area around guidance has become a matter of principle for me," he said.
Coca-Cola and the McDonald's have also said they will stop providing forecasts so that they can concentrate on longer-term objectives to enhance growth.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE AGENDA; 
Laying Out 'Big Ideas,' Not Balancing Ledger

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
When all the proposals are tallied in the budget President Bush submitted today, they amount to the most ambitious changes in government operations that any president has put forward in decades.
 Beyond its scope, the budget differs from those of other recent presidents in two important ways. Nowhere does Mr. Bush make balancing the budget an important goal. And he makes no claim that the era of big government is over, or even nearing an end. 
 "This is a president of big projects and big ideas," his budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., said today. 
Contrast that with the assertion of Mr. Bush's father in his inaugural address in 1989 that "we have more will than wallet."
Paying no heed to the notion of a balanced budget, Mr. Bush advocates deep tax cuts on top of the large ones enacted two years ago. By contrast, when big deficits began to appear after President Ronald Reagan drove tax cuts through Congress in 1981, Mr. Reagan approved offsetting tax increases.
Mr. Bush proposes adding a Medicare entitlement, prescription drug coverage. But he also proposes enticing retirees into private insurance plans, a big step that other Republican presidents have surely dreamed of but never taken. He also wants to change Medicaid so that many poor people, including some in nursing homes, will no longer be guaranteed benefits.
The president proposes doubling spending next year for domestic security, including new money for the largest new federal department since the Defense Department was created after World War II. Military spending would rise sharply over the next five years. Much of the new money would be spent for disputable initiatives like a missile defense system and futuristic ships.
All this does not take account of the billions of dollars that would be needed to fight a war against Iraq. And it does not assume any big changes in Social Security, despite the president's call in his State of the Union address last week to make Social Security more like a private pension.
Except for the first two years of Bill Clinton's presidency, this is the first time in more than 20 years that a budget has been submitted for a fiscal year in which both houses of Congress will be controlled by the president's party.
No doubt, that will be an advantage for Mr. Bush. No one is saying this budget is dead on arrival, the term given to most of the budgets offered by Mr. Bush's three most recent predecessors, who generally faced at least one house of Congress controlled by the opposition party.
In his first two years in the White House, when he did have a Democratic Congress, Mr. Clinton failed miserably when he tried to push a few ambitious measures, most notably his plan for universal health insurance. Congress, it was widely said at the time, could not deal with such an extensive undertaking.
Partly as a consequence, Republicans won the House and Senate in the 1994 elections. For the rest of his presidency, Mr. Clinton limited his budget requests to bite-size pieces like encouraging schoolchildren to wear uniforms and cracking down on deadbeat fathers.
This downsizing of presidential ambition proved to be popular politically, and Mr. Clinton was re-elected with ease.
Of course, it is impossible to say whether Mr. Bush will be thwarted by Congressional overload. If the country goes to war, Congress might be too distracted to deal with his bold plans. Or the distraction could mean that some proposals that are not particularly popular could slip through without much attention being paid.
The early line is that Congress will initially balk at the president's spending priorities -- large spending increases for the military, domestic security and veterans and not much new money for anything else -- but eventually adopt the priorities more or less intact.
Taxes are another matter. Some form of tax reduction will probably be adopted. And it will probably be sufficiently like what the president proposed that he can call it the Bush tax cut when he runs for re-election next year.
But the centerpiece of his proposal, an elimination of the income tax for individuals on most stock dividends, has been received with little enthusiasm in Congress. Interviews with a range of lawmakers found none willing to say they thought that this was the best way to use the $364 billion that Mr. Bush wants to allot for the cut.
It is too early to gauge the Congressional response to plans disclosed late last week for new forms of savings accounts in which money would accumulate tax-free and be available for withdrawal without penalty. 
The details of the president's Medicare proposal have not been completed. But even without prescription drug coverage, Medicare is, along with Social Security, the most popular government program ever devised. Any president who tries to dismantle it is taking a huge risk.
Mr. Bush apparently has no intention of pushing any time soon for one of his boldest plans -- allowing workers to use part of their Social Security taxes to set up private investment accounts. That would cost hundreds of billions of dollars over the first few years alone, and the new budget has no money set aside for the next five years.
Mr. Daniels said this morning, "A balanced federal budget remains a high priority for this president." But unlike the submissions of recent predecessors, this budget describes no plans to reach that goal.
In all the years when large deficits were a fact of life, Republican politicians and conservative economists could advocate a balanced budget with no hope that the goal would be reached but confident that steps in that direction would lead to less government spending.
But when surpluses began to appear in the late 1990's, these politicians and economists became less enamored of the concept of balance, and Mr. Bush apparently was no exception.
"It is wrong to build surpluses, because these surpluses lead to higher spending," said John F. Cogan, a top budget official in the Reagan and first Bush administrations who is now an economist at the Hoover Institution. "Governments cannot hang onto money."
Representative Jim Nussle, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, made a similar point. The goal of a balanced budget, Mr. Nussle said, is no longer the "holy grail" that it once was.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bloomberg Goes to Albany, Hat in Hand, and Gets Shrug 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came here today to make one of the most important presentations of his 13 months in office, calling on New York State to help save New York City at the time of its worst fiscal crisis since the 1970's.
 But if the mayor was hoping for any promises, he came away disappointed. 
 In their own ways, each of the three powers that control state government reacted coolly to Mr. Bloomberg's pitch, made during a joint legislative hearing and later in private meetings with lawmakers.
Republicans in the Senate made it clear that they remained adamantlyopposed to the mayor's central request, the reimposition of a commuter tax. So did Gov. George E. Pataki, the mayor's friend and ally. And while Assembly Democrats said they would support some form of commuter tax, they took the mayor to task for being too soft on the governor in his fight for more help for the city. 
Mr. Bloomberg, for his part, praised Governor Pataki at every turn, even as he complained that the state budget that the governor proposed last week would hurt New York City. 
He said that the governor's budget would force 44,000 of New York City's 4-year-olds from their prekindergarten classes, eliminate 1,900 teaching jobs and add to the crushing amount the city spends on health care. He also said that the city had already been counting on much of the aid that the governor pledged to get for the city from state-controlled authorities, like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Battery Park City Authority.
Even when questioned by the joint committee of the Assembly and the Senate, Mayor Bloomberg refrained from putting a dollar figure on how much money Mr. Pataki's budget would cost his city. Some budget monitors have said that Mr. Pataki's budget proposal could cost New York City as much as $2 billion, a figure the governor disputed today at a news conference in which he defended his budget plan. 
After Mr. Bloomberg finished testifying, reporters asked why he did not criticize Mr. Pataki.
"I'd rather have this governor as governor than anybody else," he said.
He proclaims himself optimistic that he will reach a resolution: "I think we'll work something out."
For mayors of New York City, the trip up the Hudson to testify about the state budget is an annual rite of winter. But with the city and state facing such serious projected deficits -- $3.4 billion next year for the city, and $9.3 billion for the state (cumulatively $11.5 billion over two years) -- it was an especially critical trip this year.
Now that Mayor Bloomberg has cut city spending by $2.6 billion and raised property taxes by 18.5 percent, he is counting on the state to close much of the remaining gap by imposing a commuter tax, giving more education aid, and allowing new tolls, among other things.
Some lawmakers held out hope that, while the mayor's new proposal to alter the income tax and raise the rate to 2.7 percent would not fly in Albany, there might be support for a return to the 0.45 percent tax on commuters to the city, which was repealed in 1999.
But the politics of the day were unusual. Mr. Bloomberg, a Democrat turned Republican, got perhaps his warmest welcome from Democrats in the Assembly, who said they supported some form of commuter tax and that they would fight the governor's plan to cut aid to city schools, welfare and health care.
But Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver complained that Mr. Bloomberg was not a forceful enough advocate for the city. Mr. Silver, a Democrat who represents Lower Manhattan, said the mayor had missed an opportunity by failing to get commitments of help from Governor Pataki before he was re-elected in November.
"I think it's time for him to say: 'If this money isn't there, it is clearly removed by the governor of this state. Period,' " Mr. Silver said after meeting with the mayor.
He went on to mimic, with some accuracy, the mayor's standard response to questions about state aid for the city.
"It should not be, 'Well, this document, that's a negotiating document, right now doesn't contain it, but I'm hopeful that the governor and the majority leader with the speaker in the end will provide the resources so that we can continue to educate children,' " he said.
The mayor got a cooler reception from the Republican-controlled Senate on the commuter tax, even has he continued to make the case that New York State, New Jersey, Yonkers and many other places tax commuters at the same rate as residents. The mayor's budget relies on $1 billion in revenues from changing the laws so that income taxes are based on where an employee works, not where he lives. 
During the joint legislative hearing, Mr. Bloomberg sparred over the commuter tax with State Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Nassau County Republican whom the mayor took on his private plane to Greece last year. Mr. Skelos protested that taxes were already high in the suburbs, and said no one was trying to tax reverse commuters who live in the city or the city residents who flock to Hamptons beaches each summer.
Mr. Bloomberg -- who said his proposal was not a commuter tax but was instead "tax reform" -- said New York State taxpayers had already bailed out Nassau County, which ran into budget troubles even before the recession began. And he said city Hamptonites do pay taxes.
"We do pay, when we go out to the Hamptons, part of the local taxes," the mayor said. "We pay property taxes in the Hamptons -- probably property taxes, if I read what the price of real estate is in the Hamptons, that generate a lot more revenue for the local municipalities out there than the services they have to provide."' 
The mayor met later over sandwiches and popcorn with the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a strong opponent of the tax. When the meeting ended, Mr. Bruno sounded almost as if he was leaving the door open to the tax, saying, "We're not getting into the specifics of what may be acceptable or not."
But a top aide to Mr. Bruno said afterward that he was just being polite, and that in his view the commuter tax was a "nonstarter." And while Senate Republicans from New York City said they would support some form of commuter tax, as did some Senate Democrats, they conceded it would be hard to reimpose.
Governor Pataki, at a news conference, protested that his budget provided "a net fiscal benefit for the city in excess of a billion dollars." But that figure included federal aid and aid from state-controlled authorities, which Mayor Bloomberg said was already counted in his budget. An analysis by the State Senate's finance staff estimated that the governor's budget proposal would net the city $81 million. 
The governor also disputed the mayor's contention that his Medicaid proposals would cost the city money. Mr. Bloomberg said it would cost the city $250 million next year. Governor Pataki said that the proposal would net the city $40 million.
When the governor was asked about the commuter tax, he reiterated his position that new taxes would have a negative impact on the economy. "I just think that at this very sensitive time, from an economic standpoint, we would be damaging our ability to create jobs," he said.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE MILITARY; 
Despite Bush's Vow, Spending on High-Tech Weapons Remains at Low Level

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
President Bush's Department of Defense budget for 2004, at $379.9 billion, would increase spending across the board, with the biggest increases going to higher pay, a new aircraft carrier and new fighter jets.
 The budget does not include money for military action against Iraq or for the campaign against terrorism, but it does provide for sharp increases for the administration's missile defense program. 
 For nearly two years, the Bush administration has said that this budget, which would increase military spending by 4.2 percent, would transform the Pentagon by moving money from outmoded cold war armaments into high-tech weaponry. While the budget identifies about $25 billion in what the administration terms transformational programs, the bulk would go to traditional armaments, some decades old and others still in development. 
Since money for any military action requires a separate Congressional appropriation, Mr. Bush's 2004 budget covers only ongoing programs. For soldiers, it calls for a $10 billion increase for housing, health programs and raises of 2 percent to 6.25 percent.
Big increases are also requested in shipbuilding, a $12 billion line item that calls for the construction of seven vessels, including three destroyers and a carrier. Recent budgets have financed five ships annually, but the Bush administration says seven vessels must be built each year to maintain a 300-ship fleet.
The Air Force received support for its top priority, the F/A-22, a fighter jet that costs $200 million a plane and has been in development for more than 10 years. Cost overruns for the F/A-22 have been measured in hundreds of millions of dollars, leading to speculation that the program might be cut. But $5.2 billion is requested to build the first 22 of a planned 267-jet fleet.
There were also no cuts in the program for the V-22 Osprey, an aircraft being designed for the Marines that takes off like a helicopter but flies like an airplane. Although marines have been killed in test flights, the Osprey remains the service's No. 1 request. The Army is receiving a variety of vehicles to replace heavily armored tanks, including the Stryker armored vehicle, which was also thought to face cuts.
"We believe that this is a good deal for the taxpayer," Dov S. Zakheim, the Pentagon comptroller, said in a briefing. "We are spending significant portions of our budget on transformation. Our program is balanced, and it is executable."
Critics said that for all the talk by Mr. Zakheim and the administration about transformation, the budget moves only slightly in that direction.
"They are calling things transformational that have been in the works for 10 to 15 years," said Christopher Hellman, an analyst at the Center for Defense Information, which studies the Pentagon budget. " 'Transformation' has become a buzzword. But I do not see a fundamental shifting of resources away from traditional priorities to new ones."
Charles Pena, director of defense policy studies at the Cato Institute, a free-market research group, said the budget was large enough to provide for both traditional armaments as well as more futuristic items. 
"It's huge," Mr. Pena said of the budget. "The Defense Department is going to be given a carte blanche, and defense transformation is pretty much out the window. We may see some transforming stuff, but it will not take place at the expense of anything in the pipeline."
At more than $1 billion a day, the United States' military budget would be larger than the combined military spending of the next 11 nations. Mr. Zakheim took pains to point out that the 2004 military budget would represent 16.6 percent of all federal spending, compared with 27.3 percent in the late 1980's.
A total of $9.1 billion is requested for the missile defense program. A Pentagon handout said this was for 10 land-based interceptor missiles to provide "modest capability against North Korean missiles." No other country was mentioned. The Pentagon handout said that another 10 land-based missiles, along with 20 sea-based missiles, would be added in 2005, adding "modest capability against Middle East threats."
Missile defense is among the biggest of the $25 billion in budget items identified as transformational. Others are a long-range strike aircraft, unmanned submarines, aerial drones and improved communication and informational technologies.

HEADLINE: The Imbalanced Budget 

 BODY:
The $2.23 trillion budget unveiled by the Bush administration yesterday is the furthest thing from a fiscally conservative document. It shifts taxes from today's citizens to those of the future. Rather than truly giving state governments the power to be flexible, it sticks them with the responsibility for delivering the bad news to poor people who will be denied a health care safety net. The gargantuan defense budget is bloated with money for old-style weaponry needed only by defense contractors and military empire builders.
 President Bush's underlying budget philosophy can be seen in the contrast of two alarmingly aggressive proposals. In one, the administration invites states to slash Medicaid programs for many of the poor. It cynically eases the burden of deficit-ridden governors by offering them an initial budget sweetener along with the undoubtedly tempting management "freedom" to make severe cutbacks in health care benefits on their own. 
 Meanwhile, the White House would significantly enlarge the amount of investment income that could be permanently sheltered from taxes in savings and retirement accounts. This is a switch that would benefit mainly higher-bracket Americans who have the surplus income to save more than current Individual Retirement Account programs allow. Since current workers might withdraw money from their existing I.R.A.'s, pay taxes and put the money in these more flexible accounts, the plan could create a one-time increase in tax revenue now, in return for sharply diminished revenue in the future. That's typical of so much of this administration's party-now-pay-later attitude toward the government's finances.
Mr. Bush's theory is that the new savings accounts, along with an accelerated series of income tax cuts and this year's proposal for dramatically reducing the tax on dividends, will create growth that will stimulate new waves of revenue into the Treasury. But the administration dropped any budget forecast beyond five years -- the point at which the full force of all its policies will be felt, for better or for worse. Meanwhile, the new fiscal year's budget includes a record deficit of $307 billion, with the total red ink adding up to more than $1 trillion over the next five years. The Concord Coalition, the watchdog group that helped prod the budget toward balance in the 90's, is warning politicians in their tax-cutting frenzy that "deficits merely shift the tax burden toward the future." Besides that, it will shift it downward to the states, which are left to struggle with the sluggish economy and the demands of anti-terrorism preparations without the necessary increase in federal assistance.
The president's budget offers the nation the biggest military buildup since the cold-war years of Ronald Reagan, including more than $9 billion for the still unproved missile defense program. All the resolute campaign talk of finally cutting pork and defense boondoggles has gone by the wayside amid the dual drumbeats of homeland security bureaucracy and an invasion of Iraq. Yet the cost of that war is not even provided for in the budget, and the money for homeland security is heavily tilted toward capital spending for projects like overhauling the Coast Guard fleet, while other aspects of emergency preparedness, like border patrol and customs, are virtually ignored.
The administration is clearly intent on using the war on terrorism and the return to deficit budgeting to dish up a wish list of policy initiatives for the new Republican-controlled Congress. When it comes to Mr. Bush's 10-year, $400 billion Medicare reform proposal, even his party's moderates question whether the president should force the elderly to choose between the popular traditional fee-for-service care and prescription drug aid.
Mr. Bush has included some commendable nods to the compassionate side of compassionate conservatism, notably the increase in AIDS assistance for Africa. But over all, this budget is an act of buck-passing and procrastination as much as accounting.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: CONGRESS; 
For Republicans, Praise for President's Budget Is Selective

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
The Democrats had stockpiled red ink to dramatize the record deficits in President Bush's 2004 budget, and within hours of its release the printers on Capitol Hill were churning out crimson charts and the incendiary statements.
 "The most fiscally damaging budget in U.S. history," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the House Budget Committee. "President Bush is leading the most fiscally irresponsible administration in history," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader, calling the proposal "a budget-busting epic disaster." 
 But the volume of the Democratic blasts was in inverse proportion to the party's power because the Republicans who now control both houses of Congress plan to use the administration's spending plan as the foundation for next year's government. Although some acknowledged that not all of the 62 proposed tax cuts or credits in the plan would be approved, party leaders gave the weighty budget books a warmer reception than any submission has received in years. 
"In this budget, President Bush charts a straightforward course for peace and prosperity for America," said Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Finance Committee. "That includes defeating terrorism, creating jobs and dealing with looming shortfalls in entitlement spending."
Nonetheless, the Republicans seemed to acknowledge tacitly that even they may find it difficult to vote for each and every tax cut demanded by the administration if the result is an unending prospect of deficits. Having spent years accusing Democrats of driving the government into the poorhouse, many Republicans confined their praise to the president's ceilings on spending, without mentioning the deficits at all.
Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the Republican leader, took pains to note that spending grew by about 4 percent, the same as the average American paycheck. But Dr. Frist's statement did not mention the record $307 billion deficit for 2004, an amount that would grow to $2.1 trillion over 10 years if all of the administration's tax cuts were enacted.
None of the Republican leaders who spoke today made a firm commitment to passing all of those proposed tax cuts, aware that a newly influential group of moderate Republicans will not go along with the full package.
The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, called the budget an "excellent starting point," but he declined to say that he would pursue every tax cut in the plan. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert said in a statement that the plan was a "common-sense budget," and that it recognized that economic growth was necessary to restore balance. But other Republicans clearly felt obliged to address the huge gap between revenues and spending that Mr. Bush called for.
"The biggest challenge we will face is controlling spending while meeting all of these needs," said Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, chairman of the House Budget Committee, who in previous years had singed Democrats for deficit spending. Senator George V. Voinovich of Ohio said some of the cutbacks in the budget would hurt his constituents.
"Certainly there are many programs, including some important to Ohio, which take a hit," Mr. Voinovich said.
Among the most closely watched members of Congress on budgetary issues are a group of moderate Senate Republicans who may determine the future of the tax proposals, and one of them -- Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine -- made it clear that she was uncomfortable by the large number of minuses in the budget books.
"We must exercise prudence and caution," Senator Snowe said, "and balance the near term need for tax cuts to help stimulate the economy and new spending to meet pressing priorities, against the long-term goal of maintaining fiscal responsibility and balancing the budget."
The Democrats, however, dispensed with the moderates' caution and issued some of the strongest criticisms to date of the administration's plans. They expressed incredulity at the limits on spending for domestic security, education and health care, with Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts calling it a "ripoff for the rich" that starved vital domestic programs.
Several Democrats noted that the $5.6 trillion surplus of two years ago had evaporated, replaced by a $2.1 trillion deficit over 10 years that Mr. Daschle called "the worst fiscal collapse in our history."
Though Republicans said the proposed deficits were mild by historical standards, Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the ranking Democrat on the budget committee, said the deficits would be worsened by the retirement of the baby-boom generation in about a dozen years.
"I think this budget is breathtaking in its lack of fiscal responsibility," Mr. Conrad said. "It's one thing to have tax cuts at a time of economic weakness to give lift to the economy -- that makes sense, that I would support even if we were in deficit -- but what the president is proposing is huge tax cuts beyond the time of projected economic weakness, at times he's forecasting strong economic growth. He is digging a hole that is very, very deep for this country."

UP CLOSE
Budget Committees' Leaders

SENATOR DON NICKLES -- Oklahoma. Republican, chairman. Age 54. Elected 1980. Assistant Republican leader 1997 to 2003. Member of the Budget Committee since 1987. Named chairman in 2003. Worked for a family owned business that made equipment for the oil and gas industry; eventually became vice president and general manager. Forcefully advocates a reduced role for the government. Strong supporter of President Bush's economic proposals, including more tax cuts.

SENATOR KENT CONRAD -- North Dakota. Ranking Democrat. Age 54. Elected 1986. Member of the Budget Committee since 1987. Served as North Dakota's tax commissioner from 1981 until elected to the Senate. Favors a balanced budget and paying down the debt. A spokesman for opponents of the budget deficits President Bush proposes.

REPRESENTATIVE JIM NUSSLE -- Iowa. Republican, chairman. Age 42. Elected 1990. Member of the Budget Committee since 1995 and chairman since 2001. Practicing lawyer before election to House. Has long advocated limiting federal spending. Recently said the goal of a balanced budget was no longer the "holy grail" it once was. It depends on what the deficit spending is for -- war, economic recession and new priorities such as homeland security.

REPRESENTATIVE JOHN SPRATT JR. -- South Carolina. Ranking Democrat. Age 60. Elected 1982. Member of Budget Committee 1990 to 1992, then returned to the committee in 1997 as ranking Democrat. Lawyer who also was president of a bank, owner of a small insurance company and a small farm. Has said the issue of double taxation of corporation dividends needs to be resolved.
